headline: Ericsson agrees to acquire Marconi
U.N. Concern Over Ban on Its Copters in Eritrea
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan and UN Security Council request immediate reversal of decision by Eritrea to ground UN helicopters in its airspace; say grounding threatens safety of UN peacekeepers and risks resumption of border war with Ethiopia (S)

headline: Heart medicine bolsters Novartis
Gaza greenhouses herald economic harvest
How to Tame an InflatedEntertainment Budget
abstract: You probably spend more on entertainment than you do on groceries, clothing or gasoline.      If you don't believe it, take a few minutes to total your monthly costs, starting with the services that have you locked in: basic cable television, and any premium channels, like HBO or Showtime; Netflix to rent videos; TiVo for digital recording; your high-speed Internet connection; and perhaps, satellite radio and streaming music like Yahoo Music. You are already up to about $200 a month, or $2,400 a year.

headline: Several Thousand Protest Trade Talks in Hong Kong
abstract: Protesters took to the streets peacefully as trade ministers arrived for the World Trade Organization conference.

headline: Officials: APEC leaders must speak strongly on WTO talks
China quake kills 15; hundreds injured
Antitrust Suit Turns Into a Partnership for Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft finally put its antitrust troubles in the United States behind it yesterday by agreeing to pay RealNetworks $761 million to settle a lawsuit. The two former enemies agreed to forge a partnership that promises to heighten the competitive pressure on the dominant company in digital music, Apple Computer.     The announcement reflects how much the landscape in the software and digital media markets has changed in the last few years. The strategies and interests of Microsoft and RealNetworks have shifted as well, making them allies.

headline: Dubai to Buy P&O, British Shipping Line, for $5.7 Billion
abstract: Dubai, the upstart sheikdom of the United Arab Emirates, agreed Tuesday to purchase the storied British shipping company Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation for ¬£3.3 billion ($5.7 billion), strengthening Dubai's position as a center of commerce and transport.      P&O, as it is known, got its start in the 1830's carrying mail among Portugal, Spain and England, but it later expanded to ferry passengers and goods throughout the British Empire. The company now has operations in 100 global ports as well as a passenger ferry service in Europe and a real estate portfolio.

headline: Private equity groups confirm deal for Ahlsell
Stocks: Acquisitions and falling oil prices lift stocks
Outcry as Jakarta tries to revive paper industry
One Degree of Separation on the Board
abstract: IS it a problem for Time Warner shareholders to have Robert C. Clark, a former dean of Harvard Law School, representing them as a director? Mr. Clark, after all, also sits on the board of Lazard, the investment bank advising Carl C. Icahn on how best to rattle Time Warner management's cage.     Not to worry, say a raft of corporate governance gurus. If anyone can navigate such ethical shoals, they say, it is Mr. Clark, who is a Harvard University Distinguished Service Professor.

headline: Nissan's Mr. Fix-It Is the Talk of Detroit
abstract: Carlos Ghosn, one of the world's smoothest car pitchmen, skipped a beat.     ''That is very flattering,'' he said Thursday night, stalling for time after learning that auto analysts in Detroit told reporters this week that he, the man who turned around the Nissan Motor Company, would be the dream manager to turn around General Motors. ''It is better to be cited this way than the other way around, that this is a guy you need to avoid.''

headline: In rural China, an old craft refuses to die
Europa: It's not just Turkey that must look at changing
U.S. Envoy Warns Against Deposing Nicaragua's Leader
abstract: Robert B. Zoellick, the American deputy secretary of state, intended to help defuse a political crisis.

headline: Guatemala Storm Toll Expected to Top 1,000
abstract: The official death toll in the floods that devastated Guatemala last week held steady on Tuesday at 652 people.      But authorities for the first time began to acknowledge that the hundreds of missing were probably dead as well, and that the final toll could be 1,100 to 1,300 people.

headline: GOOD OR BAD?
abstract: When its chief executive resigned last week, the American Italian Pasta Company declined to say if he did so for ''good reason.'' It is an important point. If the C.E.O., Timothy S. Webster, 44, left for ''good reason,'' as defined in his employment contract, the company is obliged to pay him for two more years.      His 2004 salary was $583,922, so that could amount to a million-dollar golden handshake from a company still recovering from accounting irregularities on his watch and struggling to revive a share price that has fallen almost 90 percent from its record, high in 2002.

headline: The Embattled Swipe-Card Hotel Key
abstract: THE magnetic hotel room key, one of the lodging industry's most popular but controversial creations, is losing some of its attraction.     New technology and old worries are edging the systems closer to extinction. Perhaps at no time will that be more apparent than at next week's International Hotel/Motel and Restaurant Show in New York, billed as the world's largest hotel industry event.

headline: Industry at risk, GM strikes deal with union
Which Chart Isn't Telling the Truth?
abstract: WHAT'S wrong with these pictures -- the ones charting the courses of the Dow Jones industrial average and the yield curve?      The Dow is hovering on the threshold of 11,000 after languishing for more than four years on the other side of the line. And the bond market is close to its first inverted yield curve in five years, meaning that Treasury instruments with long maturities have lower yields than shorter-dated paper.

headline: Kazakh President Re-elected; Voting Flawed, Observers Say
abstract: Kazakh Pres Nursultan Nazarbayev wins third term in office, officially receiving 91 percent of votes in election that international observers say did not meet democratic standards; photo; map (M)

headline: Handing over power in an Iraqi cauldron
Japan Must Show 'Deep Remorse' For Wartime Actions, Official Says
abstract: Japanese Foreign Min Taro Aso says Japan must show 'deep remorse' for its actions in World War II; Aso and other Japanese leaders have in recent years played down country's wartime record of atrocities in China and Korea, and Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi continues to make annual visits to shrine that honors Japan's 2.5 million war dead, including war criminals; Aso's latest remarks come as Koizumi prepares to fly to Malaysia to attend two summit meetings of Assn of Southeast Asian Nations, where he risks being isolated because China and South Korea refuse to engage in separate, three-way meetings with Japan (M)

headline: Study Finds Small Developing Lands Hit Hardest by 'Brain Drain'
abstract: World Bank study finds poor countries across Africa, Central America and Caribbean are losing staggering portions of their college-educated workers to wealthy democracies; analysts say study documents troubling pattern of 'brain drain,' flight of skilled middle-class workers who could help lift their countries out of poverty; chart (M)

headline: From Pants to Paper
abstract: I'M an only child. My father died when I was 12, after which my mother and I were left to run our men's clothing store until I graduated from college. My mother had never worked in the business. After she was forced to let the seamstress go, I had to learn how to take up hems. I'm the only C.E.O. I know who can alter a pair of men's pants.     It was a traumatic time for us, but I had an otherwise wonderful childhood in Brunswick, Ga., in the 1950's. It was a resort town. We went water-skiing on New Year's Day, and I played golf from the age of 9. I still play golf with Jimmy Blanchard, chairman of Synovus, and I'm still friends with many other golf buddies from back then.

headline: Pakistani Raped by Village Order Is to Visit U.S.
abstract: Mukhtar Mai, the Pakistani woman whose gang rape in 2002 on the orders of a village council caused international outrage, said Friday that she planned to visit the United States next week to receive an award from an American women's magazine.      During her trip, Ms. Mukhtar said, she also plans to help raise funds for the victims of the devastating earthquake that killed more than 50,000 people in Pakistan.

headline: Irish church's sex abuse was covered up
Greenspan Points to Danger of Rising Budget Deficits
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, warned of the dangers of rising budget and trade deficits in two speeches on Friday.     Speaking at a meeting here of the Group of 7 finance ministers, he said the growing American trade deficit could be ''quite painful'' for the world economy if it was not arrested. He urged the United States and other countries with trade deficits to stop the ''pernicious drift toward fiscal instability.''

headline: Another Easterner joins Merkel atop German political pole
Investor Moves to Block KPMG Settlement
abstract: A Florida investor is seeking to block a $195 million preliminary settlement between tax shelter investors and KPMG, and to disqualify the settlement's lawyers over what he calls a major conflict of interest.     The investor, Mark Kottler of Boca Raton, Fla., argued in a brief filed in federal court in Newark on Thursday that lawyers at Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman negotiated the settlement on behalf of separate plaintiffs in a class action against KPMG.

headline: World Briefing: Asia, Americas, Middle East, Europe
abstract: ASIA.

headline: In Russia, Pollution Is Good for Business
abstract: By its own admission, Russia's electricity monopoly is the world's largest corporate producer of greenhouse gases, accounting -- by itself -- for nearly as much carbon dioxide as is emitted by Britain.      From smokestacks across Russia's 11 time zones, the company, Unified Energy Systems, spews out 2 percent of all human-generated carbon dioxide accumulating in the atmosphere.

headline: Ramadan Ritual: Fast Daily, Pray, Head to the Mall
abstract: The decorations are hanging, the cash registers are clanging, and the air of holiday cheer is everywhere. For a holy month, Ramadan is not what it used to be.      Once an ascetic month of fasting, prayer and reflection on God, Ramadan has gradually taken on the commercial trappings of Christmas and Hanukkah, from the hanging lights that festoon windows to the Ramadan greeting cards and Ramadan sales and advertising campaigns that have become the backbone of commerce for the month.

headline: Europe Inc. is staying mostly on sidelines
Chicago's 'Mayor for Life' seems less so
In French suburbs, rage 'is only asleep'
Beijing vows to curb asset-investment rise
Former Premier Vajpayee Retires From Indian Politics at 81
abstract: Atal Bihari Vajpayee, a former prime minister of India, has announced his retirement from politics, ushering in an era of uncertainty for the country's principal opposition party.     A lifelong bachelor known for his love of Urdu poetry, Mr. Vajpayee, 81, was the avuncular face of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, eventually bringing it out of the fringes and into the political mainstream to challenge the once-invincible Congress Party.

headline: What Makes a Nation More Productive? It's Not Just Technology
abstract: IN 2001, the stock market meltdown and a brief recession threw cold water on the widely held belief that the United States economy, juiced by a technological revolution, had entered a new era of limitless, inflation-free growth. But today, as bubble-era books like ''Dow 36,000'' collect dust on library shelves, evidence is mounting that there may be a new economy after all.     In the late 1990's, growth in labor productivity -- the amount of output per hour per worker -- kicked into a higher gear. From 1996 through 1999, it grew at a blistering annual rate of 2.5 percent, compared with 1.4 percent from 1972 to 1995. Economists generally believed that the higher rate was a byproduct of the new economy. Much of the growth was spurred by the highly productive businesses that made information technology products -- companies like Dell, Intel and Microsoft -- and by their customers, who spent heavily to deploy productivity-enhancing PC's and software.

headline: Tax Proposal by G.O.P. Would Cut $70 Billion
abstract: The Senate's top Republican tax writer unveiled a bill on Tuesday that would provide $70 billion in tax cuts, including $7 billion for the Gulf Coast areas damaged by Hurricane Katrina.     The bill, sponsored by Senator Charles E. Grassley, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, fell short of what President Bush and Republican leaders had been seeking and it could be blocked by Democrats and moderate Republicans.

headline: Sergeant May Face Court-Martial in Deaths of 2 G.I.'s in Iraq
abstract: An inquiry has recommended that a staff sergeant face court-martial in the deaths of two U.S. soldiers last spring in Tikrit.

headline: Marseille's recipe for composure
Investing: Picking out quirky stock
Pakistan and India to Hold Talk on Kashmir Quake Survivors
abstract: Indian delegation will arrive in Islamabad, Pakistan, to determine points at which earthquake survivors will be allowed to cross Line of Control in disputed Kashmir region to visit relatives and receive aid (S)

headline: Some Corporate Scandals Near Partial Resolutions
abstract: CORPORATE scandals were back in the news again this week, not because new ones were breaking but because old ones were inching toward resolution. Consumers regained some confidence, however, and their optimism led some economists to brighten their outlooks for 2006.    EXECUTIVE FLIP -- Less than two weeks before he was to stand trial with the two most senior former executives of Enron, the company's former accounting chief, Richard A. Causey, agreed to plead guilty to a single count of securities fraud and to cooperate with prosecutors in pursuing the other two men.     Mr. Causey's unexpected switch, after years of resisting the federal authorities' pressure, significantly shifts the dynamics of the trial, which will now involve only Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive, and Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former president who was also briefly the chief executive.

headline: Rules and Advice for Turning You Inc. From Idea to Reality
abstract: YOU'RE slaving away at your job, and you can tell you're going to finish yet another tedious task on time. Your boss is nice enough. The pay is decent, but you need something more. So amid the buzz of the office environment, you temporarily turn your attention to the Web to order supplies for You Inc., the small business you have quietly started on the side.      Wait a minute. You have crossed the line. According to experts on business ethics, workers aren't supposed to use their employer's resources for their own entrepreneurial endeavors.

headline: Along With 'I Do' Comes a Chance to Say 'We Care'
abstract: JENNIFER VAN ZANDT'S wedding in Key Largo, Fla., had all the trimmings: Friday night party, Saturday celebration, drinks, dancing and merriment. And something else: rather than taking home a commemorative box of chocolates or a trinket, the guests helped save a few manatees.     When Mrs. Van Zandt and Derek, who is now her husband, started planning their nuptials last year, they knew that they wanted to put the money they would have spent on favors to better use.

headline: Chinese government defended fatal police shootings
Iranians Play Down President's Attack on Israel
abstract: Iran's president stood by his call to "wipe Israel off the map" while commentators suggested it was a sign of what they consider his amateurism.

headline: Stem-cell researcher vows to prove work
World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Hears Challenge To Law On Downing Hijacked Planes
abstract: Germany's highest court begins hearing challenge to law that authorizes defense minister to order shooting down of civilian airliner if it is hijacked by terrorists (S)

headline: Bomb kills 20 in Basra while U.S. toll spikes
Letter from New York: Battle against bird flu must start at its source
Democrats pounce on indictment
If You Don't Eat or Drive, Inflation's No Problem
abstract: ASIDE from the stuff that's becoming more expensive, like food and energy, there is no problem with inflation in the economy. That's the message economists want us to take from recent inflation reports.     On Oct. 14, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said the Consumer Price Index, the main inflation gauge, rose by a whopping 1.2 percent in September and by 4.7 percent in the last 12 months. The bureau also said the Producer Price Index, which measures inflation experienced by businesses, rose 1.9 percent in September alone.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Berlusconi Agrees To April Election
abstract: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi agrees to proposal from opposition center-left candidate Romano Prodi to hold national elections on April 9; rejects Prodi's call for local elections on same day and schedules them for May instead; photo (M)

headline: EU Parliament toughens laws on chemicals
UN cites progress on opium in Afghanistan
Germany Frees Hijacker Who Killed U.S. Sailor
abstract: A parole board has released a Lebanese man convicted of killing a Navy diver during the 1985 hijacking of a T.W.A. jetliner.

headline: For rebels, targets are often Iraqis
A Tiny Tower of Sound, and One Ring Controls It All
abstract: BeoSound 3 device--transistor radio, portable music system and alarm clock--retails for $850; photo (S)

headline: Initial results give Muslim Brotherhood 19%
Cellphones pick up a British accent
Johnson Threatens to Drop Plan to Buy Guidant
abstract: Johnson & Johnson wants to substantially renegotiate the terms of the deal for the manufacturer of heart devices.

headline: DataBank; Stocks Are Down, Even After a T.G.I.F. Party
abstract: A rally on Friday wasn't enough to make up for earlier declines that sent the stock market into negative territory for the week.      The price of oil set the tone for stocks, as it has so often this year. On Friday, the futures price of a barrel of crude fell to $59.39 in New York from $60.66 on Thursday, setting off a surge in the stock market. But oil had risen for most of the week and discouraged many traders. Intel, the semiconductor company, fell 4.9 percent for the week, the worst performance among the Dow industrials. Its sales forecast for the fourth quarter disappointed Wall Street, although the stock gained 1.5 percent on Friday, trimming some of its earlier losses.

headline: Carriers Adopt Content Rating For Cellphones
abstract: The nation's major cellular phone carriers said yesterday that they had adopted a content rating system for video, music, pictures and games that they sell to cellphone users -- a development that could pave the way for them to begin selling pornography and sex-oriented content on mobile devices.     The carriers said the ratings, meant to mimic content classifications for movies and video games, are voluntary.

headline: A widow putsIndonesianjustice on trial
Boy's Web cam opens portal to a grim world
3M hires an outsider to steer its businesses
Some Investors Wonder if Mellon Financial Is Being All It Can Be
abstract: Some shareholders of Mellon Financial believe it has not done enough to realize its potential value despite its transformation over last six years from slow-growing mid-Atlantic bank into asset management giant; believe Mellon should sell, spin off or merge all or some of its parts; Martin G McGuinn, Mellon's chief executive, insists that he now has right mix of businesses and right management to move company's stock price higher; photo; graph (M)

headline: Microsoft threatened with daily EU fines
Brazil rejects gun banin rebuff to the police
Bulgaria sees hope for nurses sentenced to die in Libya
LOOKING AHEAD
abstract: JOBS, JOBS, JOBS -- Only probably fewer of them this time. The nonfarm payroll survey due Friday is likely to show a net decline in jobs in September for the first time in more than two years. Blame Hurricane Katrina in part for the loss, although the rebuilding effort is creating work for lots of people, too. Expect the September unemployment rate, also being reported Friday, to tick up from August's 4.9 percent, but with the economy continuing to roll along despite storms and oil shortages, not by much. A good bet would be 5 percent.     OTHER VITAL SIGNS -- The ISM Manufacturing Index for September, being released today, will probably show some slippage from August. Construction spending for August and car sales for September are also being reported today. Statistics on factory orders for August and chain store retail sales for September will be coming out tomorrow and jobless claims figures will be reported on Thursday.

headline: Louisiana ends sweep for bodies
Explosion at Israeli mall kills at least five
Guidant Sues Johnson & Johnson for Completion of Merger
abstract: Guidant Corp files federal lawsuit to force Johnson & Johnson to complete its $25.4 billion acquisition of company; Johnson & Johnson contends that deal for Guidant is void because of Guidant's financial and legal problems; Guidant says third quarter profit fell 57 percent because of series of recent recalls of its devices; warns fourth-quarter results are likely to be lower than last year's; some industry analysts believe new deal could still be struck at lower price; Guidant also discloses that Securities and Exchange Commission opened formal formal probe into timing of company disclosures also about problem heart devices and trading in company stock; consortium of state attorneys general has requested Guidant records to determine if it might have violated state laws in connection with device sales; company is already under investigation by Food and Drug Administration and Justice Department in connection with its handling of product safety issues; Guidant says third-quarter profit fell to $65.4 million from $153.6 million year earlier; revenue dropped to $795 million, from $924.5 million; graph (M)

headline: Croatian war crimes suspect is arrested in Spain
Europe Names a Trustee to Monitor Microsoft
abstract: Eighteen months after finding Microsoft guilty of monopoly abuse, the European Commission has appointed a trustee to ensure that the company makes the changes called for in the ruling.     Neil Barrett, a computer scientist at Cranfield University in Britain, will monitor Microsoft's compliance and report directly to the competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes, Ms. Kroes said at a news conference.

headline: Thorny Issue for Board: How to Value Pension Plans
abstract: The board that writes the professional accounting rules for American businesses voted unanimously Thursday to start a far-reaching revision of the rules for reporting pensions and other retirement plans, a project that is sure to be contentious, especially among companies with big retirement plans.     To keep the project from bogging down from the start, the Financial Accounting Standards Board agreed to focus on a single issue at first: how to express the true economic value of a company's retirement plans on its balance sheet.

headline: Why 'Antiquities Trials' Focus on America
abstract: Analysis of dispute betwen Metropolitan Museum of Art and Italian Culture Ministry over claims by Italy that Met's vast collection of Italian antiquities contains items that were illegally excavated from Italy; Met director Philippe de Montebello is in Rome meeting with Italian officials in attempt to establish true provenance of these antiquities; Italy, bolstered by new evidence, has begun looking more closely at acquisitions of Italian treasures by American museums, not only the Met and J Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, but also Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, and Cleveland Museum of Art (M)

headline: The Power of Persistence
abstract: I GREW up in Amherst, Mass., in a family that was very connected to Amherst College. My father was alumni secretary. Every weekend our house was filled with people from diverse backgrounds. My parents were scout leaders, and from an early age I felt an obligation to do things for others.     I love adventure. In my senior year in college, I took part in a psychology experiment involving how people react to fear. We parachuted out of a plane. On the sixth jump my chute didn't open, which wasn't part of the plan. I had a spare on my chest, but for several moments I faced a huge danger. The fact that I remained calm was life-changing.

headline: New Home Sales Rise, but Prices Decline
abstract: Sales of new homes rose in September from the previous month, but prices dropped and the number of homes for sale increased.

headline: Farm Goods Impasse Stalls Trade Talks in Hong Kong
abstract: Global trade talks here are making little progress because of an impasse over agriculture, reinforcing worries that the negotiations may resolve little before ending late Sunday, trade ministers said Thursday.     Negotiators for the United States and the European Union have been restating their positions, each trying to turn the debate to their favorite complaints against the other side, while reaching no meaningful compromises, officials on both sides said.

headline: Straw attacks French system
Activist Throws Water at Gorbachev
abstract: A youth activist splashed a glass of water in the face of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, who is more popular in the West than in Russia. Mr. Gorbachev was speaking at a roundtable in Moscow about his reforms of the late 1980's known as perestroika. The activist, from the left-leaning Red Youth Vanguard, said he disagreed with Mr. Gorbachev's policies, the Interfax news agency reported. He was arrested.   Andrew Kramer (NYT)

headline: Viacom to Split Sooner
abstract: Viacom said that its split into two businesses would probably be complete by the end of the year, slightly ahead of its estimate.

headline: Time Warner Reports Improved Earnings
abstract: Time Warner announces improved earnings and says it will buy back $12.5 billion worth of its shares in wake of criticism from activist investor Carl C Icahn; revenue increased in third quarter to $10.5 billion from $9.9 billion year earlier, while operating income before depreciation and amortization rose to $2.6 billion from $2.4 billion; net income increased 80 percent, to $897 million; chairman Richard D Parsons comments (M)

headline: Indonesia mine case dropped
Ruling Shiite Parties to Run Together in Iraqi Elections
abstract: The deal virtual ensured that the religious parties, all with strong Iranian ties, will remain a formidable force in the new government.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Da Silva Ally To Head Party
abstract: Worker's Party, Brazil's governing party, chooses Ricardo Berzoini as new chief; former president, treasurer and secretary general all resigned after revelations of involvement in political scandal (S)

headline: Trial begins in June attack in China
Move over, Mo√´t: British bubbly sparkles
China overtakes U.S. as tech supplier
Japanese carmakers aiming high and low for sales at home
Europe and Americas
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: G.E. to Sell Insurance Business to Swiss Re
abstract: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it was selling its troubled reinsurance business for $6.8 billion to Swiss Re, which will become the largest company in the world selling insurance to insurance companies.     The insurance business has been ''a tough strategic fit for G.E.,'' said Jeffrey R. Immelt, the company's chief executive, who wants to focus on faster-growing sectors. Over the last five years, he said, G.E.'s main insurance unit has lost $700 million and required the infusion of $3.2 billion.

headline: Liberty Global to Buy Swiss Cable Operator
abstract: Liberty Global Inc., the cable television company controlled by John C. Malone, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a Swiss cable operator, Cablecom Holdings, for $2.2 billion to acquire two million new customers in Europe.     The purchase represents Mr. Malone's continued interest in expanding his cable holdings overseas, where he has told investors he sees many of the same opportunities that allowed him to build Tele-Communications Inc. into the largest cable operator in the United States before selling it to AT&T in 1999.

headline: Support for Sony DVD Format
abstract: Warner Brothers Entertainment says it will produce high-definition DVD's in Blu-ray format championed by Sony in addition to standard being promoted by Toshiba and rival group; move comes nearly three weeks after Paramount Pictures made similar announcement; Universal Studios is expected to follow (M)

headline: 2nd Term Likely for Colombia's Leader
abstract: President √É¬Ålvaro Uribe of Colombia will probably be able to run for a second term after a court approved an amendment to permit re-election.

headline: Trade Talks Now Expected to Focus on Exports of Poorest Nations
abstract: Recognizing that little progress can be expected on intractable issues like farm subsidies, officials at global trade talks scheduled to begin here on Tuesday now appear likely to focus heavily on increasing exports from the world's poorest countries.     Pascal Lamy, director general of the World Trade Organization, and John Tsang, Hong Kong's trade minister and chairman of the W.T.O. ministerial conference here, have called with increasing emphasis in the last few days for a detailed agreement eliminating all duties and quotas on the exports of at least 32 of the world's poor countries.

headline: Bomber kills 10 on Iraqi bus
World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Prison For Afghan War Crimes
abstract: A court handed down prison sentences to two former Afghan generals for torture and other war crimes in Afghanistan during the Soviet occupation in the 1980's. The men, Heshamuddin Hesam, who received a term of 12 years, and Habibula Jalalzoy, who received 9 years, had sought asylum in the Netherlands.   Marlise Simons (NYT)

headline: U.S. and China Agree on Import Quotas for Textiles
abstract: The deal raised the volumes of clothing that the United States would accept from China when compared with previous arrangements.

headline: India and China woo cross-border business
Eight killed in attempted Iraqi prison break
Bristol-Myers May End Plans for Oral Diabetes Treatment
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb said last night that it might abandon a proposed diabetes drug that it had been developing for years and had until recently hoped might become a blockbuster.      Dropping the drug, Pargluva, an oral treatment for diabetes, would be a setback for Bristol-Myers and its Pargluva marketing partner, Merck. The shares of both companies fell in after-hours trading, following Bristol-Myers's release of a statement discussing its options.

headline: Counting on the Viagra brand in India
World Briefing: Africa, Asia, Americas, Europe
abstract: AFRICA.

headline: Vodafone Agrees to Acquire a 10% Stake In Mobile Telephone Company in India
abstract: The Vodafone Group has agreed to buy 10 percent of the largest mobile phone company in India, Bharti Tele-Ventures, for $1.5 billion, Bharti said yesterday. Bharti, which is based in New Delhi, has a fifth of the mobile services market in India. Prices for mobile phone service in India, a country of one billion people, are among the lowest in the world, at less than 2 cents a minute, and 2.5 million new subscribers are added each month. Vodafone, which is based in Britain, paid about 351 rupees ($7.80) a share for the Bharti stake, about a 7.5 percent premium.   Saritha Rai (NYT)

headline: $60 oil a bonanza for private bankers, Islamic sector included
Oil Producers Are Urged to Invest in More Capacity
abstract: New report by International Energy Agency warns that oil prices will keep rising over next two decades unless oil-rich nations of Middle East and North Africa substantailly increase investments in their energy sectors; agency estimates that $3 trillion is needed for exploration, development and refining worldwide over next 25 years, but acknowledges that some countries might not be willing to invest in higher output (M)

headline: TechEarnings: Net drops as BT loses customers
Israelis Kill Palestinian and Wound 9 in Airstrike
abstract: Israeli airstrike kills Palestinian militant Mahmoud Arkhan in Gaza Strip and wounds at least nine other Palestinians as Israel steps up military actions in wake of suicide bombing in Netanya; military claims Arkhan had role in attacks on Israeli troops, including killing of soldier in June (M)

headline: Wanted: Strong words from APEC
Terrorists in Europe find base in Belgium
Wal-Mart's Health Care Struggle Is Corporate America's, Too
abstract: Back in the spring, amid relentless criticism that Wal-Mart Stores was failing to provide affordable health care to employees, executives at the company decided to take a detailed look at its benefits.      Wal-Mart knew its health costs were spiraling upward out of control, said M. Susan Chambers, the senior executive who led the initiative, but it was surprised to discover that its critics had a point. Almost half of the children of employees were covered only by government social-service programs like Medicaid or had no insurance at all.

headline: First on To-Do List: Tame Inflation
abstract: Ben S. Bernanke's first task as Fed chairman is likely to be bringing down inflation without causing too much damage to the economy along the way.

headline: Bush Keeps Open Mind on Choice to Run Fed
abstract: With less than four months before Alan Greenspan's retirement, President Bush is saying that he wants someone independent from politics as his successor.

headline: Ex-Chief of Qwest Is Indicted
abstract: Federal prosecutors announced that Joseph P. Nacchio  had been indicted on charges of insider trading.

headline: Curbs on Insurance for  Military Are Urged
abstract: The Government Accountability Office is strongly urging Congress to protect military personnel from deceptive sales practices.

headline: Will You Still Need Me, Will You Still Read Me?
abstract: WHEN the thousandth issue of Rolling Stone magazine rolls off the presses in May, its cover will feature an elaborate three-dimensional homage to ''Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band.'' Drawing inspiration from the lineup of celebrities whose images graced that seminal Beatles recording, the magazine will tip its hat to the trove of musicians, entertainers and politicians who have inhabited its pages since its founding in 1967.     ''It's going to be a version of the past 40 years of people who have influenced us and are part of our Gestalt, our zeitgeist,'' said the magazine's founder, publisher and editor, Jann S. Wenner, his feet propped atop a table in his sleekly appointed corner office in Midtown Manhattan. ''It's Richard Pryor and Jimmy Carter and it's Billy Joel and it's Bono and the Beatles and the Stones and Ike and Tina Turner and Madonna and Prince. It's the big family.''

headline: Lufthansa and unions reach a pact
Kaczynskiis electedpresidentin Poland
3 banks picked for Telstra sale
Sarkozy ups ante in France
World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Prime Minister Promises Handgun Ban
abstract: Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin pledges to ban handguns in Canada to end rash of gang shootings in Toronto, where number of gun-related murders has doubled since 2004; pledge will be critical 2006 election issue (S)

headline: The Trans-Atlantic Solution
abstract: Delta Air Lines, which filed for bankruptcy protection in September, will announce wave of new international flights to cities like Edinburgh, Budapest and Venice, additions that Delta says will make it biggest airline crossing Atlantic; new flights will begin next year, and will allow Delta to eclipse competitors like American, British Airways and Continental; new international flights are latest sign of growing revival in international service by American carriers, which significantly cut back those routes after Sept 2001 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington; photo (M)

headline: 4 Tenet Doctors Settle U.S. Case
abstract: Four doctors who worked at a former Tenet Healthcare Corporation hospital in California have agreed to pay $32.5 million to settle a federal inquiry into claims that they performed unnecessary procedures.     Tenet separately agreed to pay $5.5 million to settle claims against the company, McGregor W. Scott, the United States attorney in Sacramento, said yesterday. Tenet previously agreed to pay $54 million in August 2003 to settle government civil claims in the case.

headline: Poultry Power: China, With Huge Flocks, Is at Big Flu Risk
abstract: Health officials in China, world's biggest producer of poultry, quarrel with researchers who suggest that avian influenza remains problem there, and they refuse to share virus samples from infected wild birds this year; Chinese government insists that no poultry in country has disease now, but Hong Kong University scientists wrote in journal Nature that infected migratory birds in China appear to have contracted disease and that virus has spread to East Asia, Russia, Kazakhstan, Turkey and Romania; although strain of avian influenza found in China is different, older strain than one that has infected 100 people in Thailand and Vietnam in past two years, it is similar to one that has bedeviled Indonesia's poultry industry in past year and has infected at least six people there in last two months; photo (M)

headline: Red crystal joins other aid symbols
Gadfly leader seeks Rio's reinvention
The EU budget face-off: Sweden
EU launches first Galileo satellite
Dispute Over Division of Authority at the U.N. Grows
abstract: The dispute has prompted a warning from John R. Bolton, the American ambassador, that the U.S. may look elsewhere to settle international problems.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Powerful Quake In Region
abstract: A powerful earthquake, centered roughly 60 miles north of the Pakistani capital, Islamabad, sent tremors across the region early on Saturday morning, shaking buildings as far as the Indian capital, Delhi, to the east and the Afghan capital, Kabul, to the west. Estimates of the intensity of the quake varied from 6.8 to 7.8 on the Richter scale, with the United States Geological Survey putting the magnitude at 7.6. There were no immediate estimates available of casualties. But the intensity and scope of the earthquake, across densely populated South Asia, could cause considerable damage.   Somini Sengupta (NYT)

headline: Shoppers of the World, Unite
abstract: THE Consumerist (consumerist.com), the newest blog in the expanding Gawker Media empire, displays a healthy antipathy toward everything it thinks is wrong with the retail and service sectors.     It operates on the idea that since we are stuck with a business culture that is increasingly hostile toward consumers, we should make the best of it.

headline: Corruption Endangers a Treasure of the Caspian
abstract: Latest enemy of Caspian Sea sturgeon, fish prized for its briny eggs, is corruption; since collapse of Soviet Union, unchecked fishing and struggling hatcheries have led to catches of less than 10 percent of historic highs; poachers who disregard international and domestic regulation protecting surviving stock are abetted by lawlessness and graft; fishing for certain species has been banned since early 1960's, except for brief periods, yet it takes place in plain sight; fishermen share their profits, and sometimes part of their catch, with authorities in Nardaran, Azerbaijan, in familial type of relationship; some say illegal behavior defines Caspian sturgeon trade even with stringent regulation, and there is blatant violation of rules; map; photos (M)

headline: Congress authorized spying, Bush says
Allies get speedy Merkel visit
Germans wait, and watch, and wait
Cheney Offers Support to Afghanistan's Parliament
abstract: The vice president traveled today to Afghanistan with words of praise and encouragement for the country.

headline: As Gas Prices Fall, Thirsty S.U.V.'s Regain Their Allure
abstract: Remember all those cosmic statements a month or so ago about how soaring gasoline prices had ended America's decade-plus infatuation with low-mileage sport utility vehicles -- and how drivers were returning to the snug-fitting embrace of small, efficient cars?      Well, never mind. Displaying an instinct for making a long-term decision based on the latest short-term numbers, many drivers have rushed back to flirting with those jilted gas guzzlers.

headline: German Socialist to Quit; Coalition in Doubt
abstract: Negotiations to form a new German government were thrown into jeopardy Monday when the leader of one of the two main parties said he would step down after losing an internal power struggle.     The chairman of the Social Democratic Party, Franz M√ºntefering, said he would not run for re-election next month after the party's executive committee rejected his candidate for its No. 2 position.

headline: Mannesmann ruling reflects Germany's mood
Samsung sets goal of doubling sales by '10
More signs in Japan of sustained growth
U.N. Cites Progress on Opium in Afghanistan, but Renews Warning
abstract: Afghanistan has cut back on opium poppy cultivation in the past year, but is still in danger of becoming a "narco-state."

headline: As Reality TV Hits Maturity, Networks Lower Expectations
abstract: Early ratings in new television season show some slippage among reality shows, including Survivor and The Amazing Race on CBS and The Apprenctice on NBC; interest in reality shows has already cooled in Britian, where many of formats originated; most executives express no real concern, and networks are expected to continue coming up with reality shows, if only because they are cheaper to produce than most scripted shows; photo (M)

headline: A delay for Black
Japanese rail tycoon is convicted
Psst: Want to Know A 'Dirty Little Secret'?
abstract: The prevailing wisdom on skilled work being shifted abroad -- outsourced -- is that it is anecdotally alarming but not really a big deal economically. Sure, the thinking goes, some software engineers and others are losing their jobs to low-cost workers in India, but there is always churning in the dynamic American job market of 130 million people. It's what makes the United States economy competitive.      Last Monday, at a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York, Mark R. Anderson, editor of The Strategic News Service, a technology newsletter, sounded like a traitor to his class. He was speaking to a group of technology executives and venture capitalists, fans of Mr. Anderson but also champions of outsourcing.

headline: Dutch future in Afghan force uncertain
Rumors of chief's exit hurt Burberry
On advertising: When brands join cast, plot can get murky
Microsoft to license 'open' Office formats
Bush's Speech on Iraq and Terrorism
abstract: Following is a transcript of a Veterans Day speech by President Bush on the fight against terrorism at Wilkes-Barre, Pa., today.

headline: Hollywood Waits to See Wiretapping Indictment
abstract: Anthony Pellicano, onetime private detective to stars who is finishing 30-month sentence on federal firearms charges, expects to be indicted again in weeks; FBI accuses Pellicano of engaging in widespread illegal wiretapping on behalf of lawyers and their clients, with help of rogue law enforcement officer and telephone company worker; Hollywood film industry is bracing for possibility that damage will not end with disgraced Pellicano; among people called before grand jury or questioned by federal agents are Kevin Huvane and Brian Lourd, top partners at Creative Artists Agency, Michael S Ovitz, onetime president of Walt Disney Co who headed Creative Artists, Ron Meyer, president of Universal Studios and former partner at Creative Artists, Brad Grey, chairman of Paramount Pictures and entertainment lawyer Bert Fields; case against Pellicano originated in June 2002 when reporter Anita Busch was threatened while she was pursuing article for Los Angeles Times about actor Steven Seagal and his relationship with mob figure; photos (M)

headline: European Phone Industry Split on the Need to Bulk Up
abstract: Heated deal talk may be swirling around European telecommunications companies, but industry is still deeply divided about whether big cross-border mergers make sense; in wake of news that executives from Telefonica of Spain have made overtures to KPN of Netherlands in recent weeks, some executives and and bankers argue that big acquisitions are only way for telecommunications companies to cut costs and grow quickly (M)

headline: After the Debt Feast Comes the Heartburn
abstract: DOES a financial train wreck lie dead ahead for American consumers and investors? Paul Kasriel, chief economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago fears as much. He reckons that even a mild recession next year could spiral into something ugly, given the combination of rising interest rates, off-the-charts consumer debt and a cooling housing market.      ''We have a very accident-prone economy,'' Mr. Kasriel said. ''We have the most highly leveraged economy in the postwar period, and the Fed is increasing rates. In the past 30 years or so, whenever the Fed has raised interest rates, we've quite frequently had financial accidents.''

headline: A Belgian Mystery: Rwandan Who Aided Tribunal on Genocide Is Found Dead in a Canal
abstract: A former Rwandan government minister indicted on charges of genocide has been found dead, his mangled body floating in a canal in Brussels, according to the Belgian police.      The minister, Juvenal Uwilingiyimana, 54, had been cooperating with prosecutors from the United Nations tribunal in Arusha, Tanzania, which is addressing the genocide in Rwanda in 1994. He met with investigators for the last time three days before disappearing on Nov. 21.

headline: Japan venture plans Web TV
19 Iraqi Army Soldiers Are Killed as Insurgents Fire on a Convoy
abstract: Insurgents attacked an Iraqi Army convoy north of Baghdad on Saturday, killing 19 Iraqi Army soldiers and wounding 4 others in a well-coordinated ambush that started with a roadside bombing, an Iraqi Army officer said.     The attack unfolded around 10 a.m., when a bomb exploded by the convoy near the town of Adhaim, about 60 miles north of Baghdad. After the blast, gunmen opened fire on the Iraqi soldiers.

headline: For Big Three, All the Signs Are Warnings
abstract: Auto industry observers believe that Kirk Kerkorian, one of General Motors' largest shareholders, will want to place Jerome B York on GM's board--a threat to GM chairman Rick Wagoner; Kerkorian and York are in fact reprising their roles of decade ago, when Kerkorian was Chrysler's largest shareholder and turned to York to be his right-hand man in what became unsuccessful and contentious takeover bid; people briefed on situation say several of GM's assets are viewed as expendable, including parts of General Motors Acceptance Corp and Saab and Hummer brands; photos of Kerkorian and York (L)

headline: Unity in cyberspace eludes Europe
The Nation, Now Profitable, Has a New Commander
abstract: The Nation publisher Victor Navasky is officially handing over his job to editor Katrina vanden Heuvel; she will retain role as editor; Navasky will be publisher emeritus, but will devote most of his time to his other job as chairman of The Columbia Journalism Review; photo (M)

headline: Bush and Berlusconi trade compliments
People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Association of Independent Commercial Producers, New York, has held elections for its East and West regional boards. Rich Carter, executive producer at Gartner, Santa Monica, Calif., becomes president of the West board, succeeding Andy Traines, executive producer at Anonymous Content, Culver City, Calif., and New York. Robert Fernandez, executive producer at Moxie Pictures, which has offices in New York, London and Hollywood, Calif., was named the East board president, succeeding Pam Rohs, executive producer at the Joneses, with offices in New York and Santa Monica. Previously, Massimo Martinotti, president of Mia Films, with offices in cities including Miami, was re-elected president of the Florida chapter.

headline: U.S. Envoy to Meet Darfur Rebels in Effort to Stem Violence
abstract: With the Bush administration's Sudan policy in disarray, the deputy secretary of state arrived in Kenya for a series of meetings.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 3 at West Bank Checkpoint
abstract: Two Palestinian civilians and an Israeli Army officer were killed today when a bomber blew himself up near Tulkarm.

headline: Wal-Mart to Start Equity Fund to Help Diversify Its Suppliers
abstract: Wal--Mart Stores, which is fighting nation's largest sex discrimination suit, will set up $25 million private equity fund to support businesses owned by women and members of minority groups over next five years; fund will invest in businesses that offer merchandise and services to retailers with goal of diversifying industry's suppliers; of Wal-Mart's 61,000 US suppliers, 5,200 are owned by women and minority group members; fund will be managed by Aldus Equity Partners (M)

headline: In the Face of Broad Skepticism, Ruling Azeris Proclaim Victory
abstract: Governing party in Azerbaijan rallies to celebrate victory in parliamentary elections, which international observers say were tainted with extensive fraud; opposition calls for all election results to be overturned; its chances of overturning election or staging huge public rallies are unclear (M)

Kazakhstan, with its rough edges, faces election
U.N. Seeks to Question 6 Syrians in Killing of Lebanese Ex-Leader
abstract: United Nations team investigating assassination of former prime minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon formally requests that six Syrian officials travel to Lebanon for questioning; names of six officials have not been released, but list reportedly includes Asef Shawkat, Pres Bashar al-Assad's brother-in-law and chief of military intelligence; Syria makes no immediate comment about whether it would comply (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Death Sentences In Musharraf Plot
abstract: Military court sentences four men to death and two others to life in prison for 2003 assassination attempt on Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf (S)

headline: Mountains of Corn and a Sea of Farm Subsidies
abstract: Huge pile of corn next to full grain elevators at agricultural cooperative in Ralston is result of Iowa's largest corn crop in history and ballooning American farm subsidy program; photo; graph; 60-foot-high pile of 2.7 million bushels reflects explosive growth in US corn production that will reach 10.9 billion bushels this year as effficient American farmers are encouraged to produce far more than country can use, depressing prices and raising subsidy payments; huge volumes weigh heavily on farmers coping with last year's oversupply, soaring energy costs, Gulf Coast hurricanes that disrupted transportation and severe drought; federal spending on farm payments is closing in on 2000 record of $22.9 billion even as Bush administration tells World Trade Organization US is serious about trimming subsidies; US has promised to cut most trade-distorting farm subsidies by 60 percent over five years, to address third-world complaints that US and European Union subsidies lead to gluts that distort crop prices around world (M)

headline: U.S. tries to reassure Europe on CIA flights
Jail, Not Extradition, for Colombian Warlord
abstract: Diego Fernando Murillo, a paramilitary commander being held in comfort on a sprawling ranch, has been transferred to C√≥mbita, one of Colombia's toughest prisons, President √Ålvaro Uribe announced. The abrupt transfer came a day after Mr. Uribe said Mr. Murillo, known as Don Berna, could avoid extradition to New York on drug trafficking charges if he adhered to a pact governing the disarmament of thousands of paramilitary fighters. The Bush administration has strongly backed Mr. Uribe's dealing with the paramilitaries, but federal prosecutors in New York have been pushing for Mr. Murillo to be extradited to face cocaine-trafficking charges.    Juan Forero (NYT)

headline: Terror Suspect's Ordeal in U.S. Custody
abstract: When Muhammad Saad Iqbal finally got a chance to plead his case to a panel of military officers at the American prison at Guant√°namo Bay, Cuba, he insisted that he had nothing to hide.     ''If I have committed any crime, I am ready for the punishment,'' Mr. Iqbal told the officers a year ago, according to a transcript of the hearing. ''But I know that I am innocent. That is why I am here.''

headline: Home Building Loses Its Commanding Lead in Setting Economy's Pace
abstract: THE building of houses, which buoyed the American economy during the 2001 recession and then spurred the recovery, is no longer leading the economy up.     Figures released this week by the Commerce Department showed that private construction spending set a record in September, but the third-quarter average was only 6.5 percent above the figure in the quarter a year ago, before adjusting for inflation. That matched the growth of the overall economy. By contrast, in 2004 residential construction spending was growing twice as fast as the overall economy.

World Briefing: Americas, Europe, Australia, Africa, Asia
abstract: AMERICAS.

headline: Germany releases 1985 hijacker
Times and Reporter Reach Agreement on Her Departure
abstract: The deal ended Judith Miller's 28-year career at The Times and capped more than two weeks of negotiations.

headline: A Cisco System to Make Radios Work Together
abstract: Cisco Systems develops new Internet-based method for marrying frequently incompatible radio gear used by emergency services agencies and businesses; new approach, known as Internet Protocol Interoperability and Collaboration Systems, essentially converts voice traffic on radios and cellphones into data traffic over existing networks (M)

headline: Infinity Outlines Plan to Replace Howard Stern
abstract: Infinity Broadcasting announced plans today to replace Howard Stern with a regional slate of hosts, including the former Van Halen singer David Lee Roth and the comedian Adam Carolla.

headline: TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Recent Sale  $13.75 million  275 and 295 Greenwich Street  Manhattan    This retailing condo features 25,000 square feet on the ground floor and basement, with 600 square feet vacant, in two connected buildings of Greenwich Court, an 11-story luxury condo in TriBeCa.    BUYER: Wiana Realty Corp.
