headline: Ex-spy chiefs arrested in South Korea
Brewer to End Sound-Alike Bar Game
abstract: Anheuser-Busch says it is ending its promotion of Bud Pong, game created by brewery that is similar to popular drinking game called beer pong but supposedly played with water; Anheuser-Busch executives tried to distinguish Bud Pong from beer pong (M)

headline: Letter from America: For Louisiana, lessons in staging a comeback
Corporations Tidy Up as the Year Ticks Away
abstract: STRIKING transit workers may have brought subways and buses to a stop in New York this week, but the news kept flowing. Much of it was driven by the time of year, as corporate chiefs and government officials scrambled to tidy up things before the new year.    A MOGUL IS BORN -- Ending a succession story that was never much of a mystery, Time Warner named Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the head of its movie and television businesses, as its president and chief operating officer. The promotion makes him heir apparent to the chairman and chief executive, Richard D. Parsons.     Mr. Bewkes, 53, was one of two lieutenants to Mr. Parsons, 57. The other, Don Logan, 61, who heads Time Warner's publishing, cable and online properties, will retire at the end of the year and become nonexecutive chairman of the company's cable business.     Mr. Bewkes is perhaps best known for his time at HBO, where he made his mark -- and HBO's reputation -- with hit programs like ''The Sopranos'' and ''Sex and the City.''     In an interview, Mr. Bewkes said he did not anticipate any immediate executive changes. That may be because he will be busy fending off a campaign by the financier Carl C. Icahn to make major changes at the company to raise its stock price.    LUNCH TAB -- A California jury ordered Wal-Mart Stores to pay $172 million in damages for failing to provide meal breaks to nearly 116,000 hourly workers as required under state law. The suit, filed on behalf of employees of Wal-Mart and Sam's Club stores in California, argued that the chain violated state law more than eight million times.     California law requires that employers provide a meal break of 30 minutes for every five hours on the clock. If the break is shorter than that, provided late or not at all, the employer must pay an hour's pay.     Wal-Mart, which faces similar cases in about 40 other states, said it planned to appeal.    LATEST INDICTMENT  -- Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, the dominant local phone company in 14 Western states, was indicted for selling more than $100 million worth of stock in his company in 2001 after learning that it would miss its financial goals but before making that news public.     In a separate action in March, the Securities and Exchange Commission sued Mr. Nacchio and other former executives, accusing them of overstating $3 billion in revenue from 1999 to 2002. It said the inflated figures helped Mr. Nacchio earn $216 million in pay and bonuses. In court, he pleaded not guilty.     Several other former Qwest executives have already pleaded guilty and cooperated with government investigators. Qwest agreed last month to pay $400 million to investors hurt by the false financial statements. It also agreed to pay $250 million in fines to the S.E.C. last year.     Prosecutors and the defense team are scheduled to meet on Jan. 20 in federal court in Denver, where Qwest is based, to set a timetable for the trial.    PULLING THE PLUG -- Burdened with debts used to build power plants and with long-term contracts obligating it to sell electricity below the cost of making it, Calpine, a symbol of market deregulation, filed for bankruptcy protection.     Calpine was hurt by the California energy crisis, which sent prices soaring after the company locked itself into long-term contracts, and by the collapse of Enron, which provided much of the liquidity in electricity-trading markets.      Calpine, which employs 3,300 people, has $2 billion of debtor-in-possession financing, which is enough to keep its plants operating for now. But creditors are maneuvering to seize its assets, which include one of the world's largest geothermal plants, in Northern California.    POWER GRAB -- In one of the largest takeovers in the electricity industry, the FPL Group agreed to buy Constellation Energy for $11 billion, creating a company that will own the nation's largest portfolio of electricity generation assets, with more than 45,000 megawatts of capacity.     The combined company will have revenue of about $27 billion and will be the third-largest provider of nuclear-fueled electricity and one of the largest operators of coal-fired power plants.     More mergers are likely after February, when the federal government repeals legislation that prevents conglomerates from using power monopolies to overcharge customers and subsidize other businesses.    A DEAL, SORT OF -- Trade ministers from around the world agreed to stop subsidizing agricultural exports by 2013 and took steps to make it easier for the poorest nations to sell goods to industrialized nations. But the talks, held in Hong Kong under the guidance of the World Trade Organization, did little to persuade rich countries to lower import tariffs or limit subsidies to their own farmers and ranchers.     The agreement helps negotiators as they try to finish a comprehensive set of trade rules by the end of 2007, in time for President Bush to submit it to Congress before a Congressional deadline expires.    GAME OVER? -- Electronic Arts, the largest independent game publisher, and Activision, a big competitor, said holiday sales of their computer and video games were unexpectedly weak. NPD, a market research company, said domestic game sales fell 18 percent last month, to $700 million, from November a year ago.     Paradoxically, a big reason for the slowdown may be the success of the Microsoft Xbox 360 console. Because Microsoft did not make enough to satisfy demand, consumers waiting to buy an Xbox 360 may have stopped buying games for other consoles, like the original Xbox and the Sony PlayStation 2.     The slump may be reversed next year, when more Xbox 360's are in the hands of consumers and after Sony, the leading console maker, and Nintendo release new versions of their hardware.    MOST VIEWED -- Following are the most-viewed articles from Dec. 17 to Dec. 23:     1. Governments Tremble at Google's Bird's-Eye View     2. Notebooks Come In at Under a Thousand With Speed and Style     3. Health Care for All, Just a (Big) Step Away     4. Transition to Digital Gets Closer     5. That Blur? It's China, Moving Up in the Pack          Links are at nytimes.com/business.

headline: Trade Talks Are Hung Up on Subsidies to Farmers
abstract: Trade ministers end three days of talks aimed at overhauling farm subsidies and import tariffs without reaching deal, but agree to meet again next week, Geneva; US blames European Union for failure because it did not accept concessions that US is demanding in return; European Union agrees to lower its subsidies by 70 percent, up from previous offer of 65 percent, but has not signaled that it is willing to meet demands on tariff reductions; photo (M)

headline: Uninvited Guest Turns Up at Catholic Synod: Issue of Married Priests
abstract: Under Pope John Paul II, the question was barely up for debate. But over the last week, the deep shortage of Roman Catholic priests has dominated the first gathering of bishops under the new pope, Benedict XVI, with an openness and urgency that the Vatican has not been used to in recent years.      ''Celibacy has no theological foundation,'' Gregorios III Laham, who attended the synod as the patriarch of the Melkite Catholics, an Eastern Rite church, said at an early session, official briefers reported. ''Married priests are admitted,'' he said.

headline: Unseen Enemy Is at Its Fiercest in a Sunni City
abstract: The Bradley fighting vehicles moved slowly down this city's main boulevard. Suddenly, a homemade bomb exploded, punching into one vehicle. Then another explosion hit, briefly lifting a second vehicle up onto its side before it dropped back down again.      Two American soldiers climbed out of a hatch, the first with his pant leg on fire, and the other completely in flames. The first rolled over to help the other man, but when they touched, the first man also burst into flames. Insurgent gunfire began to pop.

headline: Viacom Explains Split Into Units
abstract: Viacom, which is planning to split into two companies next year, named Shari Redstone as nonexecutive vice chairwoman of both units and said investors would receive half a share in each new business for every Viacom share.      The boards of the new Viacom and the CBS Corporation will share three other common directors, including Ms. Redstone's father, Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman, Viacom said in a regulatory filing.

headline: Gas Bombs Hit Russian Stores; Gangsters Blamed
abstract: At peak of holiday shopping, two stores in retail chain in St Petersburg, Russia, are struck by bombs that release foul-smelling gas; at least 77 people are made ill by odor, none seriously; police say gas in bombs, while producing almost unbearable odor, is largely harmless; authorities rule out terrorism, blaming gangsterism instead (M)

headline: Blogs and text messages spread call to violence
Construction Manager Wanted, Badly
abstract: Over the last six months, Larry Fishman, the chief operating officer at Asbury Partners, has interviewed dozens of candidates for a retail development job that his company is trying to fill in Asbury Park, N.J.      As career opportunities go, the job -- senior construction manager -- has plenty to offer. It provides a chance to shape the future of a 56-acre waterfront project that Asbury Partners, the primary developer, envisions will have more than 3,000 condominiums and town houses, entertainment spots and 450,000 square feet of stores along an already renovated mile-long boardwalk.

headline: Novartis to buy rest of Chiron
Michelin scatters stars on New York
Mixed Grade for Wal-Mart on Report Card
abstract: With critics hammering Wal-Mart day after day, the company sponsored an unusual conference on Friday about its impact on America's economy, and it got some good -- and a few not so good -- grades.     The best news for Wal-Mart was that a respected economic forecasting firm, Global Insight, found that by keeping its prices low and pressuring rival retailers over the last 19 years, Wal-Mart has kept the Consumer Price Index 3.1 percent below what it would have otherwise been.

headline: Briefs: EU to encourage bank mergers
On Advertising: Advocates run afoul of ad rules
Wall Street places its bet on Internet casinos
Atlanta Looks to Sum Itself Up in Just Six Words
abstract: WHEN slogans for cities work, they really work. There's the world-famous ''I Love New York,'' which dates back to 1977, and Las Vegas's more recent: ''What Happens Here, Stays Here.''     Then there is Atlanta's new slogan, unveiled by the city's marketing arm last week: ''Every Day Is an Opening Day.''     Huh?

headline: Germany Passes Torch to New Generation
abstract: German parliament will elect Angela Merkel as first woman chancellor after two months of post-election negotiating to create 'grand coalition' between her conservative Christian Democrats and Social Democrats of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder; her ascent marks shift to new political generation, also seen in election of Matthias Platzeck, also from east, to lead Social Democratic party (M)

headline: Bare-Knuckle Democracy in Iraq Rebel Territory
abstract: Izzadin al-Muhammadi, member of Iraqi electoral commission, visits Baqubq, provincial capital in insurgent territory, and is peppered with complaints from politicians demanding more polling centers for Dec 15 election, more safeguards against casting of multiple ballots and fairer system for selecting election observers; continuing guerrilla war and leftover tensions from Saddam Hussein era have starkly polarized country's ethnic and religious factions and their political leaders; photos (M)

headline: Nearly a Year After the Tsunami, Sri Lanka Strife Flares
abstract: Nearly a year since the tsunami devastated the nation, a fresh wave of political violence is sweeping across eastern Sri Lanka. Armed factions vie for supremacy, assassinations and abductions go on in broad daylight and parents squirrel away their children for fear they will be conscripted into battle.     Loss piles upon unbearable loss. There is no sanctuary even at a relief camp here for families displaced by the tsunami. Since February three women at the camp have been widowed.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA.

headline: The Workplace: Drawing a (bottom) line on domestic violence
Insurance Concern in China to Sell 25% Stake to Carlyle
abstract: In one of the largest private equity deals ever done in China, the Carlyle Group, the global private equity firm, has agreed to invest $410 million for a minority stake in the China Pacific Life Insurance Company.     The Carlyle Group said Monday it would buy a 25 percent stake in China Pacific Life, the country's third-largest life insurance company after the China Life Insurance Company and Ping An Insurance, both of which are publicly listed in Hong Kong and the United States. The deal gives Carlyle a foothold in the world's fastest-growing life insurance market, where income from life insurance premiums has already reached $40 billion a year.

headline: China to redeem Hu Yaobang
Pakistan quake toll at 18,000
Prison over patents? Proposed EU law unites foes
Seagate Seen Buying Maxtor, a Rival Storage Maker, for $1.9 Billion
abstract: Seagate Technology, the giant digital storage company, reached a deal yesterday to acquire a rival, the Maxtor Corporation, for $1.9 billion in stock, according to executives involved in the transaction.     The deal, which was approved by the boards of both companies, is expected to be announced as early as today, the executives said.

headline: Obituary: Rodney Whitaker, 74, wrote under pen name ofTrevanian
One Director, Two Boards and a Fight at Time Warner
abstract: Robert C Clark, former dean of Harvard Law School who is board member of Time Warner and Lazard LLC, is in particularly tough spot since Carl C Icahn teamed up with Bruce Wasserstein's firm Lazard to wage shareholder war against Time Warner; Clark could become target to be replaced by Icahn-led group; Clark is paid about $175,000 annually in cash and stock by Time Warner and about $100,000 by Lazard; Clark declines comment; Icahn says he is not concerned about Clark's positions; adds Clark came after AOL-Time Warner deal and that whole mess-up; photo (M)

headline: Marketers find niche with 'functional foods'
Colombian President Scrambling in Fight to Run Again
abstract: Swept into power in a broken country, √Ålvaro Uribe promised at his inauguration three years ago that he would break with the cronyism and patronage that long marked Colombia's bare-knuckle politics.      ''We cannot fight against patronage if we practice patronage,'' President Uribe told the nation that gave him a landslide victory.

headline: Device beats the odds to provide musical harmony at home
Miscellany
abstract: Online advertising revenue reaches $3.1 billion in third quarter, up 33.9 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: A Bitterly Divided Haiti Is Lurching Toward an Election
abstract: Twenty months after a violent uprising forced President Jean-Bertrand Aristide into exile, the road to new elections here in the hemisphere's poorest nation remains planted with land mines.     A presidential hopeful, Dumarsais Sim√©us, ran over one last week. With great fanfare, he began a campaign rally in Solino, a crumbling and crime-plagued neighborhood of the Haitian capital. Throngs of people turned the dirty, foul-smelling streets into a party, singing to Mr. Sim√©us and waving his campaign T-shirts in the air like banners.

headline: Palestinian Police Stage Rowdy Protest for Better Equipment
abstract: More than 30 Palestinian policemen charged onto the grounds of the Palestinian parliament in Gaza City on Monday and fired weapons into the air, demanding more government support in a growing confrontation with the Islamic faction Hamas.      Less than an hour later, the lawmakers endorsed a plan calling on President Mahmoud Abbas to form a new cabinet within two weeks. If he fails to do so, the government of Prime Minister Ahmed Qurei could face a no-confidence vote.

headline: Temptation to Gamble IsNear for Troops Overseas
abstract: Military gambling has become big business, with about $2 billion flowing through military-owned slot machines at officers' clubs, activities centers and bowling alleys on US overseas bases each year; most of money flows back out as jackpots but six percent remains with house, as in Las Vegas; military takes in more than $120 million a year from on-base slot machines and $7 million from Army bingo games at home; money is used to fund recreational programs but easy access tempts vulnerable gamblers like Army pilot Aaron W Walsh, who lost his money, marriage and military career to habit fed by Army's own slot machines in South Korea; photos; experts warn that military is filled with risk-taking young people who are experiencing severe stress and anxiety that makes them especially vulnerable to gambling addiction; those who worked on PricewaterhouseCoopers study report that Pentagon is defensive about subject, fearing loss of revenues, and that only chaplains take problem seriously; military also spends none of profits on treatment of problem gamblers; Peter Isaacs, who runs slot machine program, says vast majority use machines responsibly; slot machines were banned from domestic bases in 1951 after scandals; there are now some 4,150 modern video slot machines on bases in nine countries (M)

headline: Gone Spear-Phishin'
abstract: ABOUT a year and a half ago, Amnon Jackont, an Israeli mystery novelist and Tel Aviv University history professor, became ensnared in a mystery of his very own: friends and students were receiving e-mail messages from him that he had never written. A few months later, unpublished paragraphs and chapters from a book he was writing were plucked from his computer and began appearing on Israeli Web sites.     Mr. Jackont took his computer to the Israeli police last fall and was told to reformat it. But his problems persisted. So the police examined his computer more closely and discovered that a malicious program known as a Trojan horse lay hidden deep inside and had hijacked the machine from a remote location.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Major Suspect In Bombings Caught
abstract: Security forces in Dhaka captured Ataur Rahman, the suspected military commander of Jamaat-ul-Mujahedeen, the banned Islamist militant group blamed for a series of recent bombings and suicide attacks. He is a brother of the group's fugitive supreme leader, Sheik Abdur Rahman, and the authorities hailed the arrest as a breakthrough. The police said they also seized a large cache of weapons and explosives for about 300 bombs.   DAVID MONTERO (NYT)

headline: And the Retail Gods Said, 'Time to Shop,' and They Shopped
abstract: Congratulations. If you are reading this, it means that you managed not to be trampled at the mall on Friday. Or, perhaps, it means that you had the good sense not to go to the mall -- that you decided to do your holiday shopping some other time or (dare one say it?) not at all.      It should be explained, for those just off an interplanetary shuttle, that the nation observes an odd ritual: First, someone in the heights of some marketing office tower decrees that everyone should flock to stores on the day after the national feast celebrating football, overindulgence and, if time permits, giving thanks. And here's the amazing thing: every year, Americans obey and head to stores, shopping mainly for that December holiday.

headline: New bids offered in Refco bankruptcy action
World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Growth Forecast Cut to 3% for This Year
abstract: Finance Minister Francisco Gil D√≠az lowered his forecast for economic growth in Mexico this year to about 3 percent, citing Congress's failure to pass economic legislation sought by President Vicente Fox. The Finance Ministry had previously maintained a growth forecast of 3.5 percent, even as the central bank cut its 2005 estimate in July and again in October to a range of 2.75 percent to 3.25 percent. The economy will expand about 3.5 percent next year, Mr. Gil D√≠az, left, said. ''Growth has not been at the level we would have liked and has proved unsatisfactory and insufficient in meeting the requirements of job and salary growth,'' Mr. Gil D√≠az said. ''Things would have been better if we had been able to achieve some of the profound reforms that are so necessary and important for our country.'' Mr. Fox has drawn criticism from all three major presidential candidates for his inability to spur faster growth. The nominee of the president's National Action Party, Felipe Calder√≥n, has pledged to avoid what he calls mistakes in dealing with Congress if he is elected in July, promising action on Mr. Fox's stalled plans to rework the tax system and allow private investment in the oil and gas industry. Mexico's economy grew 4.4 percent in 2004.

headline: UN scandal claims Indian diplomat
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Plans Plant Closings in Restructuring After Reporting a Quarterly Loss of $284 Million  The Ford Motor Company will announce a restructuring of its American operations in January that will include plant closings and job cuts, the company's chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., said. His statement came as his company reported a $284 million loss in the third quarter, its first quarterly loss since the final three months of 2003. The company said it lost $1.49 billion, before taxes, in its North American automotive operations. [Page C1.]    The United Auto Workers announced the details of its tentative agreement with General Motors and said that for the first time, G.M.'s union retirees will have to pay deductibles, monthly premiums and co-payments. [C3.]    Google Tops Expectations with Third-Quarter Profit  Finding more ways to make money from its spot as the world's most popular Internet search engine, Google topped Wall Street expectations and its own forecast and posted sharply higher profit in the third quarter. [C1.]    Congress Passes Lawsuit Shield Law for Gun Industry  Congress delivered a long-sought victory to the gun industry when the House voted to shield firearms manufacturers and dealers from liability lawsuits. The bill now goes to President Bush, who has promised to sign it. [A1.]    Medical Publication Questions a Diabetes Drug  An article in the Journal of the American Medical Association said the proposed diabetes pill Pargluva seems to significantly increase risks of heart attacks and strokes, and an accompanying editorial said the drug's sponsors, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merck, had submitted misleading data to the Food and Drug Administration that ''may have fostered an illusion of safety.'' [C7.]    Roche has agreed to meet with four generic drug companies to discuss allowing them to manufacture the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu, which is in short supply as countries stockpile it to prepare for a possible flu pandemic. [C7.]    Facing increasing generic competition and concerns about the heart risks of Celebrex, its once-popular painkiller, Pfizer said its third-quarter profit fell 50 percent, to $1.6 billion, and its sales fell 5 percent from the year earlier period. Profit for the current quarter will fall far short of analysts' forecasts, the company said and its shares fell 8 percent. [C7.]    Advertising Executive Resigns Over Remarks  Neil French, a well-known advertising executive and worldwide creative consultant at WPP Group, the world's second-largest agency holding company, resigned his position amid an uproar over remarks he made at an industry event about female creative executives. [C1.]    SBC's Profit Falls on Costs of Hurricane and a Merger  SBC Communications said its profit slipped 41 percent in the third quarter partly because its wireless unit, Cingular, had higher costs related to hurricanes and its merger with AT&T Wireless. [C3.]    Senate Panel Approves Digital Television Measure  A Senate panel approved legislation to complete the slow migration from analog to digital television by 2009, a transition of enormous importance to the television, cable and wireless telephone industries. [C3.]    Nigeria Reaches Deal to Pay Debts at a Discount  Nigeria reached an agreement with the Paris Club of creditors to pay off $30 billion of debt for $12 billion, a significant breakthrough for a nation long deemed too wealthy with oil money and too corrupt to be granted relief from debt accumulated over years of misrule. [A14.]    Chinese Economy Grew 9.4 Percent in Third Quarter  China's roaring economy grew 9.4 percent in the third quarter of this year, fueled by surging exports, strong investments in infrastructure and solid retail sales, according to a government report. [C4.]    China's rapid economic growth has fostered a tourist boom among the mainland Chinese, with Southeast Asia the favorite destination, at least for now. And, like travelers for centuries before them, they are developing a reputation, which some say is loud and obnoxious. [C1.]    After a quarter-century of growth powered largely by exports, China is showing signs of opening a new chapter of strong growth, this time propelled by domestic spending. [C4.]    Europe Fails Again to Reach Deal for Lower Farm Tariffs  The European Union failed again to deliver new cuts in its farm tariffs and subsidies, held back by France's refusal to allow deeper reductions, while other trading nations laid pressure on Europe to act. Brazil's foreign minister, Celso Amorim, left, who has become a spokesman for developing nations in these talks, urged Europe to break the logjam. [C13.]    Stocks Fall Sharply on Report of High Inflation  Stocks sold off sharply, pushing the three major gauges down more than 1 percent, after a major inflation gauge hit a 25-year high and stirred fears of higher interest rates, while Pfizer posted disappointing quarterly results. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 133.03 points, to 10,281.10. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index sank 17.96 points, to 1,177.80. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 23.13 points, to 2,068.11. [C7.]

headline: Text of Fed Statement on Rates
abstract: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to raise its benchmark interest rates a quarter-point:         The Federal Open Market Committee decided today to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 41/4 percent. Despite elevated energy prices and hurricane-related disruptions, the expansion in economic activity appears solid. Core inflation has stayed relatively low in recent months and longer-term inflation expectations remain contained. Nevertheless, possible increases in resource utilization as well as elevated energy prices have the potential to add to inflation pressures.

headline: As NATO Forces Ease Role of G.I.'s in Afghanistan, the Taliban Steps Up Attacks
abstract: Foreign soldiers in desert fatigues and helmets sealed off the main road of this southern city last Sunday to inspect the site where a suicide bomber, wrapped in a blanket, had thrown himself at a convoy of military jeeps, killing himself and an Afghan civilian.     To the Afghans watching, the soldiers looked the same as the United States troops that have been a constant presence in Kandahar since the departure of the Taliban four years ago. But these were from Canada, whose forces have quietly begun an important shift in the international military presence in Afghanistan.

headline: Gap between allies widens over N. Korea
China to pay E7.7 billion for 150 Airbus planes
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: In Microsoft's Battle With Hackers, Company Makes Some Progress  Locked in a struggle with a shadowy ''black hat'' computer underground that exploits any flaw in its software, Microsoft has spent more than three years trying to transform its engineering culture to make security the company's priority. Recently, there have indeed been some arrests for computer attacks that capitalized on Microsoft software flaws. But more important, during the last year the company has made measurable progress in improving the quality of its software code, according to a wide range of computer security specialists and customers. [Page C1.]    A Change at the Top at Time Inc.  Time Inc., a division of Time Warner, the world's largest media company, is expected to announce today that John Huey, 57, will succeed Norman Pearlstine, 63, on Jan. 1 to oversee the company's 155 magazines. This makes Mr. Huey the sixth editor in chief of the media empire since Henry R. Luce published the first issue of Time in 1923 . [C1]    A Madison Avenue Pitch to Video Game Enthusiasts  A big campaign for a new venture from Time Warner demonstrates again the growing importance of computer gaming for Madison Avenue. The campaign, which formally begins today after some ''teaser'' elements ran this past summer, introduces the venture, called GameTap, which offers computer users with broadband connections an opportunity to play hundreds of games on demand. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C7.]    NBC Universal Makes Another Offer for DreamWorks  NBC Universal has revised its offer for live-action business of DreamWorks SKG, a month after the two ended their talks, according to two people with knowledge of the bid. [C8.]    A Tiny Market, but Growing  In the past year, media companies have begun experimenting with broadcasting original programming made specifically for cellphones to increase awareness of their television shows and movies. And interest in such programming may grow further: last week, Apple introduced a video iPod, which, while not a cellphone, is another test of consumers' interest in portable entertainment. So far, efforts by media companies are modest, limited largely to games, ring tones and wallpaper. [C1.]    Smartphone and BlackBerry Makers in Licensing Deal  Palm Inc., maker of the Treo smartphone, and its rival Research in Motion Ltd., the maker of the wireless BlackBerry device, are expected to announce a licensing agreement that could alter competition in the market for phones that offer e-mail and other functions. [C6.]    Americans Play Catch-Up With Broadband  The idea has been around for years. In Spain and elsewhere in Europe, utility companies have long offered high-speed Internet service to consumers over their power lines. But American utilities are only now beginning to roll out broadband connections on their grid. [C1.]    For DirecTV Investors, a Difficult Year  It has been a tough year for shareholders of the DirecTV Group, the satellite television company. Fears about competition from telephone and cable companies have buffeted its stock price, and anxious analysts who have endorsed the stock are hoping shareholders will get a Christmas present as a reward for their loyalty. [C8.]    A Web Site Offers a Wrap-Up of the News  A Web site is being introduced today that will not only let you find articles on the topic of your choice from hundreds of newspapers and magazines, it will also alert you to all the other news accounts floating around cyberspace that have any connection whatsoever to anything you read. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. [C6.]

headline: Ford Reports a Loss and Expects 'Significant Plant Closings'
abstract: The Ford Motor Company is the latest Detroit auto giant to stall.     Ford's chairman and chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., said Thursday that his company would announce a plan for its American operations in January that includes ''significant plant closings'' and job cuts.

headline: Candidates vow to fight corruption
Iraq Dogs President as HeCrosses Asia to Promote Trade
abstract: President Bush may have come to Asia determined to show leaders here that his agenda is far broader than Iraq and terrorism, but at every stop, and every day, Mr. Bush and his aides have been fighting a rearguard action to justify how the United States got into Iraq and how to get out.     On Friday morning, as Mr. Bush was meeting the leaders of Southeast Asia, his press secretary issued an unusually blistering statement responding to Representative John P. Murtha's call for a pullout from Iraq, declaring that Mr. Murtha, a Pennsylvania Democrat who had often backed Mr. Bush's military initiatives, was ''endorsing the policy positions of Michael Moore and the extreme liberal wing of the Democratic Party.''

headline: Google Bids to Help San Francisco Go Wireless
abstract: Google ended months of speculation late Friday afternoon by submitting a proposal to offer a free wireless Internet service to the city of San Francisco.     The proposal, which is one of a range of proposals being submitted both by large communications firms and small start-ups, is in response to a TechConnect program proposed by the city's mayor, Gavin Newsom, this year. Mr. Newsom has positioned the program as a way to offer universal and affordable broadband Internet access to the city's residents and businesses.

headline: Disapproval grows over ECB's plans
G.M. to Cut $1 Billion in Costs by Revamping Some Operations
abstract: General Motors plans to cut costs by $1 billion on revamped midsize cars by streamlining engineering and production, and it may build more vehicles outside the United States, Robert A. Lutz, the company's vice chairman, said yesterday.     The cost savings that Mr. Lutz discussed would be from a group of nine midsize vehicles, including the Chevrolet Malibu, that G.M. plans to introduce starting in 2007.

headline: Russia to Sell Antiaircraft Missiles to Iran in Billion-Dollar Deal
abstract: Russia has agreed to sell antiaircraft missiles to Iran as part of a $1 billion arms deal that would significantly increase Moscow's military cooperation with Tehran, Russian news media reported Friday.     The announcement of the sale coincided with a visit to Moscow by R. Nicholas Burns, the American under secretary of state for political affairs, who said in a radio interview that the United States had asked the Russian Foreign Ministry to explain the deal, reported by the newspaper Vedomosti and the Interfax news agency.

headline: Dutch activist fatally shot
Real Energy Savers Don't Wear Cardigans. Or Do They?
abstract: WHEN oil and gas prices surged after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, President Bush appealed to Americans to conserve energy. He asked people to cut back on nonessential travel, for example, and to carpool to work. Then, in October, the White House started a campaign for energy conservation in American homes, dusting off some old ideas like switching to fluorescent light bulbs and installing better insulation in attics.      Some critics derided the program as a bizarre flashback from the 1970's -- a collection of worn-out ideas that evoked feelings of deprivation and gloom. It will be a pity, though, if an effective energy policy never gets off the ground. Much has been learned since the 70's about what works and what doesn't. Clearly, energy conservation isn't what it used to be.

headline: Rebels Dressed as Women Attack Iraqi Police Station
abstract: Insurgent attacks across central Iraq, including one in which the guerrillas disguised themselves as women, left at least 16 dead on Friday as Shiite Arabs across the country began celebrating the end of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.     In the deadliest assault, insurgents dressed in women's clothing attacked a police checkpoint in the town of Buhriz, 35 miles north of Baghdad, killing at least 6 police officers and wounding at least 10 others, American and Iraqi officials said. The guerrillas were armed with Kalashnikov rifles, rocket-propelled grenades and mortars, and pulled up in five cars, an Interior Ministry official said. The police officers killed at least two of the gunmen, he added.

headline: Sales for Web Help Nortel Reduce Loss
abstract: Nortel Networks says it narrowed its third-quarter loss to $105 million from $259 million year earlier; revenue rose to $2.66 billion from $2.18 billion (S)

headline: The Workplace:In the EU, stark wage disparity
General Dynamics to Acquire Information Systems Concern
abstract: The General Dynamics Corporation, the military contractor, announced yesterday that it would acquire the Anteon International Corporation for $2.1 billion in a move by a company known for its warships and tanks to expand its technology services business.      The deal reflects a shift in Pentagon spending and strategy away from heavy military equipment and toward more high-technology weapons and sophisticated electronic systems. The Pentagon recently announced that it wanted to cut $32 billion from coming budgets, and military contractors have responded by investing in the one growth area of the Pentagon budget, intelligence and technology.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: One Killed In Blast Near Istanbul
abstract: A bomb hidden in a garbage container on the outskirts of Istanbul killed one person and wounded 10 others, the Anatolian News Agency reported. No one claimed responsibility for the blast, near a popular amusement park in the Beylikduzu district. The Istanbul governor, Muammer Guler, said security forces suspected a remote-control device caused the blast.   Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

headline: Turnout Is Mixed as Iraqis CastVotes on Constitution
abstract: Millions of Iraqis streamed to the polls Saturday to vote on a new constitution, joined by what appeared to be strong turnouts of Sunni voters in some parts of the country.      But the Sunni turnout -- high in some cities like Mosul, low in others like Ramadi -- appeared to be insufficient to defeat the new charter, and Iraqi officials predicted that it would pass.

headline: In Poland, changing alliances
Acting Head Named for Auditing Board
abstract: Willis D. Gradison Jr. was named acting chairman of the auditing oversight board yesterday as the Securities and Exchange Commission outlined how it planned to select a permanent chairman and fill future openings on the panel.     Mr. Gradison, 76, a former Republican representative from Ohio, is one of four original members of the five-member Public Company Accounting Oversight Board. He will temporarily succeed William J. McDonough, who stepped down on Wednesday.

headline: Guatemalan Village Overwhelmed by Task of Digging Out Hundreds of Dead From Mud
abstract: Hundreds of men in the Guatemalan Indian village of Panab√°j hacked with hoes and shovels on Saturday at the river of mud about a half mile wide and as deep as 20 feet that hit their town last week.      As rescue workers and relatives of the dead arrived Saturday, villagers handed out native herbs and told the visitors to press the leaves into their noses to fend off the smell of decomposing bodies.

headline: Briefs: Government proposes broader antiterror law
Foreign Investors Pour Money Into Bonds Every Minute, Every Day
abstract: CALL it the trillion-dollar investment.     The Treasury Department reported this week that foreigners had put a net $1.01 trillion dollars into long-term American securities in the 12 months through September. It was the first time the 12-month total topped that threshold. It is a figure that works out to almost $2 million of investments a minute.

headline: In cancer battle, U.S. to crack genome codes
The Fed Wears Its Feelings on Its Sleeve
abstract: THE Federal Reserve is a modern, sensitive central bank that likes to communicate how it feels. Its well-telegraphed signals to the market leave virtually no doubt that it will execute a 13th consecutive quarter-point increase in its benchmark interest rate this week; the debate among investors is whether the accompanying statement will reveal a change in mood about further increases.     Recent statements by the Fed have repeated that it will tighten credit ''at a pace that is likely to be measured.'' If that phrase is omitted, it will indicate that the end of the tightening cycle is near, said John K. Lynch, chief market analyst at Evergreen Investments.

headline: Pricing Drugs as if They Were Cars
abstract: SOME countries set health care spending policies through national legislation. In California, they do it through television advertising.     It is almost impossible this week to turn on a television set without seeing an advertisement paid for by the major drug companies that is pushing one plan to let uninsured people qualify for prescription drug discounts, while vigorously opposing a competing proposal backed by unions and consumer groups.

headline: Republican Strategist Is Taking Heat for Taking Mexico as Client
abstract: Rob Allyn, the political consultant, meet Rob Allyn, the punching bag.      A longtime Republican strategist, Mr. Allyn has found himself in the cross hairs of conservative critics in the last week after signing a contract with Mexico's foreign ministry to lead a campaign to strengthen the country's image in the United States.

headline: Profit Soars at Rosneft
abstract: The Russian state-owned oil company Rosneft yesterday reported a jump in profit of about 600 percent for the first half of 2005, reflecting its takeover last year of the largest production unit of the privately held Yukos.

headline: Stocks: Productivity gains fuel optimism on earnings
Report Says Ex-A.I.G. Chief Defrauded Foundation 35 Years Ago
abstract: New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer submits report as part of his lawsuit against American International Group's former chief executive, Maurice R Greenberg, contending that Greenberg unfairly enriched himself and other AIG executives in series of transactions that violated will of company's founder, Cornelius Vander Starr, and defrauded foundation he created; says questionable transactions took place more than 35 years ago as far-flung insurance operations built by Starr were melded into AIG; says that after Starr died in 1968, Greenberg and his colleagues, as executors of his estate, benefited by selling assets at fire-sale prices to companies they controlled; says these executives almost immediately turned around and sold assets at far higher prices to AIG, which then set some of them aside for use as compensation pool for company's executives; says Greenberg was able to cement his control of company because those shares amounted to 12 percent of AIG's outstanding stock; says Greenberg and his associates cheated Starr Foundation by selling assets that were worth more than $30 million for just $2 million (M)

headline: Rate Rise Is Opposed in Europe
abstract: European Central Bank is being urged to reconsider plan to lift interests rates for first time in five years; bank's assertion that Europe is finally on sustainable growth plan is undercut by survey of German business showing larger-than-expected decline in confidence in November; survey follows reports on decline in consumer spending in France and drop in business confidence in Belgium; complicating matters further is report about decline in consumer prices in five German states in October, since bank's president, Jean-Claude Trichet, cited threat of rising inflation as main reason to lift rates (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Tribunal Jails One, Frees 2 In Trial Of Kosovo Albanians
abstract: United Nations war crimes tribunal, in its first trial of Kosovo Albanians, acquits Kosovo Liberation Army commander Fatmir Limaj and co-defendant Isak Musliu; third defendant, Haradin Bala, is convicted and sentenced to 13 years in prison (S)

headline: OPEC Leaves Output Unchanged, and Prices Climb
abstract: OPEC decided on Monday to keep its current production levels unchanged for now but hinted that it would consider paring its output early next year if it expected a drop in demand next spring.     OPEC's signal was the strongest in recent months that it did not intend to let oil prices fall, and that was all the encouragement oil markets needed to push up oil prices again on Monday.

headline: Techbrief: ITV plans to close ITN, a British news channel
Putin's Party Leads in Moscow Council Vote
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin's party takes strong lead in city council elections in Moscow in what is widely seen as dress rehearsal for federal elections in 2007 and election for his successor in 2008 (S)

headline: An Identity Crisis for Supermarkets
abstract: Consumers are increasingly shunning neighborhood supermarket and going to Wal-Mart, Costco or other discounters for rock-bottom prices or to places like Whole Foods Market and Wild Oats for specialized quality and service; traditional supermarkets, caught in middle, are struggling to survive; pressures on them may intensify: Wal-Mart and Whole Foods have ambitious expansion plans, and Target says it wants to become big player; traditional supermarkets are trying everything they can think of to turn things around and win back customers; graph; photos (M)

headline: Retire Early, or Not at All
abstract: IT is enough to ruin the rest of your weekend.     At a time when ''only 25 percent of workers are very confident that they'll have enough money to live comfortably in retirement, according to the Employee Benefit Research Institute,'' Essence magazine runs a feature on women in their 40's -- and younger -- who have retired.

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: U.N. Inquiry To Continue After Investigator's Report
abstract: *Detlev Mehlis, prosecutor leading United Nations investigation into assassination of former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri, is scheduled to leave post in December but is asked to maintain association with inquiry, which is expected to continue into 2006; will report status of inquiry to UN Security Council Dec 15 (S)

headline: McDonald's and Nintendo in Wi-Fi Deal
abstract: Nintendo of America is expected to offer free wireless Internet access for its Nintendo DS portable game system at McDonald's restaurants; customers will be able to play select DS games with other players around world (S)

headline: Briefs: Laser pen defendant strikes plea agreement
World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: First Talks With A Rebel Group
abstract: Colombian government will meet for first time with National Liberation Army in hopes of negotiating agreement from 5,000-fighter organization to disarm (S)

headline: Flooding causes chaos in Central America
Peace Prize honors UN agency on atom arms
Indian relief plane turned around mid-air
Fashion Magazines Rush to Mold China's Sense of Style
abstract: From behind her big desk on the top floor of a sleek new office tower in the Xintiandi district, Angelica Cheung, the guiding hand behind this country's new edition of Vogue magazine, contemplated a very Chinese dilemma.     ''Just a few years ago, China definitely wasn't ready and didn't have consumers at the level of Vogue,'' said Ms. Cheung, the magazine's editorial director, as smoothly spoken as she was elegant in a black-and-white pattern Max Mara blouse and skirt. ''Two years from now, though, would have definitely been too late. That's the way China is, moving incredibly fast.''

headline: Enron's Top Accountant Will Help Prosecutors
abstract: The former chief accounting officer of Enron agreed on Wednesday to cooperate with the government in its case against the two leading executives in the scandal over the company's collapse, significantly shifting the dynamics of a trial that is scheduled to start late next month.      In exchange for a guilty plea to a single felony charge of securities fraud and for help in prosecuting Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling, both former chief executives at Enron, the accounting officer, Richard A. Causey, will face a sentence of seven years. That sentence could be reduced by as much as two years, depending on his cooperation at the trial. Mr. Causey did not specifically agree to testify, leaving open that possibility as the trial gets under way.

headline: Bribe Inquiry Looks at Sale of Field Gear to Military
abstract: Federal investigators are looking into possible bribery scheme at US Special Operations Command as well as accusations of improper influence involving millions of dollars in battlefield equipment used by Navy Seals and Army Green Berets and Rangers; investigations are examining hiring of former Special Operations Command official William E Burke by military contractor as well as financial contributions by military contractors to Night Stalkers, nonprofit organization that ran social events for special forces; among those under investigation is Gen Bryan D Brown, who heads command; Pentagon is specifically looking into accusations that one former military procurement official who oversaw millions of dollars in Boeing Co contracts went to work for Boeing after leaving command (M)

headline: Superreviewers: People Who Spend Lots of Time Playing With Products
abstract: BRETT JIU, a financial analyst in New York, is the gadget guy his family and friends consult when buying electronics. And a few other people hang on his words too -- 13,000 Amazon.com customers, for instance, have said that the 887 reviews he has posted on that site have been helpful, a figure that makes him the 38th-ranked critic there.      So in May, when he found out that a co-worker bought a television without consulting him and wasn't happy with the purchase, Mr. Jiu was understandably upset.

headline: Hey, It's Good to Be Back Home in India
abstract: With globalization, many Americans of Indian origin in the high-technology industry are looking at India as a way to enhance their careers.

headline: J&J threatens to drop its deal for Guidant
ViewPoints: Is WTO conference a spectator sport?
Saddam claims he's been beaten in detention
U.N. Sets Day To Remember The Holocaust
abstract: The General Assembly adopted a resolution on Tuesday to establish an annual day to commemorate victims of the Holocaust, reject denials that the genocide occurred and urge countries to educate their citizens about the World War II killings.     The date chosen was Jan. 27, the anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz death camp.

headline: As Background Checks Get Big, the Little Guys Get Bigger
abstract: AS long as employers have wanted to check up on job applicants, an industry of tiny background-checking companies has existed, prowling courthouses to check criminal records and working the phones to verify employment and education.     Driven by post-Sept. 11 wariness and the spread of public databases that enables more efficient checking from distant locations, the industry is now rapidly consolidating. A handful of national companies is bulking up by buying smaller competitors, seeking dominance in a business expected to double in sales over the next five years to $4 billion.

headline: Mac Programs That Come With Thinking Caps On
abstract: IT'S time for another look at ''thinking tools'' -- software for storing, retrieving and generally making the best use of information. Today the focus is on programs for the Apple Macintosh.     These programs are of obvious interest to the Mac community, but the much larger community of non-Mac users also has good reason to keep an eye on them. Some are simply better than their current Word counterparts, illustrating features and approaches that PC users will want once they have seen them. The companies making two of the programs discussed here have announced forthcoming Windows versions.

headline: In 5th night of clashes, unrest spreads to other Paris suburbs
EVERYTHING'S RELATIVE
abstract: Lunch with Rupert Murdoch does not come cheap. William Zanker, the founder and president of the Learning Annex, discovered that when he bid $57,100 for the honor in an eBay auction to raise money for the Jerusalem College of Technology in Israel.     Even though he had to pay almost $1,000 a minute for the one-hour meal, Mr. Zanker crowed that it was a good deal. After all, he noted, he gives Donald J. Trump $1.5 million to deliver a one-hour lecture at real estate seminars. ''Paying Rupert Murdoch $1,000 a minute for a one-hour lunch feels like a bargain compared to the $25,000 a minute I'm paying Donald Trump,'' he said.

headline: Poor nations balk at trade proposals
Azerbaijan Leader Predicts Victory and Scoffs at 'Revolution'
abstract: President Ilham Aliyev predicted today that his party would win overwhelmingly in parliamentary elections next month.

headline: Economy Lost 35,000 Jobs, Much Below Expectations
abstract: Employment contracted at an unexpectedly modest pace in September, underscoring the American economy's strength in the first broad snapshot since Hurricane Katrina hit Louisiana and Mississippi in August.      The Department of Labor reported yesterday that the economy lost 35,000 jobs in September, the first contraction since May 2003. The unemployment rate rose for the first time in seven months, inching up to 5.1 percent in September from 4.9 percent in August.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Telef√≥nica Sees Market Growth
abstract: Telef√≥nica, Spain's biggest telephone company, expects Brazil's wireless market to expand as much as 40 percent this year, as falling interest rates and higher employment fuel demand for mobile services. Brazil's wireless companies added 15.6 million customers this year, ending October with 81.2 million users. Telef√≥nica is based in Madrid.

headline: Poison pill, a vote anda mystery at News Corp.
NTL lets CEO focus on deal with Virgin
Profit Declines 28% at Dell as Sales Growth Slows
abstract: Dell Inc. said yesterday that third-quarter profit fell 28 percent, hurt by one-time charges and by a slowdown in the rate of sales growth, a slowdown its chief executive said was likely to worsen this quarter.     Dell earned $606 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $846 million, or 33 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Briefly: GE net rises despite storms
BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: Apple Selects a Worldwide Sales Executive To Become Its Chief Operating Officer  Apple Computer has named Tim Cook, the company's executive vice president for worldwide sales and operations, as chief operating officer. Mr. Cook, left, who took over day-to-day operations during chief executive Steven P. Jobs' recovery from cancer surgery last year, will essentially become the No.2 person at Apple. ''Tim has been doing this job for over two years now, and it's high time we officially recognized it with this promotion,'' Mr. Jobs said in a statement. Mr. Cook, 44, will continue to overseeing worldwide operations and leading the Macintosh division, and will work with Mr. Jobs and the executive team to lead Apple's overall business, Apple said. The company also said Jon Rubinstein, head of the iPod unit, will retire March 31 and be succeeded by Tony Fadell, vice president for iPod engineering.   (AP)    Pension Agency Objects to Airline's Reorganization Plan  The government agency that insures corporate pensions has objected to United Airlines' reorganization plan, saying in court documents that the carrier has changed a deal covering the termination of its pensions. The Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said in a filing that the airline's disclosure statement, which details its financial model, is ''unconfirmable.'' United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, must get bankruptcy court approval of the statement before asking creditors to vote on restructuring. The agency complained that the plan was inconsistent with a settlement the parties reached last spring for the airline to turn its pensions over to the government.   (Reuters)    Medical Device Maker Posts a Quarterly Loss  Boston Scientific said yesterday that it had lost ground to its only medical device rival in the lucrative market for drug-coated heart stents, reporting a $269 million third-quarter loss and slowing sales of a stent that provided big profits last year. The performance, hurt by a $598 million expense for a legal settlement, fell short of company's projection and Wall Street's expectations. Boston Scientific executives said in a conference call with analysts that its Taxus stent has lost market share to the Cypher stent made by Johnson & Johnson's Cordis Corporation. The company, based in Natick, Mass., said it lost 33 cents a share and the results compared with a profit of $258 million, or 30 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 2 percent, to $1.51 billion.   (AP)    Bank of America's Purchase of MBNA Advances  Delaware's banking commissioner yesterday approved the proposed $35 billion acquisition of MBNA by the Bank of America Corporation, moving the buyout of the world's largest independent credit card issuer one step closer to completion. The approval of the Delaware banking commissioner, Robert Glen, was required because MBNA is based in Wilmington, Del. Bank of America is based in Charlotte, N.C.   (AP)    Justice Department Approves Software Merger  Adobe Systems said late Thursday that the Justice Department had approved its $3.4 billion acquisition of Macromedia. Adobe and Macromedia, two of the largest providers of graphic design software, must wait for several European jurisdictions to approve the deal before it can close. Adobe's Illustrator and Macromedia's Freehand are two of the leading products for vector graphics illustration, a term for drawings that are stored as collections of points and objects instead of pixels. A combined company would also own a substantial part of the market for Web site-building tools.   (AP)    Profit Rises 21 Percent at Insurer UnitedHealth  The UnitedHealth Group, one of the nation's largest health insurance companies, reported a 21 percent increase in third-quarter profit on membership gains and lower-than-expected medical costs. The company forecast profit growth would continue through 2006 at an annual rate of at least 15 percent. UnitedHealth predicted a Medicare prescription drug benefit would add 2 million to 3 million members to its rolls next year, potentially increasing 2006 earnings by 5 cents a share. UnitedHealth said it expected to complete its acquisition of PacifiCare Health by year-end or early in 2006. UnitedHealth said its third-quarter profit rose to $842 million, or 64 cents a share, from $698 million, or 52 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 15 percent, to $11.3 billion.   (Reuters)    Bush Seeks End to Lumber Trade Dispute With Canada  President Bush told the Canadian Prime Minister Paul Martin yesterday that it was time to find a solution to a long-running trade fight between the two countries over softwood lumber. A White House spokesman, Scott McClellan, said Mr. Bush and Mr. Martin spoke by telephone for about 20 minutes, and trade was a major part of their discussion. Mr. Martin criticized the United States government last week for its position on trade in lumber, saying Washington was ignoring a North American Free Trade Agreement ruling against United States duties on Canadian softwood lumber.   (Reuters)    Developer's Bid for British Grocer Is Accepted  A billionaire property developer, Robert Tchenguiz, and two partners won the right to buy Somerfield, a British grocer, for ¬£1.08 billion ($1.9 billion) to gain control of its real estate. The bid, 197 pence for each share in Somerfield, was accepted, Anthony Cardew, a spokesman for Somerfield, said yesterday. The investor group includes Tchenguiz, Apax Partners Worldwide and Barclays Capital. Mr. Tchenguiz will get control of 1,300 Somerfield and Kwik Save stores. Somerfield is based in Bristol, England.   (Bloomberg News)

headline: Executive's Article Revives Feud With Prosecutor
abstract: A former chairman of Goldman Sachs has rekindled a months-old dispute with Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, who is seeking to be governor.     In an op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, John C. Whitehead, the former chairman of Goldman Sachs, who now heads the corporation responsible for rebuilding Lower Manhattan, accused Mr. Spitzer of declaring ''war between us'' and warning that Mr. Whitehead would ''pay dearly for what you have done.''

headline: E.U. Offers New Tariff Cuts, but Internal Conflicts Remain
abstract: Calling it one of the biggest steps it has made in trade liberalization, the European Union unveiled a fresh offer of sweeping cuts in its agricultural tariffs.

headline: Google Gift to Digital Library
abstract: The Library of Congress will announce today a $3 million gift from Google to help the library begin building a World Digital Library, a project that aims to digitize and place on the Web significant primary materials from national libraries and other institutions worldwide.      James H. Billington, the librarian of Congress, said the World Digital Library would be modeled after the library's American Memory Project, started in 1994, which has been digitizing and placing on the Web millions of items, including manuscripts of Abraham Lincoln and Thomas Jefferson, the Gettysburg Address and Civil War photographs.

headline: Casablanca: A pragmatist's fresh take
Shantytown Dwellers in South Africa Protest Sluggish Pace of Change
abstract: Sending what some call an ominous signal to this nation's leaders, South Africa's sprawling shantytowns have begun to erupt, sometimes violently, in protest over the government's inability to deliver the better life that the end of apartheid seemed to herald a dozen years ago.     At a hillside shantytown in Durban called Foreman Road, riot police officers fired rubber bullets in mid-November to disperse 2,000 residents marching to the municipal mayor's office downtown. Two protesters were injured; 45 were arrested. The rest burned an effigy of the city's mayor, Obed Mlaba.

headline: Taser Shares Face Delisting by Nasdaq
abstract: Taser International, the maker of stun guns, said yesterday that the Nasdaq stock market might stop trading its shares because the company had failed to file a quarterly report with the Securities and Exchange Commission.      Taser shares fell 12 percent, the biggest drop in two months.

headline: Cable Relents on Channels for the Family
abstract: Nation's biggest cable companies, yielding to pressure from regulators, lawmakers and interest groups, say they expect to introduce packages of family-friendly channels as early as first quarter of 2006; National Cable and Telecommunications Association head Kyle McSlarrow says at least six cable companies, including two largest, Comcast and Time Warner Cable, are developing packages of channels that would appeal to parents who want to shield their children from potentially offensive shows; in recent weeks, FCC chairman Kevin J Martin and several congressmen have pressured cable industry to remedy concerns of advocacy groups that oppose sex, violence and profanity on airwaves; photo (M)

headline: Many Germans see a lost opportunity
Miles and More Miles, but Also More Snags
abstract: Joe Sharkey On the Road column describes problems that travelers with abundance of frequent-flier miles have in redeeming them; describes his wife's dealings with Continental and Northwest; drawing (M)

headline: March of the Malls, Not Always in Step
abstract: With a multimedia extravaganza that included magic tricks and fashion models shooting confetti out of cannons, the Mills Corporation broke ground last week in Chicago on a retail, entertainment, office and hotel complex that will fill a long-vacant block in the heart of the Loop.     It was a big moment for Mills, a fast-growing real estate investment trust based in Arlington, Va., that is known for developing huge off-price malls in outlying suburbs. Chosen by the city of Chicago from among 10 bidders, Mills is poised to begin construction on a significant site that had bedeviled other developers.

headline: Shares Retreat on Worries About Further Rate Increases
abstract: Stocks dropped yesterday amid speculation that the sales and earnings forecasts from Intel  and the Federal Reserve's stance toward interest rates might derail a fourth-quarter rally.     ''When the market is uncertain, it either drifts or goes down,'' said Cummins Catherwood Jr., who helps manage $715 million at Walnut Asset Management in Philadelphia. ''Looking at the economic figures that we're seeing, it tells you that inflation is coming. I suspect the Federal Reserve will keep beating on it gradually.''

headline: Icahn Finds Ally in Bid to Change Time Warner
abstract: Carl C. Icahn has a new, perhaps unlikely ally: Bruce Wasserstein.     Mr. Icahn, who is leading a group of dissident investors in a campaign against Time Warner and its board, said yesterday that he had hired Mr. Wasserstein and his firm, Lazard, to help advance the fight.

headline: Correction: Foreign Trade in the Port of South Louisiana
abstract: Because of a production error, a chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about efforts to rebuild the Louisiana port system misstated the value of imports and exports for the Port of South Louisiana. Here is the corrected chart.    IMPORTS: Fertilizer  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: $120.3    IMPORTS: Rice, barley, rye, oats, sorghum  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: 13.4    IMPORTS: Petroleum coke  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: 14.1    IMPORTS: Nonferrous ores and scrap  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: 40.6    IMPORTS: Gasoline and kerosene  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: 751.9    EXPORTS: Corn  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: $1,507.5    EXPORTS: Oilseed  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: 1,949.0    EXPORTS: Rice, barley, rye, oats, sorghum  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: 248.8    EXPORTS: Wheat  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: 472.4    EXPORTS: Petroleum coke  AMOUNT, IN MILLIONS: 77.2    (Sources by Army Corps of Engineers; Maritime Administration)

headline: Rise in Gases Unmatched by a History in Ancient Ice
abstract: Scientists report that shafts of ancient ice pulled from Antarctica's frozen depths show that for at least 650,000 years three important heat-trapping greenhouse gases never reached recent atmospheric levels caused by human activity; measured gases are carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide; concentrations have risen over last several centuries at pace far beyond that seen before humans began intensively clearing forests and burning coal, oil and other fossil fuels; sampling and analysis are done by European Program for Ice Coring in Antarctica, and are being published in journal Science (M)

headline: Business Briefs
abstract: Caterpillar Posts 34% Increase in Earnings But Disappoints Wall Street and Its Shares Fall  Caterpillar Inc., the heavy equipment maker, posted a 34 percent increase in third-quarter profit yesterday but its earnings and its outlook disappointed Wall Street, and its shares fell 10 percent. Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., said strong global demand and price increases helped push its earnings up to $667 million, or 94 cents a share, from $498 million, or 70 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue climbed 17 percent, to $8.98 billion from $7.66 billion, a year earlier. The income fell short of the $1.06 a share expected by analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. The company also cut its full-year forecast, saying it expects 2005 earnings of $3.85 to $4 a share, down from its previous estimate of $4 to $4.20 a share. Caterpillar said it lowered earnings expectations because of a higher tax rate and about $100 million in expected pretax expenses for changes in its dealer distribution software and a product realignment under consideration. Its stock slid $5.11, to $48.92 a share. (AP)    United Airlines Bankruptcy Reorganization Advances  United Airlines' bid to come out of bankruptcy in early 2006 advanced yesterday when a judge approved the disclosure statement that is a key part of its exit plan. Judge Eugene Wedoff of United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago said at a monthly bankruptcy hearing for the UAL Corporation, United's holding company, that he approved the statement yesterday morning after the biggest objections to it had been withdrawn. The disclosure statement details the airline's plans for emerging from bankruptcy and outlines how creditors will be paid. Judge Wedoff also formally approved United's exit financing, a $3 billion all-debt package led by J.P. Morgan Chase and Citigroup.    Wyeth's Profit Slips After Restructuring and Tax Charges  The pharmaceutical maker Wyeth said yesterday that its third-quarter profit fell sharply from a year earlier, when it benefited from a tax gain, but sales for its prescription drugs increased. The company said it earned $869.9 million, or 64 cents a share, in the period, compared with $1.42 billion, or $1.05 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 5 percent, to $4.7 billion, as higher sales of the Enbrel arthritis drug and Prevnar vaccine for childhood infections offset lower sales of its Effexor antidepressant. (Reuters)    Profit Slips at Xerox but Color Technology Sales Gain  The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that third-quarter profit slid sharply on one-time charges, but sales of its color technology were strong and its results met Wall Street's expectations. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., said net income declined to $49 million, or 5 cents a share, from $149 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue increased to $3.76 billion from $3.72 billion. Xerox said sales of its color technology rose 22 percent over the year-earlier period. (AP)    Maytag Posts $18.2 Million Third-Quarter Loss  The Maytag Corporation, the appliance maker, reported a bigger-than-expected third-quarter loss yesterday amid excess capacity and high prices for oil and materials. Maytag reported a loss of $18.2 million, or 23 cents a share, in contrast to profit of $7.5 million, or 9 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 6.5 percent, to $1.26 billion. The results include restructuring charges of 2 cents a share, compared with 16 cents a share a year earlier. Maytag has agreed to be acquired by a larger rival, the Whirlpool Corporation, for $1.7 billion in cash and stock. Ralph Hake, the chief executive, said a shareholder vote to approve the deal was scheduled for Dec. 16. (AP)    Charles Schwab Prefers That an Insider Succeed Him  Charles Schwab, the founder and chief executive of the Charles Schwab Corporation, the discount broker, said the company's next chief executive would come from inside the firm. Mr. Schwab, 68, plans to remain chairman of the company ''indefinitely,'' he said yesterday at a gathering of investors in San Francisco. Mr. Schwab, who returned as chief executive in July 2004, said previously he would remain chief executive until 2007. ''I told the board yesterday that I will remain here as C.E.O. as long as it takes but not a day longer,'' Mr. Schwab said. ''I'm not in favor of dropping someone in'' from outside the company, he said. (Bloomberg News)    Exploration Boom Fuels Profit Rise at Schlumberger  Schlumberger Ltd., the oil field services company, said third-quarter profit rose 70 percent as soaring oil and natural-gas prices prompted increased investment in exploration. Net income rose to $540.8 million, or 89 cents a share, from $318.2 million, or 53 cents a share, a year earlier, Schlumberger said. The company, based in New York and Paris, said revenue rose 27 percent, to $3.7 billion. All regions posted revenue gains of at least 20 percent, led by a 31 percent rise in Latin America. Disruptions from hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico reduced net income by about $36 million, or 6 cents a share, the company said. Oil and gas exploration and production activity worldwide continued to grow during the quarter, even with disruptions from Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, Schlumberger's chief executive, Andrew Gould, said in a statement. (Bloomberg News)    Orders in Americas Help Results at Ericsson  The Swedish telecommunications equipment maker LM Ericsson said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings grew 22 percent as sales of wireless network equipment surged in North and South America. Ericsson's sales were also strong in the Asia-Pacific region, but they were flat in Western Europe. Net profit rose to 5.31 billion kronor ($673 million) in the quarter, from 4.35 billion kronor a year earlier. Sales were up 14 percent, to 36.2 billion kronor ($4.59 billion). Latin American sales grew 40 percent with particularly strong results in Brazil and Mexico. In North America, sales were up 45 percent, helped by deals to upgrade the networks of Cingular Wireless. (AP)

headline: Hewlett Chief Tells Wall St. Efficiency Drive Is Still On
abstract: In his first appearance before Wall Street analysts yesterday, Mark V. Hurd, who took over eight months ago as the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, delivered a clear message: The company's business strategy has not yet changed, but the management style and focus certainly have.     His priority, Mr. Hurd said, would be execution and accountability. The drive for further improvements in efficiency will not let up, he said, although he portrayed the cutting of 14,500 workers in July as a ''one-time action.''

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Police Kill 6 Protesters
abstract: Riot police kill at least six people at demonstration in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, as parliamentary elections held in May continue to divide country; opposition says country's ruling party rigged election results and accuses government of detaining many of its top leaders (S)

headline: Briefs: U.S. pushes China on markets
New Delhi Police Doubt a Boast; Shoppers Back, a Day After Blasts
abstract: New Delhi's shopping centers return to near normalcy day after synchronized string of bombs tears through packed holiday-season markets there, killing 59 people; little-known militant outfit in disputed Kashmir Province claims responsibiilty, but police insist that investigation remains inconclusive; photo (M)

headline: At-Home Enterprises Seek Elbow Room
abstract: Eric Poses wanted to hire an assistant for the game-board company that he was running out of his two-bedroom condominium in Santa Monica, but realized it was too cramped to accommodate another desk.     Joan Casey, whose consulting business was based in her Brookline, Mass., home, needed a quieter place to meet with clients.

headline: Arab League Plan for Hussein Exile Went Sour, Arab Leader Says
abstract: Months before the invasion of Iraq, Saddam Hussein tentatively accepted a proposal to go into exile and avert war, but Arab leaders scuttled the deal, unable to reach consensus on it, senior officials in the United Arab Emirates said this week.      Sheik Muhammad bin Zayed al-Nahyan, the crown prince of Abu Dhabi and son of the late president, Sheik Zayed al-Nahyan, told the pan-Arab news channel Al Arabiya on Saturday that his father had received conditional acceptance from Mr. Hussein to go into exile before the invasion of Iraq, in exchange for amnesty and protection.

headline: Pez MP3 Player
abstract: Any eBay veteran can tell you about the unusual relationship that collectors have with Pez dispensers. The little plastic candy holders were one of the first collectible items to take off in online auctions. Just last month, a Dutch buyer paid $800 for a vintage model shaped like a pear.      Now, for $99, Pez aficionados can take their obsession into the digital age with the new portable Pez MP3 player. The device, available at pezmp3.com, is powered by a single AAA battery and topped by the Pez Pal Boy head.

headline: Eating Your Way to Health; Companies Are Marketing Fortified Foods to the Drug-Wary
abstract: Ever since she gave birth to her fourth child in 2003, Michelle Celona, a 43-year-old part-time teacher in Philadelphia, had suffered from annoying bouts of constipation. Figuring it was the stress of carting three children around or the result of something that had changed in her body after pregnancy, she learned to live with it.      But when the Dannon Company asked Ms. Celona in June if she wanted to participate in a two-week trial for Activia, a new fortified yogurt that the company said could help speed up what nutritionists delicately refer to as intestinal transit time, she jumped at the chance.
