headline: Fed raises U.S. rates a 12th time
Betting high on risky China bank
Rice's Visit: Official Praise, Public Doubts
abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice left behind two Europes when she returned home this weekend from her diplomatic tour aimed at reassuring the allies of the United Sates that the Bush administration did not practice torture and abided by its international obligations.     One was the Europe of government leaders and diplomats who generally praised Ms. Rice for her reassurances, and said that they were satisfied with what she had told them.

headline: It's 33 Feet Wide, but Enough for a Hotel
abstract: IT is easy to spend $400 a night to stay at a hotel in Manhattan. It is less easy to find one for under $200. (The most recent average daily room rate was $221.62 for the first six months of the year, according to PKF Consulting.)     So it would appear that there is a market for a well-located new hotel whose effective daily rate is in the range of $180 to $190. ''These days, that is a relative bargain,'' said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF, which specializes in the hospitality industry.

headline: Of Man's Seven Ages, No. 6 Is Wrenching, and Ever More Costly
abstract: The seventh age of man is starkly clear-cut: ''sans teeth, sans eyes'' and all that. It's the sixth that's the tricky one, that wrenching limbo when a person gradually comes face to face with a ''world too wide'' -- when, say, an aging parent is no longer quite capable of living alone but is far from needing to move to a nursing home.      In an ideal, Norman Rockwell world, a family member takes the person in, but for any number of reasons, that option is often not possible these days. That's where assisted-living facilities come in -- and with an aging population, assisted living is most definitely a growth business.

headline: France Declares State of Emergency to Curb Crisis
abstract: Rioters have sown disorder in the streets, burning cars, targeting businesses, schools and churches and police.

headline: Briefly: Foot-sore commuters bundle up during strike
Gun-Happy Brazil Hotly Debates a Nationwide Ban
abstract: Government plan for complete, nationwide ban on guns generates impassioned civic debate in Brazil, country where nearly 40,000 people were killed by firearms in 2003 alone; country will vote on Oct 23; referendum is thought to be first time anywhere in world that electorate is called on to decide issue; Brazil has second-largest arms industry in Western Hemisphere, and it exports 80 percent of weapons to neighboring countries; both sides agree that race is tight, and outcome is uncertain; photos (M)

headline: Iran Looking, Once Again, for Nominee for Oil Post
abstract: Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's candidate for major post in Iran, oil minister, withdraws his candidacy for job in face of increasing criticism over his inexperience; members of Paliament voice discontent with Ahmadinejad's other cabinet nominees, claiming they were nominated for being his comrades in Revolutionary Guards or during his time as mayor of Tehran; Ahmadinejad says he would continue purging ministry figures who are close to his political rivals (M)

headline: Novartis Would Consider U.S. Vaccine Plant, Chief Says
abstract: Novartis chief executive Dr Daniel L Vasella says company will consider building vaccine production plant in US amid concern that its deal for Chiron Corp will leave US overly reliant on foreign companies for flu vaccine supplies (M)

headline: U.S. Approval Is Expected Soon for Sale of Guidant
abstract: Johnson & Johnson's proposed acquisition of Guidant Corp is expected to be approved by Federal Trade Commission as early as Nov 1; approval may force companies to end standoff over renegotiating price of $25.4 billion deal; Johnson & Johnson is pushing to lower price, contending that Guidant's business has been seriously damaged since it recalled tens of thousands of implantable heart devices like defibrillators and pacemakers; Food and Drug Administration is investigating Guidant's handling of product-related safety issues (M)

headline: Poll Workers in Rebel City: Danger 'Has a Purpose' Now
abstract: Clutching net bags of overnight essentials with boxes of ballots under their arms, about 700 poll workers climbed aboard giant armored trucks on Friday and rode along one of Iraq's most dangerous highways to voting sites all over this city.      The workers -- mostly poor Shiites from southern Iraq and slums in Baghdad -- came to run polling stations here in Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province and the center of Iraq's violent insurgency. The pay was low ($300 for 10 days) considering that the risk was high (as of 7 p.m., the marines had found at least six roadside bombs in the western part of the city alone).

headline: Adobe's Deal for Macromedia May Help It Fend Off Microsoft
abstract: Adobe Systems and Macromedia spent more than a decade as fierce rivals in the software market. Now they are hoping that by banding together they can be better positioned to face increasingly aggressive competition from Microsoft.      Early this month, Adobe completed its $3.4 billion acquisition of Macromedia, giving it control of Flash, Macromedia's crown jewel, a software tool for developing multimedia applications for the Web.

headline: EastWest Creative Acquires an Agency
abstract: The Bezos/Nathanson Marketing Group, a New York creative agency founded in 2000, has been acquired by EastWest Creative, a promotional marketing agency also based in New York. Terms were not disclosed.     The six staff members of Bezos/Nathanson and their accounts, which include Cendant and Jet Airways, join EastWest, which has more than 90 employees and accounts like Cadbury Schweppes and Kraft Foods.

headline: Early Results Show Religious Groups Leading in Iraqi Vote
abstract: The main Shiite coalition had taken a commanding lead with nearly two-thirds of the ballots having been counted.

headline: Remorseful or Not, Buyers Start to Return to Japanese Real Estate
abstract: IN the United States, there is talk about real estate bubbles. In Japan, there is knowledge, and plenty of it, about what happens after one pops.     Figures on housing starts released this week in Tokyo provided evidence that the market finally has gotten over the long and painful decline, and that the Japanese are more willing to buy new homes after avoiding them as prices fell for many years. In the 12 months through October, construction began on 1.22 million homes, nearly 8 percent more than at the low point reached in early 2003.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: G.E. Buys Stake in a Bank
abstract: GE Consumer Finance, consumer-lending unit of General Electric, will buy stake in Shenzhen Development Bank of China; will buy newly issued shares in bank for $100 million (S)

headline: Annual Meeting Embraces Lucy and Ethel and Does a Little Gecko-Bashing
abstract: Stuart Elliott reports on various highlights, lowlights and sidelights of 95th annual meeting of Assn of Natl Advertisers, attended by more than 900 people, in Phoenix; notes one topic discussed by many speakers during conference was branded entertainment, integration of products and sponsors into movies and television programming; photos (M)

headline: Crucial Antibiotic Rescues Biotech Maker's Finances
abstract: ViroPharma, formerly struggling biotechnology company, is reaping financial windfall from Vancocin, only drug approved to treat Clostridium difficile, bacterium that kills thousands of people a year in US and is apparently becoming more common and more deadly; ViroPharma acquired American rights to drug last November; company has increased price of drug, its only product, three times by total of 80 percent, to about $800 for course of treatment; sales are expected to more than double this year to $120 million; company's stock is up 14-fold since reaching 52-week low in April; some doctors say price increases are exploiting growing fears of bacterium; company's chief executive Michel de Rosen comments; photo (M)

headline: Entr'acte:If only French leaders listened to pop culture
Merkel Takes Office in Germany and Announces Coalition Cabinet
abstract: German Parliament elects Angela Markel chancellor, making her first woman to lead a postwar German government and first chancellor to have grown up under Communist government in East Germany; after vote, in which 397 of 614 members of Parliament support her, Markel is sworn in as eighth chancellor since end of World War II (S)

headline: Immigrant Polygamy Is a Factor in French Unrest, a Gaullist Says
abstract: An effort to explain recent violence sets off charges of racism.

headline: LOOKING AHEAD
abstract: ESCAPE HATCH CLOSES -- In a country with a savings rate that has fallen below 1 percent, going broke just got a lot more painful. The new federal bankruptcy law took effect today, ending the stampede to the courthouse by debt-strapped individuals and businesses eager to apply for protection from creditors under the old, looser rules.    TURN OF CREDIT SCREWS -- Count Toshihiko Fukui, governor of the Bank of Japan, in Alan Greenspan's anti-inflation corner. The two men will confer today in Tokyo, and Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, will no doubt get a sympathetic hearing on his penchant for notching up short-term interest rates. Last week, Mr. Fukui, above, announced the imminent end of the Japanese central bank's superloose monetary policy as the nation's economy picks up momentum. Not to be outdone, Treasury Secretary John W. Snow, in Beijing for trade talks, will be lecturing China's Securities Industry Association.    TAX TINKERING -- President Bush's tax advisory commission is holding its final meeting tomorrow before making recommendations to the White House on Nov. 1 for overhauling the federal income-tax system. Expect some fireworks after the panel's report comes out. Last week, a Houston organization called Americans for Fair Taxation attacked its proceedings as ''fraudulent political theater.''    ECONOMIC BELLWETHERS -- With inflation jitters spreading, attention this week will be focused on tomorrow's producer-price index for September and Wednesday's figures on housing starts for the same month. Also out this week are the Fed's beige book survey of economic conditions on Wednesday and leading economic indicators on Thursday.    A LOSS LOOMS -- General Motors -- which is holding talks with the United Auto Workers to lower health care costs -- is expected to announce a third-quarter loss today. Earnings season gets into full swing this week with reports out today from Citigroup and I.B.M.; tomorrow from 3M, Intel, Johnson & Johnson, Merrill Lynch, Motorola and Yahoo; Wednesday from Bank of America, Eastman Kodak, eBay, Honeywell and J.P. Morgan Chase; Thursday from Coca-Cola, Eli Lilly, Ford, Google, JetBlue, McDonald's, Pfizer and Southwest; and Friday from Wyeth and Xerox.

headline: 5 Israelis killed by suicide bomber
U.S. saving Europeans, Rice asserts
Dolans Drop Plan to Take Cablevision Private
abstract: Charles Dolan family withdraws its bid to take Cablevision Systems Corp private, after negotiating since June, and asks directors to approve $3 billion dividend to shareholders; family controls 71 percent of votes and 22 percent of equity in company; dividend would net Dolan family $600 million (M)

headline: New Optimism About the Japanese Economy After a Bleak Decade
abstract: Most economists and analysts believe economic recovery in Japan is real, its roots extending through Japanese economy; economists say that Japan seems to have addressed its bubble-era problems and emerged leaner and more competitive after more than decade of working off excessive debt, bloated payrolls and overbuilt factory capacity; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Blasts Kill 7 Sri Lankan Soldiers, Threatening Cease-Fire
abstract: The second precision attack on the Sri Lankan Army in three days raised the prospect of renewed conflict in this country.

headline: Thousands of Quake Survivors Trapped in Himalayan Villages
abstract: Pelting hail and rain, and a shortage of copters, prevented rescuers from reaching people, Pakistani officials said today.

headline: Transit strike in New York ends
Google's Shopping Service to List User's Local Stores
abstract: Google executives said last night that the company planned to move quickly to capitalize on its new Google Base database service, adding a feature that lets merchants provide local shopping information.     Many publishers had become concerned about the potential of Google Base, which could allow the company to dominate the classified advertising business. Now, publishers of services like the Yellow Pages are facing a competitive threat from Google.

headline: Broadcaster Is Reported Ready to Sell Radio Stations to Investors
abstract: Susquehanna Media, the nation's largest privately owned radio broadcaster, is near a deal to sell its group of radio stations to investors including Cumulus Media, the Blackstone Group and Bain Capital for more than $1 billion, executives involved in the talks said.     The company is also close to a separate agreement to sell its cable television operations to Comcast for slightly less than $800 million, the executives said. Both transactions could be announced as early as next week, they said.

headline: Competition in Registered Travel
abstract: COMPETITION IN REGISTERED TRAVEL -- There is growing competition in the nascent Registered Travel program that enables passengers to move more quickly through airport security. The program is run by private companies under federal supervision, and passengers pay a fee to be prescreened to get a biometric encoded identification card, which uses fingerprints and iris scans. Right now, the only operating program is called Clear, run at the airport in Orlando, Fla., by Verified Identity Pass of New York. Yesterday, the Saflink Corporation, a security company based in Bellevue, Wash., said it had expanded a partnership that now includes Microsoft to compete in the Registered Traveler program. Other partners include Johnson Controls., Expedia Corporate Travel and ID Technology Partners. The Transportation Security Administration has said a wide rollout of the program beyond Orlando would begin next year at airports nationally. At Orlando, more than 11,000 frequent fliers have already signed up for Clear, which costs $79.95 a year, the company's founder, Steven Brill, said. Saflink, in announcing yesterday that it had expanded its partnership, said its competing card could also be used as a credit card.    A COURTYARD FOR MOSCOW -- The first Courtyard by Marriott hotel in Russia is scheduled to open this week with rooms ''offering spectacular views of the Kremlin,'' Marriott International says. The opening of the 218-room hotel will expand to 100,000 the number of guest rooms within Courtyard, Marriott's main moderately priced brand, which operates 700 hotels in the United States and abroad. Introductory rates at the Moscow Courtyard will start at $225 plus tax, the company said.    FOR BETTER ONLINE BOOKING -- More than 80 percent of small-business travelers book trips directly on airline Web sites, but they are not especially impressed with the sites' flexibility, a new survey by the American Small Business Travelers Alliance, a nonprofit organization based in Flower Mound, Tex., finds. ''The Internet has done much to level the playing field for small-business travelers,'' Chet Gray, the vice president of the group, said in a statement. Small businesses, including the self-employed, do not typically have access to in-house booking systems used by big companies to arrange travel. While the survey shows small-business travelers are avidly booking online directly with airlines, ''opportunities remain for more tailored services on these sites,'' Mr. Gray said.    ONE THICK MAGAZINE -- A new in-flight magazine, US Airways Magazine, with its first issue in January weighing in at a fat 200-plus pages, is being published by Pace Communications, which also puts out United Airlines' Hemispheres and Delta Air Lines' Sky magazines. US Airways Magazine, with a monthly printing of 375,000 copies, will replace America West Magazine and US Airways' Attach√© magazine, and will be available on all flights flown by the merged carriers and their regional partners.    LEARN FRENCH WHILE YOU FLY  -- Travelers on Singapore Airlines can now take interactive language-learning lessons in 20 different languages on the airlines' in-flight on-demand entertainment system. That doubles the number of language offerings available since the program began in June, the airline said. The programs are produced by Berlitz World Traveler. In all, Singapore's in-flight entertainment system, which it calls KrisWorld, has more than 500 on-demand video and audio options, including 60 movies.    QUESTIONS WITHOUT ANSWERS -- A reader was asked the following at a check-in counter at the airport in Birmingham, Ala.: ''Has anyone put anything in your baggage without your knowledge?'' The reader's reply: ''If it was without my knowledge, how would I know?''

headline: Profit Increases at Tiffany
abstract: Tiffany & Co says third-quarter profit rose 37 percent; net income climbed to $23.8 million from $17.4 million year earlier; sales rose 8.4 percent, to $500.1 million (S)0

headline: Fed Gives Mixed Sign on Rates
abstract: After raising interest rates for the 13th time in a row on Tuesday, the Federal Reserve said that its work was not yet finished.     As expected, the Fed raised the benchmark federal funds rate on overnight bank loans to 4.25 percent, from 4 percent. At the same time, it dampened the hopes of some on Wall Street that it was near the end of its campaign to control inflation by tightening its monetary policy.

headline: A warning as U.S. toll hits 2,000
U.S. Patent Office Likely to Back BlackBerry Maker
abstract: The technology patents at the heart of an infringement lawsuit by NTP against Research In Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry wireless e-mail device, are likely to be struck down by the United States patent office, both companies said on Monday, a move that would be a setback for NTP.     The United States Patent and Trademark Office took the unusual step of notifying the companies that it expected to reject the five patents held by NTP in its final rulings.

headline: BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: Director of Ford Motor's Hybrid Program Resigns  Mary Ann Wright, left, the Ford Motor Company's director of hybrid programs and chief engineer on the Ford Escape Hybrid, resigned yesterday. She is one of many senior managers to recently exit Ford, which plans a restructuring next year. Ms. Wright, who had been with Ford since 1988 in high-level engineering roles, was involved in Ford's hybrid and fuel-efficiency initiatives. She also helped conduct the company's recent hybrid clinics with consumers, where she trumpeted Ford's commitment to hybrids and improved vehicle fuel efficiency. Ms. Wright will be succeeded by Nancy Gioia, who previously oversaw engineering of small vehicles, including the Mustang.   (Dow Jones/AP)    Judge Refuses to Become Involved in Google Case  A federal judge has rebuffed an attempt by Google Inc. to remove court-ordered restrictions limiting its employment of the computer scientist Kai-Fu Lee, whose recent defection from Microsoft exposed tensions between the companies. In a ruling late Thursday, Federal District Judge Ronald Whyte in San Jose, Calif., declined to become involved in the legal battle over Mr. Lee until the completion of a Washington State trial on the validity of a noncompete agreement Mr. Lee signed when he joined Microsoft in 2000. The Washington trial is scheduled to begin Jan. 9.   (AP)    Profits Decline at Archer Daniels Midland  Shares of the Archer Daniels Midland Company rose yesterday despite a 30 percent decline in first-quarter earnings from sluggish grain sales because of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Much of the profit decline was attributed to the agricultural services unit, which was disrupted by the storms. The largest business segments, including corn and oilseed processing, showed solid profit growth. Net income was $186.3 million, or 29 cents a share, compared with $266.3 million, or 41 cents, a year earlier. Analysts had expected 33 cents a share. Sales dropped 4 percent, to $8.63 billion, below analysts' estimates of $9.08 billion.   (AP)    No Accord, F.C.C. to Meet Again on 2 Takeover Deals  Federal regulators failed to reach agreement yesterday on whether to approve the takeover of AT&T by SBC Communications and the purchase of MCI by Verizon Communications. The Federal Communications Commission met through the day but could not agree on what conditions, if any, should be attached to the deals. Another meeting was set for Monday. The negotiations come a day after the Justice Department gave its blessing to the acquisitions, with limited conditions.   (AP)    AirTran Decides Not to Sell Tickets on Expedia  AirTran Holdings Inc., parent of AirTran Airways, said yesterday that it would no longer make its inventory and fares available for sale with Expedia Inc., which runs the online travel agency Expedia.com. The low-cost carrier also said it had entered a multiyear deal with the Cendant Corporation to sell tickets through its Apollo and Galileo travel sites.   (Reuters)    S.E.C. Names 2 Directors of Enforcement  The Securities and Exchange Commission has named Peter Bresnan and Walter Ricciardi as deputy directors of enforcement, the first time the agency has split the post between two people. Mr. Bresnan, 50, who is an associate enforcement director in Washington, will oversee staffing issues like assignments. Mr. Ricciardi, 52, who is head of the S.E.C.'s Boston office, will manage and track the workload. They will replace succeed Thomsen, who was named director in May.   (Bloomberg News)    Profit Soars 46% at Deutsche Bank  Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, said yesterday that third-quarter profit increased 46 percent after a surge in trading revenue and the highest fees from underwriting and giving mergers advice in almost three years. Net income rose to 991 million euros ($1.2 billion), or 1.89 euros a share, from 680 million euros, or 1.28 euros. Analysts had expected profit of 839 million euros. Revenue gained 31 percent, to 6.62 billion euros.   (Bloomberg News)    Matsushita Electric Reports Higher Income on Strong Sales  The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, the Japanese maker of Panasonic electronics, said yesterday that its profit surged 33 percent for the July-September quarter, lifted by strong sales of flat-panel TVs, digital cameras and personal computers. The Osaka-based company said profit was 31 billion yen ($268 million) in the second quarter, up from 23 billion yen in the period a year earlier. Sales were unchanged at 2.2 trillion yen ($19 billion).   (AP)

headline: New Xbox Goes on Sale at Midnight. Good Luck.
abstract: Retailers will begin selling Microsoft's Xbox 360 at midnight, Nov 21, but some stores have already sold out their allotment through advance orders and Internet sales; Wall Street analysts expect shortage of game consoles in US, with some saying Microsoft has purposely stoked demand beyond company's ability to meet it; photo (M)

headline: Google Found to Be Testing Classified Ads
abstract: Online classified service being tested by Google sets off intense speculation after Web site for service is accidentally made public and discovered by British computer programmer; service is named Google Base (M)

headline: Manufacturers look outside Germany for survival
China Allows Yuan To Pass Key Point
abstract: Beijing authorities permitted China's currency to inch past a psychologically important benchmark in trading on Friday, but the move only underlined their reluctance to tolerate anything more than very gradual currency appreciation against the dollar.      The yuan crept up to 8.084 to the dollar on Friday, for a total increase of just 0.32 percent over the 14 weeks since China revalued its currency on July 21. The move was crucial because at the time of the revaluation, Chinese authorities said they would not permit the yuan to rise or fall more than 0.3 percent against the dollar in a single day.

headline: HK man jailed in world's first copyright violation case
In egalitarian Europe, a not-so-hidden world of squalor
3 Sunni Parties Form Bloc to Take Part in Iraq Vote
abstract: Leaders of three Sunni political parties joined together Wednesday to compete in the Dec. 15 parliamentary elections, a sign that the country's embittered Sunni Arab minority might play a more active role in the democratic process.     The alliance, the Iraqi Concord Front, will field candidates in the elections for a new National Assembly and work as a bloc to advance Sunni interests, said leaders of the three groups involved: the Iraqi Islamic Party, the National Dialogue Council and the Iraqi People's Gathering.

headline: Profile: Harold Pinter
Indonesia to produce Tamiflu
Chinese protesters report a massacre
Iran's Stocks Plunge After Vote for U.N. Review of Nuclear Program
abstract: Iran's government and Parliament held emergency meetings this week on the country's plummeting stock market, where prices have declined nearly 30 percent since Sept. 24. The decline began after the International Atomic Energy Agency passed a resolution referring Iran to the United Nations Security Council for violating its nuclear obligations.      Meraj Naderi, a stock analyst in Tehran, said: ''The line to sell shares was really long and there was no one to buy. There had been ups and downs in the stock market, but I had never seen such a thing.''

headline: Cheney Cites Progress During Surprise Visit
abstract: Vice President Dick Cheney paid a surprise visit to Iraq while insurgents launched a string of attacks that left at least nine people dead.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Chirac Rejects New Farm Aid Cuts
abstract: President Jacques Chirac of France said that he would oppose any further changes to the European Union's system of farm subsidies. His remarks came after the European trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, said earlier in the day that he would present new plans to cut farm trade barriers today. The plans come amid a last-ditch effort to rescue collapsed talks aimed at agreeing upon a framework for a global trade accord in Hong Kong in December.

headline: Canada's leader backs minister
THE CHURN
abstract: Deal Makers       Citigroup advised Sprint Nextel on its agreement to buy wireless affiliate Alamosa Holdings for $3.4 billion. King & Spalding served as legal adviser. Alamosa was advised by Blackstone Group, UBS and the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

headline: EU data retention measure falls short of British plan
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consumer Prices Rise
abstract: Japan's consumer prices rose last month for the first time in two years, gains the central bank says need to be sustained before it can change its policy of keeping interest rates at almost zero. Core prices rose 0.1 percent from a year earlier, the first gain since October 2003, and only the second rise in more than seven years, the government's statistics bureau said. The gain, which excluded prices of fresh food, matched the median forecast of 30 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. Prices have not kept pace with an economy the government said will expand for a fifth year in the 12 months starting April. Excluding energy and all food, Japan's consumer prices fell 0.2 percent in November.

headline: Strategy Seen on Airbus Aid
abstract: European governments are expected to delay any formal pledges of aid to build the Airbus A350 jet in an effort to defuse a serious trade dispute with the United States, a European official said on Wednesday.     The European Union and the United States are locked in a battle over subsidies to Airbus and Boeing. American officials contend that European governments are paying billions of dollars to Airbus to help develop new planes, while European officials say the United States subsidizes Boeing with billions of dollars in contracts for research and development.

headline: Saddam Gets His Day in Court
abstract: The trial of former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein begins on Wednesday. The tribunal, part victors' justice, part reprocessing of history, could end sooner than expected, with the defendant possibly facing the gallows after only the first of 12 planned trials.

headline: Congo Troops Move to Evict Ugandan Rebels
abstract: United Nations airlifts several hundred Congolese soldiers to remote northeastern area to confront members of Ugandan rebel group Lord's Resistance Army that crossed border into Congo in September (S)

headline: 'EASY' CAN BE HARD
abstract: The serial entrepreneur Stelios Haji-Ioannou, the founder of the budget airline easyJet, the budget snack vendor easyPizza and the budget lodging chain easyHotel, is finding that the watch business is a bit, well, difficult.     Soon after introducing an easyWatch line of timepieces, named after stops that his easyCruise passenger liner makes in the Mediterranean, he was sued by the Swiss watch company Richemont. Both make a watch called the Portofino, although the Richemont version offers style choices like 18-karat white gold and crocodile straps, and sells for up to $7,000. The easyWatch version comes with no style choices, a ''rubber-feel'' strap and sells for less than $20.

headline: A One-Wheeled Semi Rules a Battered Capital's Roads
abstract: Wheelbarrow is cornerstone of vast, informal economy in Monrovia, Liberia, war-scarred city with no electricity or running water where official unemployment rate exceeds 80 percent; wheelbarrows are used to transport all kinds of products; they are numbered and lettered, and fees for certain kinds of loads are fixed; photo (M)

headline: Outlook Express and Viruses
abstract: Outlook Express And Viruses    Q. I use Outlook Express for e-mail. Does that window at the bottom that shows the selected message make me more vulnerable to computer viruses?    A. Outlook Express has had its share of security problems over the years, and there have been malicious threats that take advantage of its preview pane, which displays the contents of a message without your having to open the file. Internet security experts have often recommended turning off the preview pane to prevent such instant virus and worm infections when you go through your e-mail.     You can turn off the preview pane by going to the Views menu in Outlook Express, selecting the Layout option and unchecking the box next to ''Show preview pane.''

headline: Quality Issues Delay a Chip From Intel
abstract: Intel will postpone volume production of new processor for network servers because of problems with quality of product; still expects chip, code-named Montecito, to offer twice performance of current version (S)

headline: China aims to reassure public on mine blasts
On Milton Friedman's Birthday, We Get the Present: Him
abstract: ONE of the infinite number of ways in which I have been blessed is in the friends I inherited from my parents. Peter M. Flanigan, investment banker and aide to my former boss, Richard M. Nixon, and ambassador to Spain. Roy L. Ash, a co-founder of Litton Industries and a budget director in the Nixon and Ford administrations. Mr. Nixon, president and peacemaker. Paul W. McCracken, genius economist and adviser to three presidents. C. Lowell Harriss, a super teacher and emeritus professor of economics at Columbia University. Anna Jacobson Schwartz, a renowned economist and statistician. And the list goes on and on.      But at the top of the totem pole for their contributions to man's progress and to human understanding comes Milton Friedman, and his wife, Rose D. Friedman. This week, a giant f√™te is being held in their honor (nominally about his 90th birthday, although he actually turned 93 in July) in Los Angeles. I was to be the master of ceremonies, but I was also needed to preach the good gospel of freedom and gratitude at the University of Utah that night, so I think I will tell a little bit about this giant of a man right now.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Internal Memorandum at Wal-Mart Outlines Company's Health Strategy  An internal memo sent to Wal-Mart's board proposes many ways to hold down spending on health care and other benefits while seeking to minimize damage to the retailer's reputation. Among the recommendations were hiring more part-time workers and discouraging unhealthy people from working at Wal-Mart. [Page C1.]    McDonald's to Add Nutrition Labels  McDonald's announced that it would begin putting nutrition labels on most of its food products starting next year. [C1.]    Family Withdraws Bid to Take Cablevision Private  The Charles Dolan family withdrew its bid to take the Cablevision Systems Corporation private and asked directors to approve a $3 billion dividend to shareholders. The family issued a statement saying that it ''has become clear that we will be unable to reach an agreement'' with directors. [C1.]    German Industrial Workers Face a New Reality  Just as the American auto industry and its workers are facing stark choices between reducing costs and preserving a social compact that has long provided generous wages and benefits, Germans are confronting the grim arithmetic of the global economy: most industrial workers here are paid far too much to compete with those in Eastern Europe and Asia. [C1.]    DaimlerChrysler reported that its third-quarter profit dropped by more than one-fifth even as business steadily improved at both its Chrysler and Mercedes-Benz divisions. It attributed its weakened performance to increased income tax expenses. [C7.]    Survey Indicates Confidence in German Economy  The German economy, which has taken one step back for every two steps forward since the recession of 2003, may finally be on firm footing, according to a new survey. The Ifo survey of business confidence rose 2.7 points in October, to 98.7, its highest level in five years. But the emergence of Angela Merkel, the conservative leader, left, as the designated chancellor of a ''grand coalition'' government seems to have soothed the uncertainties of German business people. [C10.]    An Unknown Becomes a Safe Choice for Fed  Ben S. Bernanke, President Bush's choice to succeed Alan Greenspan as Federal Reserve chairman, has a world-class reputation among economists, credibility on Wall Street, and an air of political independence that seems free from hints of cronyism. [A1.]    New Data Shows Easing of Housing Market Boom  Sales prices for existing homes fell last month and total sales stayed flat, providing further indications that the housing boom is starting to cool. [C3.]    Microsoft Plans an Online Book-Content Search Service  Microsoft announced that it planned to join the move into online book searches with a new service called MSN Book Search. [C6.]    Amazon Earnings Fell in the Third Quarter  Amazon.com said its profit declined during the third quarter, partly as a result of a legal settlement, while sales of the latest Harry Potter book helped increase revenue by 27 percent. [C4.]    BellSouth Profit Rises Despite Hurricane Impact  The BellSouth Corporation said that profit rose 2.3 percent in the third quarter, though Hurricane Katrina pushed sales lower. BellSouth earned $817 million, or 44 cents a share, in the quarter as more customers signed up for high-speed data lines. Including its 40 percent share of Cingular Wireless and without some one-time items, BellSouth earned 46 cents a share, in line with estimates. [C6.]    Infinity Announces Array of Replacements for Stern  Infinity Broadcasting plans to replace Howard Stern with an array of radio hosts for different regions of the country, most notably David Lee Roth, the former lead singer of Van Halen, and the comedian Adam Carolla. [E1.]    Major Stock Indicators Post Declines  The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 2.84 points, to 1,196.54. The Nasdaq composite index lost 6.38 points, to 2,109.45. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 7.13 points, to 10,377.87. [C10.]    BBC to Open Operation in the Middle East  The BBC World Service said that it would shut down 10 of its foreign-language broadcasts, most of them serving Eastern Europe, and open an Arab-language television news and information service in the Middle East. [A6.]    First-Time Buyers Turn to Commercial Property  Real estate executives say they have seen an increase in the number of first-time buyers who are entering the commercial market. Square Feet. [C8.]

headline: Briefly: Activist gets jail term for 'picking quarrels'
TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Recent Sale  $15.25 million    180-188 Mount Airy Road  Basking Ridge, N.J.    The sale involves two office buildings, encompassing 104,000 square feet, which are 58 percent leased, on an 11-acre site with a pond.    Buyer: Pitcairn Properties Inc.  Seller: Transwestern Greenbrook L.L.C.  Broker: CB Richard Ellis    Recent Lease  $30/square foot  $357,840 approximate annual rent    501 Merritt 7  Norwalk, Conn.    A company based in Des Moines has signed a five-year lease for 11,928 square feet in one of six buildings in Merritt 7 Corporate Park. Owner: 830 West L.L.C.  Broker: ABS Partners Real Estate L.L.C. and Helmsley-Spear Inc.

headline: Fox Reaches Five-Year Deal With Star of 'American Idol'
abstract: The Fox network solved its most worrisome problem yesterday, announcing that it had signed its most important star, Simon Cowell of ''American Idol,'' to a five-year contract. The deal means that Fox will keep intact the elements of the show, which has been the most powerful draw in television for the last two years.     The deal was not completed easily. Negotiating against the deadline of a lawsuit filed in Britain against Mr. Cowell by the originator of ''Idol,'' Simon Fuller, the parties had to postpone opening arguments in the trial to pursue the settlement.

headline: Underlying quick fixes, a lack of how-to
Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
abstract: Recent Sale  $119.5 million  Metropolitan Center  Route 3  East Rutherford, N.J.  This 15-story 423,000-square-foot building, across Route 3 from Giants Stadium, is near the Xanadu shopping center, now under construction, and a planned rail spur.  Buyer: ING Clarion  Seller: CB Richard Ellis Investors  Buyer's broker: Michael O'Connor, ING Clarion  Seller's broker: Cushman & Wakefield Metropolitan Area Capital Markets Group    Recent Lease  $30/sq. ft.  Approximate annual rent $67,500  102 Franklin Street  Manhattan  An architectural firm has leased a 2,250-square-foot floor in this TriBeCa building.  Tenant: StudioMDA  Landlord: Kyle Wittels  Tenant's Broker: Michelle Stone, Sinvin Realty    For Sale  $10.995 million  80 Delancey Street (at Orchard)  Manhattan  This six-story walk-up building on the Lower East Side has 24 apartments and 6 stores.  Owner: ERA Realty  Broker: Peter J. DeCheser and Gina Berger, Massey Knakal   JOHN HOLUSHA

headline: Brazil Opens Former Dictatorship's Files, a Bit
abstract: Bowing to domestic and international pressure, the Brazilian government has begun releasing intelligence files compiled by the former military dictatorship on government opponents, including victims of torture and those who disappeared.      A preliminary list of people whose activities were monitored by military intelligence during the dictatorship, which ruled from 1964 to 1985, has already been made public. As of Jan. 1, those people will be allowed to examine their own files, which are being transferred from military control to the National Archives.

headline: British Agent Tells (a Bit) of Years Undercover in Ulster
abstract: Denis Donaldson, prominent Irish Repubican movement member who served in prison with Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams and Bobby Sands, hunger striker who died in 1981, reveals that he became British double agent in early 1980's; details of his recruitment are unclear; his work as agent coincided with critical period when armed campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland was giving way to political drive by Sinn Fein; Donaldson says he was forced to reveal his double life after being told he was about to be exposed in newspaper report; he is said to be in hiding in Irish Republic; photos (M)

headline: Briefly: Ohio expands rights on child visitation
Mountain of gold leaves a river of waste
Internet Matchmaking: Those Offering Help and Those Needing It
abstract: WHERE can I deliver a truckload of clothing?''     Tom Wales, a stock trader in Ridgewood, N.J., was oozing frustration when he posted this plea on Sept. 13 on the New Orleans site of craigslist.org, which offers free access to local classifieds and discussion forums.

headline: U.N. Puts Children in Forefront of AIDS Effort
abstract: Only one in 20 of the H.I.V.-infected children worldwide who need life-prolonging drugs gets them. Only one out of 100 gets a cheap antibiotic that can nearly halve death rates from secondary infections like diarrhea and malaria. Less than one in 10 mothers infected with the H.I.V. virus are given drugs that can stop transmission to their babies.     Every minute of every day a child dies of an AIDS-related illness.

headline: Infighting stalls efforts to update UN Council
Tories Elect Young Moderate as New Opposition Leader
abstract: In a triumph of svelte youth over rugged experience, Britain's opposition Conservatives chose David Cameron today as their new leader.

headline: Iran leader renews furor, calling Holocaust a 'myth'
3 Killed by Suicide Bomber at Checkpoint in the West Bank
abstract: Two Palestinian civilians and an Israeli Army officer were killed Thursday when a Palestinian suicide bomber, stopped at a checkpoint near Tulkarm, in the West Bank, blew himself up.     At least five Palestinian civilians and three Israeli soldiers were wounded, one of them seriously.

headline: Letter from China: Hollywood, you have a problem with Asians
DuPont settles toxin case
Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.     At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.85 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 4.15 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 3.43 percent.

headline: Internet Sales Show Big Gains Over Holidays
abstract: Online retailers, whose growth was expected to level off after a decade of dizzying gains, experienced a stellar holiday season, according to two preliminary reports released yesterday, as traditional stores like Wal-Mart and Target cemented their place on the Web.     Consumer spending online reached $18.1 billion in November and December, a 25 percent increase over 2004, according to the research firm ComScore Networks.

headline: On Advertising: U.K. ad unit takes heat, as usual
Burson-Marsteller Appoints Political Consultant as Chief
abstract: Mark Penn, the well-known political consultant and pollster, was named yesterday as the worldwide chief executive of Burson-Marsteller, the public relations and public affairs agency in New York that is part of the Young & Rubicam Brands division of the WPP Group. He succeeds Thomas R. Nides, who left in July to join Morgan Stanley as chief administrative officer.

headline: Old school ties bind 3 key Iraqi candidates
Iraqi leaders reach last-minute deal on charter revision
Tornado hits Indiana and Kentucky
Iraqi Officials Declare Charter Has Been Passed
abstract: Iraqi electoral officials anounce that voters passed new constitution, paving way for parliamentary elections in December; say that although 79 percent of voters approved constitution in referendum, three provinces voted against it, two of them by two-thirds majority; under election rules, if two-thirds of voters in each of three provinces had voted against constitution, it would have failed; overall vote is sharply divided along ethnic and sectarian lines: Shiites and Kurds, who make up about 80 percent of population, generally supported document; map shows referendum results in various provinces (L)

headline: Zucker Named Chief of NBC; Seen as Heir to Chairman
abstract: NBC elevated Jeff Zucker, one of the fastest-rising executives in the network's history, to chief executive of the NBC Universal Television Group yesterday, establishing him as the likely successor to NBC's longtime leader, Bob Wright.     The move was announced by Mr. Wright, who remains chairman of NBC Universal as well as vice chairman of NBC's parent, General Electric, and it realigns NBC management, with Mr. Zucker at the top.

headline: London Stock Exchange Rejects Takeover Offer
abstract: The London Stock Exchange rejected as ''derisory'' a ¬£1.48 billion ($2.6 billion) preliminary bid from Macquarie Bank on Friday, but will be required nonetheless to open its books to its suitor.      Macquarie, based in Sydney, Australia, said it had offered 580 pence a share for the London Exchange, 5 percent less than its closing price of 612 pence a share on Thursday.

headline: Internet challenges television networks
The Day After Christmas, Shoppers Take a Holiday
abstract: Many retailers hoping for big finish to holiday season instead had lighter-than-expected crowds over long Christmas weekend, leaving stores to rely heavily on next few days to pump up December sales; few shoppers are reported in some major cities day after Christmas; photo (M)

headline: Is Bird Flu Drug Really So Vexing? Debating the Difficulty of Tamiflu
abstract: If a bird flu pandemic breaks out, the world's ability to fight back may come down to an ancient Chinese cooking spice -- or the perseverance of people like Professor Frost.      The Chinese spice, star anise, provides the starting material for the manufacture of the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu, which is expected to be the first line of defense in a pandemic.

headline: An Actress Pardons (and Poses for the Cover)
abstract: Catherine Zeta-Jones appears on Glamour magazine's December cover, apparently having forgiven magazine for unauthorized cover photo and bogus interview in 2001 (S)

headline: EU pushes to open defense market
Rove testifies a 4th time
For Tiny Music Players, a Larger Set of Headphones
abstract: Many people find that the earbuds that come with most personal music players are less than ideal. The buds tend to fall out of the ear and, in some cases, the sound is poor. Some earbud wires also fray easily. So it's not surprising that replacement headphones for portable music players are expected to be popular gifts in the holiday season, according to a survey by the Consumer Electronics Association.      Ultrasone, a German headphone manufacturer, is entering the American consumer market with its iCans headsets for iPods, MP3 players and other portable sound devices. Ultrasone says that the headsets, which are priced at about $130, reduce the pressure on the eardrum by as much as 40 percent compared with earbuds. The sets accomplish that by directing the sound just outside the inner part of the ear, where most sound is processed.

headline: Swiss Voters Approve Ban on Genetically Altered Crops
abstract: Swiss voters approve five-year ban on farming of genetically modified crops, underscoring problems facing European Commission and biotech companies like Syngenta, Bayer and Monsanto as they try to overcome consumer doubts about safety (M)

headline: Iran Backs Off From Direct Threat to Israel
abstract: Iran's Foreign Ministry released a statement on Saturday backing away from direct threats to Israel, even as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice harshly rebuked the Iranian president for his hostile comments.      On Wednesday, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad said in an address to 4,000 students in Tehran that ''Israel must be wiped off the map.''

headline: Iraq's Lethal Traffic: Warning! Anarchy Ahead
abstract: It was Monday morning in one of the world's most dangerous cities, and already the traffic was causing a peculiar, decidedly nonmechanical sort of breakdown.     ''We are suffering psychologically from this,'' said Bessam Abdel Khalid, a 24-year-old minivan driver, staring dully through the windshield at the crush of cars idling in a frustrated mass near Baghdad University.

headline: Surfing for a Pup? Homework Comes First
abstract: AFTER waiting more than a year, September Morn of Shelton, Wash., recently received her American Eskimo puppy from a breeder she found online.      ''I consider this breeder a personal friend now, after our many, mostly e-mail, interactions,'' said Ms. Morn, a professional dog trainer. ''We've shared joys and sorrows, hopes and worries, and news of our dog families. And if it weren't for the Internet, I might never have found her.''

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: A U.S. Court Date on BlackBerry
abstract: Supreme Court, in response to request from Canada's Research in Motion, company that provides BlackBerry wireless service, gives NTP, patent holding company, until Oct 26 to show why wireless service should not be shut down in US; American appeals court recently upheld patent infringement case NTP brought against Research in Motion, and NTP plans to ask lower court to activate injunction it was granted two years ago against BlackBerry service; Research in Motion will ask to have $450 million settlement two companies reached earlier in year enforced by court (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Threat To Bar Campaigning On Charter
abstract: With a hotly contested referendum looming, the Electoral Commission blamed both supporters and opponents of the government's draft constitution for instigating recent rioting that has left 4 people dead and more than 30 injured. Gabriel Mukele, the vice chairman of the commission, which is overseeing the Nov. 21 polling, said both sides would be forbidden to campaign if there were any more violent clashes. President Mwai Kibaki is pushing to revise the country's colonial-era Constitution, but opponents, including some of his own ministers, say his proposal does not go far enough in weakening the powers of the presidency.   Marc Lacey (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inquiry Into 1985 Air India Bombing
abstract: The Canadian government will have the former Ontario premier, Bob Rae, conduct a policy-based inquiry into federal officials' role in the 1985 Air India bombing, which killed all 329 people on board. Flight 182, carrying mostly Canadian citizens traveling to India to visit relatives, blew up off the coast of Ireland and plunged into the Atlantic. A second attack on an Air India flight killed two baggage handlers at a Tokyo airport. The police said the bombings were revenge by Sikh extremists for the Indian government's storming of a Sikh shrine in India.    Cybele Sack (NYT)

headline: Currencies: Euro slides vs. dollar on Merkel worries
World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Shell Oil Pipeline Attacked
abstract: Nigeria put security forces in the Niger Delta on high alert after two explosions crippled oil production in the restive oil-rich region that makes Nigeria the world's eighth-largest producer of crude. Vandals attacked a Shell pipeline 30 miles west of Port Harcourt on Monday evening, causing an explosion that killed several people and forced the closing of an export terminal. Militant groups in the Niger Delta have attacked pipelines frequently in recent years, both to highlight the destitution in the Niger Delta despite the region's oil wealth and to steal oil and sell it on the black market.   LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Pope Meets Israel's President
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI and Israeli President Moshe Katsav meet at Vatican to discuss Roman Catholic Church's tax status in Israel and possible visit by Pope in 2006 (S)

headline: Peru withdraws its envoy to Japan
Book Report: Think small to think big
U.S. Troops and Insurgents Clash in Western Iraq
abstract: American troops fought street battles with insurgents in a desert village in western Iraq for a second day on Sunday.

headline: Fed chief warns of fuel cost 'drag'
Fatal strain of bird flu confirmed in Turkey
Canadian government toppled in no-confidence vote
Romania quarantinesvillage and kills birds
Palestinian Faction to Stop Firing Rockets Into Israel
abstract: The group Islamic Jihad said its pledge depended on a halt in Israeli airstrikes and other military operations against the Palestinian factions.

headline: Combative Saddam back in court
BP estimates damage by hurricanes at $700 million
Stocks: A rally on optimism for holiday spending
Medical Journal Criticizes Merck Over Vioxx Data
abstract: New England Journal of Medicine accuses Merck of misrepresenting results of crucial clinical trial of painkiller Vioxx to play down heart risks; Merck issues statement denying that it acted improperly; allegation could play key role in thousands of lawsuits that Merck faces over Vioxx, arthritis and pain drug; journal editor Gregory D Curfman is sharply critical of Merck for how it presented data from trial and says company did not disclose all it knew; move is considered extraordinary step (M)

headline: Entry Level:Away-from-home cellars for fine wines
Israel Is Easing Barrier Burden, but Palestinians Still See a Border
abstract: Israel's overhaul of its separation barrier along West Bank and Jerusalem, intended to ease burden on Palestinians and soften international criticism, is proving contentious; it is giving barrier feel of international border; construction project of 27 terminals will cost $500 million; Israeli officials say it will reduce tension, because civilian contracors will be hired to replace armed and ill-trained soldiers at checkpoints; say crossing time for people and goods will be cut from hours to minutes; many Palestinians see project as further proof of Israeli intention to create border, unilaterally, on occupied land, annexing territory without negotiation and undermining viability of future Palestinian state; say this is latest example of Prime Min Ariel Sharon's preference for imposed solutions, like last summer's Israeli pullout from Gaza; photos; maps (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Philips to Take a Charge on a Venture
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics, Europe's largest maker of consumer electronics, will take 460 million euros ($553 million) in fourth-quarter costs related to its unprofitable LG.Philips Displays venture. Philips will take charges of 290 million euros for ''accumulated negative difference in currency translation'' and about 128 million euros for writing off the remaining book value of the venture, the company said in a statement. A cash charge of 42 million euros linked to an existing guarantee provided to the venture's banks will also be taken. LG.Philips Displays, a maker of glass tubes for televisions and monitors, said earlier that it would write off about $725 million because of falling product prices and adverse business conditions. The venture has posted four consecutive quarterly losses, partly because consumers are switching to slimmer liquid-crystal or plasma display panels. LG Electronics will book combined charges of about 52 billion Korean won ($52 million) because of LG.Philips Displays during the fourth quarter, a spokeswoman, Judy Pae, said. The venture is separate from the LG.Philips LCD Company, a maker of L.C.D.'s used in computers and TV's, which is also jointly owned by LG Electronics and Philips.

headline: French protests draw droves nationwide
Israeli Airstrikes Kill Gaza Militant
abstract: The strikes came as the Israeli defense minister, Shaul Mofaz, expressed doubt that Israel could make peace "with the present leadership of the Palestinians."

headline: On Advertising:At Aegis, its time to tango
The EU budget face-off: Germany
A Hometown Favorite, Acquitted, Casts His Gaze at Hollywood
abstract: The entourage of Richard M. Scrushy is heading to Hollywood.      Lawyers for Mr. Scrushy, 52, the former chief executive of the HealthSouth Corporation, who was acquitted by a hometown jury in June on 36 federal counts including money laundering, securities fraud and conspiracy, have met with producers in recent weeks about making a feature-length film about Mr. Scrushy's trial.

headline: Prodi first in primary by landslide
Lawyer Denies Hollinger Fraud
abstract: Mark Kipnis, a former corporate counsel at Hollinger International, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges accusing him of helping Conrad M. Black steal $51.8 million from the company.     Mr. Kipnis, 58, entered the plea to each of nine counts of mail and wire fraud at a hearing in Federal District Court in Chicago, said Randall Samborn, a spokesman for the United States attorney's office there.

headline: Ford Reports Losing Money in 3rd Quarter
abstract: The quarter marks a turning point for the company, which unlike rival General Motors, had until now been profitable.

headline: Obituary: Shirley Horn, jazz singer and pianist
France arrests 3 more on terror links
6 top Paris hotels fined on pricing
Japan rally catches funds off balance
Private equity firm agrees to buy Hilfiger
Insurgent ambush northwest of Baghdad leaves 24 dead
World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Roadside Bomb Kills G.I.
abstract: An American serviceman and an Afghan soldier were killed in a roadside explosion in the unstable eastern province of Kunar, the United States military said in a statement. Two other American servicemen were wounded in the explosion near the provincial capital, Asadabad, during a combat patrol. Another American soldier died in a road accident in southern Afghanistan.    CARLOTTA GALL (NYT)

headline: OPEC talks open with China
Criticism spurs Britain to rethink EU budget
Root for $5-a-Gallon Gas
abstract: GASOLINE prices stubbornly hover near $2 a gallon, but $5 would be even better, writes Spencer Reiss in this month's Wired. The higher the price, he reasons, the more incentive there is to find alternatives.      ''For anyone with a fresh idea, expensive oil is as good as a subsidy -- with no political strings attached,'' he writes. ''Indeed, every extra penny you pay at the pump is an incentive for some aspiring energy mogul to find another fuel.''

headline: In mishaps at JAL, somesee corners being cut
Earnings: Cosmetics give a big lift
Google Earth: Too close for comfort?
Australian doctors win Nobel medicine prize
Tech Mania Takes Over the Toy Aisles
abstract: WHEN Michele Carr's family shops at Wal-Mart, her sons -- ages 10 and 13 -- never go to the toy department. ''We always go to the electronics section,'' said Ms. Carr, who lives in North Vancouver, British Columbia. ''They want to look at the latest games for PlayStation 2 and check out the MP3 players.''     Gadget mania has taken hold of older children, and the toy industry knows it. (The iPod was the top gift for 12-year-olds last year, some industry experts say.) To ensure that younger siblings do not abandon the toy section, manufacturers are filling the aisles with gadgets like two-way radios, mobile phones, portable digital video players, cameras, camcorders and hand-held games -- for children as young as 6 years old.

headline: EU expected to cut growth outlook
Bali attacks blamed on suicide bombers
Egyptian Opposition Leader, Echoing Iran, Calls Holocaust "Myth"
abstract: The leader of Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood issued a statement condemning America while declaring that the Holocaust was a "myth."

headline: DreamWorks Is Said to Get a Revised Offer
abstract: Hollywood loves a good mystery. And this fall, at least two studios are trying to figure out how much DreamWorks SKG, co-founded by the director Steven Spielberg, is worth.     On Friday, NBC Universal, a unit of General Electric, revised its offer for DreamWorks' live-action business, a month after the companies ended their talks, according to two people with knowledge of the bid.

headline: The Situation in France
abstract: Craig Smith, the European correspondent for The Times, is in Paris covering the unrest in France. Later today, while he continues to report on the situation, he will answer your questions about what is happening in the suburbs of Paris. Please e-mail your questions and include your name and location.

headline: Gazprom Becomes the Bear of Russia
abstract: Russia is demanding fivefold increase in price of gas supplied to Ukrain, change widely seen as payback for Kremlin-backed candidate in Ukaine's contested presidential election that was lost to Viktor A Yushchenko, pro-Western leader of Orange Revolution; at center of geopolitical game is Gazprom, Russia's natural gas monopoly, country's largest company and producer of third of world's supply of natural gas; Gazprom is powerful instrument of Russia's emerging foreign policy doctrine, which rests on energy exports in place of lost military might; Gazprom is at risk of appearing as tool of Russian government in conflict with Ukraine--used to punish pro-Western government in Eastern Europe--rather than as modern company that could claim to be attractive to institutional investors; photo (M)

headline: Allergan to Buy Inamed
abstract: Allergan, the maker of Botox, entered into a definitive agreement late Tuesday to buy the Inamed Corporation for $3.2 billion, wresting the breast-implant maker from the Medicis Pharmaceutical Corporation.     Allergan first came into the picture last month when it made a surprise bid for Inamed that topped the Medicis offer by $450 million and offered a larger cash component. Allergan said its offer was devised to cover the $90 million breakup fee to Medicis.

headline: PERK OF THE WEEK
abstract: Opening night of the International Fine Art and Antique Dealers Show last week -- a benefit for the Society of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center -- drew an impressive crowd to the Seventh Regiment Armory in Manhattan. In addition to notables including David and Julia Koch, there was Colleen Caslin, the recently appointed chief operating officer of Graff, the high-end jewelry store that sponsored the event with Bill Blass.     Ms. Caslin was resplendent in large diamond earrings, a wide diamond bracelet and a tank watch outlined in diamonds.

headline: Trading boom bolsters Deutsche Bank
French Engineer Is Latest Westerner Kidnapped in Iraq
abstract: Gunmen abduct French engineer Bernard Planche outside his home in upscale Mansour neighborhood of Baghdad, latest in wave of kidnappings of Westerners; photos; Planche worked for nongovernmental organization Aaccess, reportedly on sewage project (M)

headline: As Riots Continue in France, Chirac Vows to Restore Order
abstract: Rioters fired shotguns at police just hours after President Jacques Chirac called a special meeting to confront the violence.

headline: Filmmaker's murderer declares 'Islam's enemies' legitimate targets
Germany closes case on LSE bid
Angry Crowds Protest Delays in Reopening Kashmir Border
abstract: Pakistani officials report that protests marred partial opening of one of five planned crossing points along line of control dividing Pakistani- and Indian-administered portions of Kashmir; say men gathered on Pakistani side grew angry when officials blocked them from crossing (M)

headline: Bird flu experts skeptical of China's current figures
World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Ex-Police Chief Held In 1975 Kidnapping
abstract: Federal agents have arrested a second high-ranking former police official in connection with the kidnapping, torture and disappearance of a leftist leader in 1975. The former officer, Carlos Solana, who was head of the police in the northern state of Nuevo Laredo, was arrested on charges that he participated in the abduction of Jes√∫s Piedra Ibarra during the government's illegal crackdown on leftists. Mr. Piedra Ibarra's case became a cause c√©l√®bre largely because of the advocacy of his mother, Rosario Ibarra. The former chief of Mexico's secret police, Miguel Nazar Haro, was arrested in the case last year. Two other police officials are being sought.   JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Mideast: Accord Near On Relief Groups
abstract: The Palestinian Red Crescent and Israel's equivalent, the Magen David Adom, are expected to sign an agreement in Geneva next week, and the Swiss news media reported that it would be tantamount to formal mutual recognition by the two organizations. The Swiss Foreign Ministry, in a statement, said the agreement would be signed about one week before a conference, also in Geneva, that is expected to pave the way for Israel to join the Red Cross movement by approving an additional emblem, a red crystal, for use in Israel, in addition to the red cross or red crescent now in use.   John Tagliabue (NYT)

headline: Looking Out for No. 1 Before and After the Fire
abstract: ONE Sunday afternoon in March, my family and I drove up to our suburban Detroit home to find four fire trucks, two police cars and all our neighbors surrounding our house. It was the beginning of a financial, logistical and emotional ordeal that's still not over.     An electrical fire that started in our finished basement created smoke and soot that permeated everything in the house and asphyxiated our dog. Our home's infrastructure -- plumbing, heating and electrical systems as well as most of the wall board -- and almost all of our furnishings need to be replaced. We're living in a rental home nearby, and hope to move back into our restored home in the spring -- about a year after the fire.

headline: Three tetanus deaths, 17 cases reported in quake area
Boeing receives Chinese order for 150 jets
Drawing investors back to Africa
LOOKING AHEAD
abstract: HAPPY TIMES -- The economy's strong performance continues to surprise just about everybody. This week, the news came out that consumer confidence surged in November; that the economy grew at a revised 4.3 percent annual rate in the third quarter, the fastest pace in a year and a half; that retail sales were robust and the housing market remained reasonably healthy despite a lot of gloomy talk. On Tuesday, we can revisit some of those trends with the release of a major store-sales index, a retail-sales index, October factory orders and the ABC-Washington Post consumer-confidence index.    SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY SEMINAR -- Chip companies will announce breakthroughs and sages will impart wisdom at the three-day International Electron Devices Meeting that opens Monday in Washington. At the conference, sponsored by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Neil Gershenfeld, director of the Center for Bits and Atoms at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, will give a keynote speech on the relationship of digital bits and atoms.    SIGNUPNOW.EU -- The European Union's ''.eu'' regional domain name opens Wednesday for registration by businesses and government agencies, and a spokesman for the E.U. said several hundred thousand applications were expected to be filed in the first few days. For those that make the switch, the .eu affix will replace national domans like .es for spain, or the international .com. Registration for the general public begins on April 7. Separately, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, above, says he hopes to reach an agreement with the other E.U. members this week on cutting the bloc's 2007-13 budget, including reductions in agricultural subsidies.    NOBEL CEREMONIES -- The 2005 Nobel prizes will be distributed in Oslo and Stockholm on Saturday. The economics award went to two game-theory experts, Robert J. Aumann, 75, of the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and Thomas C. Schelling, 84, of the University of Maryland.

headline: In 3rd Round of Egyptian Vote, Police Kill Political Activist
abstract: Riot police blocked voters from getting to the polls in parliamentary elections, according to independent poll watchers.

headline: Obituary: Hugh Sidey, 78, profiled U.S. presidents for Time across 4 decades
Cut Deals? Play Golf? He'll Just Do Both
abstract: What's a Goldman Sachs partner supposed to do after he retires at 38? Play golf, of course. But David M. Baum, who ran the mergers and acquisitions practice at Goldman at the height of merger mania in the late 1990's, can't seem to stop making deals, too. So, he's doing both.     Mr. Baum has gone on an acquisition spree to build a mini-publishing empire all about golf. So far, he has acquired two premium monthly golf newsletters, Golf Odyssey and The Golf Insider, which review golf courses and resorts worldwide. And he says he is not done with his buying binge. ''You can't take the merger guy out of the golfer,'' said Mr. Baum, who has shaved 10 strokes off his game since leaving Goldman.

headline: Catalonia Seeks Status as 'Nation'
abstract: Catalonia's parliament approved a plan that declares the northeastern region of seven million people a largely autonomous ''nation'' within Spain, setting the stage for a possible confrontation with the central government. The proposal calls for transferring an array of powers, like tax collection, away from the central government. It now goes to the national Parliament in Madrid, where passage is not being ruled out because of the Catalan government's strong ties with several parties there.    Renwick McLean (NYT)

headline: New British Law Allows Same-Sex Civil Partnerships
abstract: From Brighton to Birmingham and beyond, gay and lesbian couples began registering today for the first ceremonies later this month.

headline: West Bank town is proving ground for Hamas
'We're French,' but not 'real' French
The Trade-Offs in Zoning Trade-Offs
abstract: It has become common in New York City for real estate developers to offer public amenities in exchange for the right to put up buildings that are taller than the zoning ordinarily would allow or to garner public support for projects that might stir controversy. But those amenities -- parks, plazas or atriums, for example -- sometimes fail to live up to expectation, fall into disrepair and are occasionally scrapped altogether.      It was recently disclosed, for example, that the Forest City Ratner Companies will not open a rooftop park to the public -- as it originally announced -- as part of its proposed mixed-use development on Atlantic Avenue in downtown Brooklyn, which includes an arena for the New Jersey Nets basketball team, as well as 16 buildings. The omission of the park is a small change amid many others in this large-scale development, but it provided fodder for critics and renewed questions about relying on private developers to create public spaces.

headline: Relying on Computer, U.S. Seeks to Prove Iran's Nuclear Aims
abstract: In mid-July, senior American intelligence officials called the leaders of the international atomic inspection agency to the top of a skyscraper overlooking the Danube in Vienna and unveiled the contents of what they said was a stolen Iranian laptop computer.      The Americans flashed on a screen and spread over a conference table selections from more than a thousand pages of Iranian computer simulations and accounts of experiments, saying they showed a long effort to design a nuclear warhead, according to a half-dozen European and American participants in the meeting.

headline: For Europe's Sake, Spotting Moonshine Among Swans
abstract: Smuggling has thrived along Lithuania's borders ever since it regained its independence from Soviet Union in 1991; as Lithuanians strengthen their border checkpoints, smugglers turn to more creative tactics, including cars retrofitted with secret compartments to hide contraband and pipelines pumping moonshine; photo; map (M)

headline: End of English soccer's winning streak?
World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Chief Named at Barilla Pasta
abstract: Barilla Holding, the world's biggest pasta maker, has named Robert Singer to the post of chief executive to help expand the group's international operations. Mr. Singer, 54, will manage brands like Kamps, Harry's and Gran Milano that are part of the group, Barilla said. He will also be chief financial officer, succeeding Vittorio Ogliengo. ''Singer's new role will help Barilla Holding and its associated companies grow internationally,'' the chairman, Guido Barilla, said in the statement.

headline: Kaczynski Defeats Rival in Poland's Presidential Election
abstract: Lech Kaczynski of the conservative Law and Justice Party defeated his rightist rival, Donald Tusk, according to surveys of voters leaving the polls.

headline: FDA move pulls Glaxo shares down
Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,928 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:    ARNOLD, Daniel L., 27, Staff Sgt., Army National Guard; Montrose, Pa.; 28th Infantry Division.    BENFORD, Jason A., 30, Staff Sgt., Army; Toledo, Ohio; Third Infantry Division.    BROWN, Oliver J., 19, Pfc., Army National Guard; Carbondale, Pa.; 28th Infantry Division.    JACOBSON, Elizabeth N., 21, Airman First Class, Air Force; Riviera Beach, Fla.; 17th Security Forces Squadron.    MORIN, Steve Jr., 34, Sgt., Army National Guard; Arlington, Tex.; 36th Infantry Division.    PUGLIESE, George A., 39, Staff Sgt., Army National Guard; Carbondale, Pa.; 28th Infantry Division.    SLEBODNIK, Eric W., 21, Sgt., Army National Guard; Greenfield Township, Pa.; 28th Infantry Division.    WIEGAND, Lee A., 20, Specialist, Army National Guard; Hallstead, Pa.; 28th Infantry Division.

headline: Pharmacies Endorse Crackdown on Fraud
abstract: Drugstore.com, KwikMed.com and other legitimate online drug marketers welcome government shutdown of 4,600 illegal online pharmacy sites and arrest of 18 people who ran them; believe reputation of legitimate online pharmacies has been undermined by rogues, which purport to offer prescriptions to customers who cannot or will not get prescriptions from their own doctors and who typically pay $400 for drugs that would have cost $40 with legal prescription; only about 8 percent of America's 150 million-drug users have bought their medications online so far this year, down from 8.6 percent in 2004; photo (M)

headline: Suit seeks to block copy of Nexium
U.S. Is Urged to Raise Rates
abstract: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said yesterday that the Federal Reserve should keep raising interest rates but urged central banks in Europe and Japan to keep rates low to foster economic growth.      Strong demand and rising prices in the United States will push the Fed to increase its benchmark rate to 4.75 percent, the organization said in its semiannual economic outlook. The absence of an inflation threat means the European Central Bank and the Bank of Japan should leave rates unchanged, it said.

headline: Imports trim trade surplus in Japan
The Village Voice, Pushing 50, Prepares to Be Sold to a Chain of Weeklies
abstract: Village Voice Media is selling Voice and five other alternative newspapers to New Times Media, creating chain of 17 free weekly newspapers around the country with combined circulation of 1.8 million; no money is changing hands, but merger is valued at about $400 million; merged company will continue to use name Village Voice Media; deal raises questions about whether Voice and its siblings can preserve their anti-establishment roots as part of growing corporation and whether conglomeration will give chain editorial and financial muscle to compete against free competitors, both online and in print; deal must be submitted to Justice Department under 2003 consent decree; chronology of Village Voice since founding in 1955; photo (M)

headline: Song prices online face an inquiry
Slow Progress in Bali Inquiry Hints at Wilier Terror Groups
abstract: The investigation into the Bali bombings nearly a month ago has yet to make any breakthroughs, leaving counterterrorism officials and experts with an edgy sense that the terrorist network in Southeast Asia has become smarter and more sophisticated, both in carrying out attacks and in avoiding detection.     Compounding the difficulties of the investigation, Indonesian officials and Western security specialists now say that preparations for the attack were made in the Philippines; these included training the suicide bombers and assembling the backpack bombs, which had detonation wires sown into the straps.

headline: Experts Doubt Bird Flu Tallies From China And Elsewhere
abstract: China reports its first two human deaths from bird flu, while international health specialists warn that tallies from China and elsewhere greatly underestimate problem; scientists are mystified by low number of cases in humans reported in China, where bird flu problem is so severe that country plans to vaccinate 14.2 billion chickens, geese and ducks; note far smaller countries with less severe bird flu outbreaks have reported many more human cases; Vietnam has reported 91 cases of bird flu in humans, with 41 deaths (M)

headline: Raid kills 8 in sect in Pakistan
Six American soldiers killed in Iraq
A Coffee Themeland, Temporary by Design
abstract: THE new Galleria Illy store in Manhattan is not expected to turn a profit, and it will be gone by Christmas. But its creators hope that the impact of what is essentially a three-dimensional advertisement for Illy, the Italian coffee, will linger far longer than a caffeine buzz.     Situated on West Broadway in SoHo, in a 3,500-square-foot, two-story space formerly occupied by Dom New York, an eccentric housewares store, Galleria Illy is a sort of coffee themeland. It is divided into an art gallery, library, classroom and espresso bar. Nothing beyond desserts and coffee drinks -- including a $2 espresso and a $5 cappuccino -- can be bought for immediate gratification, though many products, including the company's distinctive vacuum-packed canisters of coffee, can be ordered from computer kiosks in the store.

headline: China plans public offerings for state-run railroads
New Viacom shares trade before the company splits
A Solid but Not Spectacular Finish for Holiday Spending
abstract: Visa USA said yesterday that purchases using its credit cards rose 21 percent in the week before Christmas, a sharp increase that suggested a solid -- though by no means extraordinary -- end to the holiday shopping season.      Visa cardholders spent $13.1 billion during the week that ended Sunday, largely at electronics and home furnishing retailers, the credit and debit card company said. Online spending, a separate category, rose 48.4 percent, to $2.7 billion.

headline: Ex-Kazakh Official Who Made a Threat Found Slain
abstract: Zamanbek K Nurkadilov, former minister in government of Pres Nursultan A Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan, is found shot to death three weeks before presidential election, after saying he would speak publicly about high-level corruption (M)

headline: China Acts Swiftly to Stem Anxiety Over Avian Flu
abstract: BEIJING, Oct. 27 - Anxiety over avian influenza escalated in China today as health officials investigated whether it caused the recent death of a 12-year-old girl. But by early evening, state media reported that the girl had died of pneumonia.

headline: Conduct a Search, Make a Donation
