abstract: BILL GATES made news earlier this month when he said Microsoft's MSN search engine might give away cash or software to get people to use the site. Actually, Yahoo and Google are already exploring that ground, although they are relying on other companies to do it for them.     Like many other Web sites, a pair of online newcomers, Blingo and GoodSearch, license search technology from Google and Yahoo and earn a commission from the major search companies for any ads visitors click on when they are on Blingo.com or GoodSearch.com. (Those ads are, like the search results, generated by Google and Yahoo.) Unlike other sites, though, both Blingo and GoodSearch give away portions of their revenue -- as prizes or as donations to the users' favorite charities.

headline: EU compromise on chemical bill
TechBrief: Cisco has big plans for India
Blair cautious on Iraq pullout
Egyptian Vote Again Marred by Intimidation
abstract: Egypt's parliamentary elections were marred by new charges of violence and government-sponsored intimidation as voters went to the polls Saturday in a runoff that held the prospect of candidates loyal to the banned Muslim Brotherhood adding to their representation, poll monitors said.     Though the streets were more subdued on Saturday than when the second round of voting began 10 days ago, when men attacked voters in Alexandria with knives and machetes, hundreds of Muslim Brotherhood supporters were reportedly arrested, and there were many allegations of voting irregularities.

headline: Cisco warns on revenue as options hurt profit
Aid groups and nations move fast to help out
Hitting the high end: $20,000 DVD player
Kabul suicide bombers target NATO
Free-for-all over generic drugs in Europe
World Briefings: Asia, Europe, Americas
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Israel saves hang glider who landed in Lebanon
Water Crisis Shows China's Pollution Risks
abstract: The Chinese government's decision to cut potentially contaminated supplies of fresh water to a major city has highlighted the threat that industrial pollution poses to public health and economic development across the nation.     Almost four million people in Harbin in northeastern China are expected to be without running water until late Saturday after a chemical plant explosion on Nov. 13 contaminated the upper reaches of the nearby Songhua River with toxic benzene.

headline: U.S. visit to China will focus on yuan
Text of Iraq's draft constitution
Obituary: Management guru Peter F. Drucker dies
World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: U.S. Opens Southern Consulate
abstract: The United States opened a consulate in Juba, the primitive, hardscrabble town that is the capital of Southern Sudan. Robert B. Zoellick, the deputy secretary of state, officiated. The United States helped broker the peace agreement this year that ended a 21-year civil war between the mainly Muslim north and the Christian and animist south. It calls for power sharing, and Mr. Zoellick has been pushing the Sudanese government to implement its terms. Officials said the new consulate was intended to demonstrate that the United States will remain engaged. A senior official said two diplomats had so far applied to be consul general in Juba, where there is no indoor plumbing.   Joel Brinkley (NYT)

headline: PERKS AHOY!
abstract: Companies like Home Depot have long required their directors to visit company stores regularly and report back on their experiences. Now the Carnival Corporation, the cruise giant, has instituted a similar -- presumably far less arduous -- program for nonemployee directors and retired directors.      Under the company's ''Cruise Benefit Policy,'' which it disclosed in a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, directors are allowed to take up to two cruises a year for a total of 14 days at a bargain rate of $35 a night.

headline: Cellphone and TV firms set to merge
German hostage released in Iraq
Aung San Suu Kyi to be detained another year
German road clears for grand coalition
World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Jailed Opponent To Challege President
abstract: Ugandan government rules that opposition leader Kizza Besigye can challenge President Yoweri Museveni in 2006 presidential election despite fact that he is currently serving prison sentence for treason and other charges (S)

headline: Novartis considers building in U.S.
British Ruling Expected Wednesday in Lipitor Suit
abstract: A British court is expected to issue a ruling Wednesday in a case brought by an Indian generic drug maker, Ranbaxy Laboratories, against Pfizer over Pfizer's patents for the cholesterol drug Lipitor.      Ranbaxy is challenging Pfizer over two Lipitor patents registered in Britain. The Indian company is also seeking to invalidate the patents in the United States, in a case that is expected to be heard by year-end.

headline: Balance Sheet: A little protection
Antitrust suit accuses Exxon and BP
Briefly:Bomb attacks prompt demands for security
A Tale of Two Streets
abstract: THE neighborhood gang I was in growing up on Dyckman Street in Manhattan wasn't like your jailhouse types with the tattoos, everybody shooting each other. While it wasn't uncommon for somebody to carry a knife, the fights were street fights, not knife fights. We had names like the Tiny Tots or the Redskins, like the football team.      I got beat up once by my group for stupidity. When I was 12, I asked my mother where babies were born. She told me God came down from heaven and planted a seed under a woman's heart and it took nine months to grow and came out of the stomach.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Johnson & Johnson Threatens to Abandon Its Plan to Acquire Guidant for $25.4 Billion  Johnson & Johnson threatened to abandon its plan to acquire the Guidant Corporation, a troubled heart device maker, setting the stage for a financial and legal confrontation over the $25.4 billion deal. [Page A1.]    Johnson & Johnson's stumble in the purchase of Guidant illustrates the perils of designing a corporate strategy around acquisitions. Market Place. [C1.]    Rule Change Would Allow Foreign Investment in Airlines  The Bush administration is proposing to allow foreign airlines and other foreign investors to control the management of airlines based in the United States, a move intended to attract capital to hard-pressed carriers. Jeff Shane, a Transportation Department official, said the proposed change could have a profound impact on the airline business, both here and abroad, by lowering barriers to global investment. [C11.]    Novartis Would Consider Building a U.S. Vaccine Plant  The chief executive of the Swiss drug company Novartis, Dr. Daniel L. Vasella, left, said the company would consider building a vaccine production plant in the United States amid concern that its deal for the Chiron Corporation would leave the United States overly reliant on foreign companies for flu vaccine supplies. Novartis won approval this week from independent directors of Chiron, the only major United States producer of flu vaccines, to buy the 58 percent of the company that it does not already own for $5.1 billion. [C4.]    The Bush administration's long-awaited plan to deal with the threat of pandemic flu received a mixed reception on Capitol Hill as senators chided top health officials for taking too long and questioned spending priorities. [A20.]    Time Warner Posts Profit and Plans Share Purchase  The media conglomerate Time Warner announced improved earnings and said it would buy back $12.5 billion worth of its shares in the wake of criticism from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn. [C3.]    Cablevision Takes a Step Toward a $3 Billion Payout  The Cablevision Systems Corporation said its board had authorized management to prepare to pay a $3 billion dividend that the Dolan family, which controls the company, had proposed last week. The dividend would pay the Dolan family more than $650 million. [C3.]    CNN Names a New Prime-Time News Anchor  CNN ousted its longtime prime-time anchor, Aaron Brown, in favor of Anderson Cooper, who received extensive media attention in the wake of his coverage of Hurricane Katrina. [C3.]    Google Completes a Step in Expanding Its Print Database  Google said it had completed the first major expansion of its Google Print database of searchable books, adding the full text of more than 10,000 works that are no longer under copyright, culled from the collections of four research libraries. [C11.]    Deutsche Telekom to Cut 19,000 German Jobs  Deutsche Telekom, the largest phone company in Europe, said it would cut 19,000 jobs from its German payroll over the next three years as it struggles to cope with changes in the telecommunications sector. [C4.]    Nortel Reports a Smaller Loss as Internet Sales Rise  Nortel Networks said that it narrowed its third-quarter loss to $105 million, from $259 million, helped by higher sales of Internet-related products. [C5.]    Mercury Interactive Executives Resign in Options Inquiry  The chief executive and two other top executives of the Mercury Interactive Corporation resigned amid a widening investigation into the pricing of employee stock options. In a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mercury, a large provider of software for monitoring Web sites, said an internal investigation found at least 49 instances in which the stated date of a Mercury stock option grant was different from the date on which the option appears to have actually been granted. Shares in Mercury fell 27 percent. [C5.]    Stocks Rise after Time Warner Posts Strong Profit  Stocks were higher on strong earnings from Time Warner and other companies. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 65.96 points, to 10,472.73; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 12 points, to 1,214.76; the Nasdaq composite index rose 30.26 points, to 2,144.31. [C11.]    Wal-Mart Strengthens Its Control of a Japanese Affiliate  Wal-Mart Stores said it would extend its control of Seiyu, its ailing Japanese affiliate, by installing one of its top United States executives at the helm. [C4.]    Music Entrepreneur Drops Radio Promotion Deals  Jeff McClusky, a music entrepreneur who emerged as an influential behind-the-scenes player in the 1990's by devising a technique to curry favor with radio programmers while sidestepping laws against payola, said he is dumping the business model he pioneered. [C18.]

headline: A global shortage of tools for the oil industry
Prodding or Pleading, Charities Hit Jackpots
abstract: Bill Gates is no slouch in the charitable-giving department. Just last week, the foundation he founded with his wife, Melinda Gates, said it would donate $258 million to eradicate malaria, which kills 2,000 African children a day. All told, Mr. Gates has given away 37 percent of his vast fortune, Forbes magazine estimated last year.     At a global health conference in New York last week, however, he shied away from Ted Turner's exhortations of the late 1990's to other billionaires -- including Mr. Gates -- to share their wealth. Mr. Gates told the conference, sponsored by Time magazine, that he had ''to give credit to Ted Turner, who is willing to speak out and give wealthy people a hard time.'' But, he added, he didn't think that publicly haranguing people was the most effective approach. ''There's got to be a way to do it that people feel they came to it freely and wanted to do it,'' he said.

headline: Critics assail Hong Kong plan
Australian leader puts nation on terror alert
Germans agree on coalition
World Businesss Briefing | Europe: Farm Ministers Oppose Cuts in Sugar Aid
abstract: Plans by the European Union to phase out subsidies to sugar farmers and cut the price of sugar 39 percent met with resistance at a meeting of farm ministers yesterday. The Netherlands, Finland and Poland were quick to demand changes to a new proposal presented by the secretary of state for the environment, food and rural affairs, Margaret Beckett of Britain. She stuck to European Commission plans that aim for prices to fall 39 percent, but proposed that the measures be phased in over four years starting in 2006. The original proposal recommended the cut in prices be done over two years.

headline: Ex-chief of Banca Popolare is arrested
World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Rebels Kill 8 Policemen
abstract: Remnants of the Shining Path, a guerrilla group largely wiped out in the 1990's, attacked a police patrol and killed eight officers, officials said. The attack in a remote coca-growing region in northeast Peru, was the second by rebels in a month. Authorities attribute the attacks to rebels working with drug traffickers.    JUAN FORERO (NYT)

headline: Stent vs. Scalpel
abstract: Carotid Stenting's seeming ease and its growing popularity have some experts worrying that too many doctors and patients, spurred on by medical device makers, may embrace procedure without fully understanding that it is generally as risky as surgery, and potientially riskier in some cases; analysts estimate that sales of carotid stents, which cost around $3,000 each, have not yet topped $100 million; but some envision $1 billion market for devices within decade, not counting doctor's fees; US spends about $2 billion annually on surgical treatment of carotid blockages; both surgery and carotid stening procedures cost about $10,000 to $15,000; prominent skeptics include Dr Mark J Alberts, professor of neurology at Northwestern University Medical School; he cites clinical study showing sroke and death rates of more than 10 percent within one year among those getting stents--not much different from results in same study for surgery; Dr John J Ricotta, chairman of surgery at Stony Brook University Hospital, says that in most cases he would still probably prefer surgery to stenting; diagram; photos (M)

headline: Police Fire on Protesters in China, Killing Several
abstract: Riot policemen in Guangdong Province, China, fatally shoot at least four protesters as simmering dispute over land use turns into violent confrontation; incident occurs in coastal village of Dongzhou as angry residents try to prevent construction of wind-powered electricity plant (M)

headline: Briefly: Guidant board agrees to discuss rival offer
HOLIDAY BONUS
abstract: Corporate catch phrases and political slogans are often hard to tell apart. Can you match the following entities and buzzwords?    1. Way Forward  2. A New Beginning  3. Plan for Victory  4. Manifesto for Growth    A. Coca-Cola  B. Ford Motor Company  C. President Bush  D. Angela Merkel, the German chancellor    Answers: 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A    Floyd Norris

headline: Fish shares fly on avian flu scare
Monitor Group Says Team Will Review Iraq's Voting Results
abstract: An international elections monitoring group that gave a preliminary endorsement to Iraq's parliamentary vote two weeks ago has agreed to send observers back into Iraq to investigate allegations by Sunni Arab and secular Shiite parties that widespread vote-rigging tainted the results.     The International Mission for Iraqi Elections, a Jordan-based monitor, said it would dispatch two investigators from the League of Arab States and one from Canada and one from a European nation. The group previously said that based on early indications, the Dec. 15 election appeared to have ''generally met international standards.''

headline: Have Recessions Absolutely, Positively Become Less Painful?
abstract: The nearly empty Airbus 310 was coasting through the Alabama night sky when a message flashed in the cockpit. ''DIVERT,'' it said, before using code to order the plane to land in Atlanta.     The pilot banked the jet to the east and a half-hour later it was on the ground. There, its cargo door opened up to a group of waiting FedEx employees who began filling it with 17,000 pounds of cargo.

headline: Iran announces plans for a second nuclear power plant
People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Mark Allen was named creative director at Mascola, New Haven, Conn., succeeding Chad Vorbrich, who moved to Florida and became the art director for Tampa Bay Metro magazine. Mr. Allen had most recently been creative director at the Gale Group, New York.

headline: Violence spreads beyond Paris
Thousands march in Hong Kong
NASD Awards $2 Million in Bias Case
abstract: Three former brokers at Merrill Lynch who complained of sexual discrimination were awarded more than $2 million by NASD, the regulatory organization for the brokerage industry, after two years of arbitration.      The award, decided on Nov. 10, was less than the $33 million originally sought by the brokers, and stemmed from an arbitration case filed in February 2003.

headline: Lure of Refco on rocks
ROW THAT PUMPKIN
abstract: Canada has a fairly porous southern border, but it does balk at having certain types slithering in: convicted felons must seek special permission. And just what kind of trip north seems so vital to the national interest that it just has to be made? Today, Martha Stewart, criminal record and all, will be allowed to join other celebrities and politicians in paddling giant hollowed-out pumpkins across a lake near Halifax, Nova Scotia, in the annual Pumpkin Regatta.   Hubert B. Herring

headline: Dutch Investigating High Toll in Fire That Killed Detainees
abstract: Dutch authorities are investigating why 11 people died in fire in detention center for drug smuggling suspects and illegal immigrants at Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam; officials say part of reason might have been difficulty in releasing prisoners quickly; note that buildings had no system for opening cells simultaneously; one detainee claims guards were slow to respond to their cries of alarm once fire erupted in one of cells; photo (M)

headline: Saudi Women Vote, and Run, in Business Chamber Election
abstract: Turnout is low as Saudi businesswomen vote for new board of directors for Jidda Chamber of Commerce and Industry; for first time, list of candidates includes women; voter eligibility is uncertain, but election is billed as major step forward for women in Saudi Arabia, especially after women were barred from polls earlier in year (M)

headline: Three Suicide Bombers Carried Out Bali Attacks
abstract: The coordinated terror attacks on crowded restaurants in Bali on Saturday killed 19 people and injured 90 others.

headline: Toll on Rise in Sri Lanka's 'Shadow War'
abstract: One could be forgiven for thinking Sri Lanka is at war.      On Tuesday, a land mine attack killed 11 soldiers on the northern Jaffna peninsula, and a policeman was killed patrolling the eastern town of Kalmunai. The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, ethnic separatists who want their own homeland in the north and east, were blamed for both attacks.

headline: It's Like Selling Meals by the Bite. And It May Work.
abstract: HOW much is this sentence -- the very one you are reading right now -- worth? Is it potentially more valuable than this entire column, this section, or the entire newspaper itself? This is not a play for a raise or a plug for the genius of my prose, but a riff on the latest mania in media-land: finding new ways to be paid for old material. Nearly every day, it seems, a new business strategy emerges that on its face may sound not only counterintuitive but also absurd. Then consumers start to buy it, and you can only say, ''Who knew?''     The ultimate example of this is the ring tone -- the grating, pulsing rendition of the Macarena or an old Whitesnake song that has replaced the annoying blaring ring on the cellphone of the person sitting next to you on the bus. When media companies of every stripe are facing increased competition and rising costs for programming and marketing, here is a product that consumers love -- and that simply reuses a fragment of existing recordings.

headline: Europe's jungle of drug regulators
World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Antimissile System Tested
abstract: Israel conducted a successful test of its Arrow missile defense system, shooting down an incoming missile intended to simulate Iran's long-range Shahab-3.    Greg Myre (NYT)

headline: Putin wants Russia to assist its weapons exporters
Currencies: Higher U.S. rates give a lift to dollar
Merck reorganizationto cut 300 jobs in Japan
Scandal Forces Brazil's Top Party to Regroup
abstract: Until a few months ago, Brazil's governing Workers' Party was seen as Latin America's most successful example of a political movement on the hard left migrating toward moderate social democracy. Now, stained by the biggest corruption scandal in the country's history, the party is frantically trying to regroup and head off a crushing defeat at the polls next year.     But the choices confronting the party's 800,000 registered members, who elect a new party president on Sunday, are unpalatable. They can either vote to reconfirm the existing scandal-tainted leadership or empower a reform slate that claims to be morally pure but is also calling for a return to economic policies that voters have repeatedly rejected.

headline: Anti-Malaria Donation
abstract: Bill Gates announces that Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation will donate $258 million to research on malaria, which kills 2,000 African children each day (S)

headline: Weimar Journal; In the Ashes of a German Past, a Vision of Europe's Future
abstract: Fire that swept through famous library in Weimar, Germany, last year destroyed 30,000 books, manuscripts and irreplaceable, handwritten musical scores from 16th to 18th centuries; it led to renewed interest in redesigning Weimar as focal point of collections on German literature and culture; photos; map (M)

headline: Lexmark Halves Estimate and Shares Plunge
abstract: Lexmark International shares fall 28.6 percent after company warns that its earnings for third quarter will be half of what it had predicted; company says it lost market share after other manufacturers cut prices on low-end inkjet printers (M)

headline: Of Tabloids, Mega-Fame and Free P.R.
abstract: LAST week brought another media story that became a clich√© a long time ago: celebrity-obsessed magazine publishes a salacious scoop about starlet, starlet denies, demands retraction and then sues.     The name involved -- Britney Spears -- might bring a little heat to the story, but the allegation from US Weekly on Oct. 17 that she and her husband, Kevin Federline, made a sex tape might prompt a yawn. I mean, who hasn't?

headline: Bomber Strikes Police Convoy in Northern Iraq
abstract: Suicide car bomber plows into convoy of police vehicles in northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk, killing at least 16 people and wounding at least 28 others (S)

headline: Merkel's husband, a scientist, shuns the political limelight
Iran allows UN inspectors to visit secret military site
Credit Suisse Queried on Refco
abstract: The Credit Suisse Group, an underwriter on the $583 million initial public offering of Refco Inc. in August, has been subpoenaed by regulators in connection with Refco's collapse into bankruptcy last month.     Credit Suisse said yesterday in a quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that its securities unit received subpoenas and requests for information from regulators. The Zurich-based company said it was cooperating with the requests.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Softwood Lumber Appeal
abstract: Jim Peterson, Canada's trade minister, said Canada would appeal a World Trade Organization ruling that upholds the method used by the United States to impose duties on softwood lumber from Canada. If the appeal succeeds, Canada would impose trade retaliation of $3.57 billion against the United States. The W.T.O. found that the United States altered the methods used to calculate the tariffs on Canadian softwood to make them comply with international trade rules. An earlier decision found that the United States had not acted in an ''objective and unbiased'' manner. Mr. Peterson repeated Canada's contention that any W.T.O. rulings were trumped by a Nafta ruling ordering that the tariffs be dropped. Rob Portman, the United States trade representative, said he hoped the decision would prompt a negotiated settlement.   Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: New York burdened by transit strike
Just When Consumers Feel Confident ... Wham
abstract: MURKY, often conflicting signals about the holiday shopping season and gyrating energy prices drained some of the fun out of good news about the economy and consumer confidence this week.     A week after General Motors announced its reorganization plan, another corporate giant -- Merck -- took significant steps to right itself. But as with G.M., analysts and investors were initially disappointed that the changes at Merck were not more sweeping and radical.    BARGAIN HUNTING -- Images of wild-eyed shoppers racing into stores before dawn on the day after Thanksgiving gave many people hope for a robust holiday shopping season, and many retailers did indeed say that business was good that day. But as time passed, the picture grew cloudier.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Production Up 8.5% in October
abstract: India's industrial output grew 8.5 percent in October from the previous year. Demand has been fueled by rising incomes and increased borrowing because of low interest rates. According to government data, manufacturing output, which accounts for more than three-quarters of production, rose 9.6 percent in the period. Analysts say that the growth may prompt the Reserve Bank of India, the country's central bank, to raise interest rates next month to control inflation. The economy is expected to grow more than 8 percent in the year ending in March.    Saritha Rai (NYT)

headline: Stocks: Alcoa bolsters Dow on rough day for Wall St.
New Finance Chief Is Named at Times
abstract: The New York Times has promoted Roland A. Caputo, vice president for circulation fulfillment services, to chief financial officer effective Jan. 1.     Mr. Caputo, 45, who will also remain a vice president, has been in his current role since 2001. He will succeed Liam J. Carlos, who has been named controller for the newspaper.

headline: Beijing reports 2 bird flu outbreaks
Texas Instruments Profit Up 12%
abstract: Texas Instrumentsd says third-quarter profit rose 12 percent, to $630 million; sales rise 10 percent, to $3.59 billion (S)

headline: 20 Reported Killed as Chinese Unrest Escalates
abstract: It is the largest known use of force by security forces against ordinary citizens since the 1989 killings around Tiananmen Square.

headline: On Advertising:A race to connect in India
BUSH PUSHES U.N. TO MOVE SWIFTLY ON SYRIA REPORT
abstract: President Bush and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice called Friday for urgent Security Council action in response to a United Nations report implicating high ranking members of the Syrian government in the assassination of Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.     Noting that ''the report strongly suggests that the politically motivated assassination could not have taken place without Syrian involvement,'' Mr. Bush, in Simi Valley, Calif., said the world must ''respond accordingly.''

headline: West fights for access to markets
In an old Celtic revival, spelling is a test of wills
Have Yoga Mat, Will Accessorize
abstract: CRITICS and the masses often have diverging tastes, which explains why moviegoers flock to sequels like ''Saw II'' rather than art-house revivals of ''La Petite Chartreuse.'' According to Maria Coler, this axiom also sheds light on why she has sold only about 500 of her BigHeart yoga mat carriers, despite laudatory coverage in magazines like New York, Shape and Palm Beach Illustrated.     ''The editors loved it, but I think it's more of an exercise in design at this point,'' said Ms. Coler, who owns an environmental consulting firm in Hoboken, N.J. ''The aesthetic belongs in some futuristic scenario. It's not an effortless style.''

headline: InBev selects Brazilian to revive Europe's flat beer market
Experts Give Scientists Road Map on Nanotechnology Research
abstract: Toxicologists studying whether materials being invented by nanotechnology researchers can be hazardous to humans have been given a "screening strategy" by a government-sponsored panel.

headline: Romania's 'look for yourself' offer
Syria Involved in Killing Lebanon's Ex-Premier, U.N. Report Says
abstract: The assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri of Lebanon was a carefully planned terrorist act organized by Syrian and Lebanese intelligence services.

headline: Johnson Sues Amgen Over Sales Practice
abstract: Johnson & Johnson files antitrust suit accusing rival Amgen of using illegal leverage to drive its drug, Procrit, out of market; says Amgen is bundling sales of its drugs in way that forces cancer clinics to buy Amgen's Aranesp at expense of Procrit; Amgen says allegations are not legitimate and company intend to fight accusation (M)

headline: Commerce Official Leaving Bush Team
abstract: Michael D Gallagher is resigning as head of National Telecommunications and Information Administration (S)

headline: Treatment of suspects is heated U.S. issue
Scrushy Is Indicted on Charges of Bribery
abstract: Richard M. Scrushy, the embattled founder of the HealthSouth hospital chain who was acquitted of fraud charges earlier this year, was indicted on new criminal charges yesterday in a 30-count indictment that accuses him of paying $500,000 in bribes to an Alabama state official.

headline: U.S. and EU must move, Lamy says
Soria Makti, 30, museum curator
Bush, on TV, Says Iraq Vote Won't End Violence
abstract: President Bush acknowledged Friday that the elections in Iraq were ''not going to stop violence'' there, and that ''we're behind'' on the training of capable Iraqi police forces.     Even so, in a lengthy interview with Jim Lehrer on the PBS program ''The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer,'' he called the elections ''a very important step, because part of our strategy is to encourage a political process that will marginalize those who want to use violence to achieve ends.''

headline: Pressured, Knight Ridder Ponders Sale of Company
abstract: Knight Ridder, publisher of 32 newspapers, says it is considering sale of company and has hired Goldman Sachs to help it evaluate 'strategic alternatives'; sale has been urged by big shareholders, including Private Capital Management and Harris Associates; industry experts say Knight Ridder could attract interest from other publishers, leading media investors and private equity funds, but they note that buyers might prefer to acquire its properites piecemeal rather than together; other newspaper chains may face similar pressure from big shareholders (M)

headline: New start for young Indian families
French Court Rejects Pedophilia Convictions
abstract: French appeals court overturns conviction of six people accused of participating in pedophilia ring in northern France five years ago; nation is asking how court system could have gone so awry in what is considered one of most mismanaged criminal cases in country; Justice Min Pascal Clement calls case 'disaster' and orders unprecedented investigation of police, judiciary and social servie operations in case; case was based on accusations by woman in town of Outreau who later recanted her allegations; photo (M)

headline: For a G.M. Family, the American Dream Vanishes
abstract: Four generations of the Roy family relied on General Motors for their prosperity.      Over more than seven decades, the company's wages bought the Roys homes, cars and once-unimaginable comforts, while G.M.'s enviable medical and pension benefits have kept them secure in their retirements.

headline: A suspect in Rwanda genocide is found dead
DataBank; Stocks Rally on Gains in Economic Growth
abstract: The stock market rose for the week, thanks to a rally on Friday prompted by a government report showing accelerating economic growth accompanied by only moderate inflation.     The Commerce Department said preliminary numbers showed that the economy expanded at a 3.8 percent annual rate in the third quarter, half a percentage point faster than in the previous quarter. It also showed that personal consumption expenditures -- used by the Fed as an inflation gauge -- rose at their slowest rate since mid-2003.

headline: 5 Marines Killed as U.S. Pushes Sweep in Western Iraq
abstract: It was the deadliest day for U.S. troops since beginning a sweep of towns near the Syrian border on Nov. 5.

headline: Fears of identity theft: Ripe for exaggeration?
EU expert wants new flier deal
Toll rises in China mine explosion
Step Right Up, the Fares Are Down
abstract: Business travelers buying last-minute airline tickets are enjoying one of longest periods of generally falling ticket prices in recent memory; fares that big corporations negotiate with airlines, generally in autumn for following year, are also shrinking, if not quite so rapidly; bargains may depend on whether there is a low-cost competitor nearby; photo (M)

headline: A government on the move to a half-built capital
Justices hear campus recruiting case
Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings, an initial public offering of 35 million Class A shares. Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank, J. P. Morgan, Merrill Lynch and UBS.    Columbus McKinnon, 3.4 million shares. Credit Suisse First Boston.    CombinatoRx Inc., an initial public offering of six million shares. SG Cowen and Pacific Growth.    DealerTrack Holdings, an initial public offering of 10 million shares. J. P. Morgan, Lehman Brothers and Wachovia.    Equinix Inc., 4.3 million shares. Credit Suisse First Boston.    Global Secure, an initial public offering of 8.3 million shares. Morgan Keegan and Jefferies.    IHS Inc., an initial public offering of 14.5 million Class A shares. Goldman Sachs and Citigroup Global Markets.    iRobot Corporation, an initial public offering of 4.3 million shares. Morgan Stanley and J. P. Morgan.    Passave Inc., an initial public offering of 4.7 million shares. Merrill Lynch and J. P. Morgan.    Saifun Semiconductors, an initial public offering of five million shares. Lehman Brothers and Deutsche Bank.    Zumiez Inc., 1.9 million shares. Wachovia and U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray.    (Source by MCM EquityWatch)

headline: World Briefing: Asia, Europe, Africa, Americas
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Merkel to follow Schr√∂der's lead
Nicaragua evacuates thousands as Hurricane Beta approaches
Staying Connected on Long Stays Abroad
abstract: TECHNOLOGY is supposed to make our lives more flexible. Unfettered from our cubicles, we can journey with our laptops and cellphones to the coffee shop around the corner, or halfway around the world. At least that is the general idea.     But if you want to mix one part travel, one part technology and two parts gainful employment, you had better be a stickler for technical details.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Big Stake Sold in Steel Maker
abstract: Turkey sells 46 percent stake in state-owned steelmaker, Erdemir, to pension fund for Turkish army officers for $2.77 billion (S)

headline: Police Raid Raises Fears of Bosnia as Haven for Terrorists
abstract: A recent police raid on an apartment near this city's airport uncovered evidence of an imminent suicide bombing, intensifying the fears of Western security services that Bosnia is becoming a haven for Islamic militants.     The raid, which occurred in October after an extensive surveillance operation by both the Bosnian police and Western intelligence services, turned up an arsenal in the apartment, in the suburb of Ilidza, including suicide vests, up to 65 pounds of exploding bullets and high explosive, and a machine pistol. Investigators also found a video in which three men -- at least two of them teenagers -- are seen asking forgiveness from God for their ''sacrifice,'' in a recording made just hours before the raid. The two teenagers were detained.

headline: NBC, Following ABC, Will Sell TV Shows on iTunes
abstract: NBC Universal said today that it would start to sell downloadable versions of 11 of its television shows through  Apple Computer's iTunes Music Store.

headline: French Riots Expose Handicaps Faced by Immigrants' Children
abstract: By KATRIN BENNHOLD.

headline: Briefly: Bin Laden kin testifies in French investigation
Head of Nuclear Agency Again Urges Iran to Cooperate
abstract: Mohamed ElBaradei, the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency, warned Iran on Friday to stop hindering an investigation into the country's nuclear energy program, which the United States and many other observers suspect is a cover to develop nuclear weapons.     ''The international community has begun to lose its patience,'' he told reporters here before a ceremony on Saturday at which he is to be awarded the 2005 Nobel Peace Prize.

headline: Bid for Prewar Iraq Files Raises Political Heat
abstract: Democrats pressed their demand on Thursday for White House documents on prewar intelligence on Iraq in the House Committee on International Relations, with one member only slightly outdoing his colleagues by repeatedly accusing President Bush and his top aides of lying about the threat posed by Saddam Hussein.     Republicans indignantly rebuffed the accusations, their arguments ranging from the Founding Fathers to Pearl Harbor to Vietnam, but boiling down to an assertion that the Democrats were exploiting the war to angle for cheap political advantage.

headline: Home Sales Fall 2.7%, Suggesting a Drag on '06 Economy
abstract: National Association of Realtors says home sales fell to annual pace of 7.09 million units in October, down from 7.29 million in September; there were 2.9 million single-family houses, condominiums and co-ops for sale in October, enough to keep market supplied for 4.9 months, up from 4.6 months in September and most since June 2003; Freddie Mac says average interest rate on 30-year mortgages was 6.28 percent last week, up from 5.77 percent at start of year (M)

headline: Slowing Is Seen in Housing Prices in Hot Markets
abstract: Real estate slowdown that began this summer has spread to hot housing markets around country, including New York; more sellers are putting their homes on market, houses are selling less quickly and prices are no longer increasing as rapidly as they were in spring; in Manhattan, average sales price fell almost 13 percent in third quarter from second quarter; amount of time it took to sell home was up 30.4 percent over same period; for-sale listings have swelled in Washington suburb of Fairfax County, Va, Boston suburb of Brookline, Mass, and throughout California; brokers say some houses seem to be on market longer because sellers priced them too high, while in other cases people who otherwise would have waited year or two to sell their homes had listed them out of fear that prices would soon fall; question remains whether this represents momentary cooling off of overheated housing markets, or it presages more pronounced downturn that would end decade-long boom; photo; chart (M)

headline: AOL tries to navigate between online ad trends
News Analysis: Britain's multicultural experiment goes on
Briefs: Doctors say patient pleased with new face
Playback Problems With DVD's
abstract: Playback Problems With DVD's    Q. Why won't DVD's that I burned on my computer play on the DVD player connected to my TV?    A. DVD's come in a number of formats, like DVD-R and DVD+R, but some older DVD players can't read many of the newer disc formats. Check your player's manual to see what types of discs it is compatible with.

headline: Top officers of Delphi agree to big salary cuts
Dow Ends Lower for 2005
abstract: World stock markets ended a generally up year on a down note, leaving the Dow with its first annual decline since 2002.

headline: Currencies: Speculation over ECB sends dollar lower
Hong Kong votes down political overhaul
Iran's New President Says Israel 'Must Be Wiped Off the Map'
abstract: Iran's new president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, told a group of students at an anti-Israel event on Wednesday that Israel ''must be wiped off the map'' and that attacks by Palestinians would destroy it, the ISNA news agency reported.     He was speaking to about 4,000 students at a program called ''The World Without Zionism,'' in preparation for an annual anti-Israel demonstration held on the last Friday of the holy month of Ramadan.

headline: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.     According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 3.98 percent, while the rate on the six-month issue was at 4.30 percent and the rate on the four-week issue was 3.98 percent.

headline: At helm of the EU, Austria looks south
Black faces new U.S. charges of racketeering
Bill Clinton Finds Better Relief Coordination in Tsunami Area Tour
abstract: Former Pres Bill Clinton tours Aceh Province, Indonesia, laying wreath at mass grave where thousands of tsunami victims are buried; he visits three villages in his role as United Nations special envoy for tsunami recovery, surveying progress of reconstruction effort; says he sees some improvement in information-sharing and cooperation among private aid groups, donors and four levels of government (M)

headline: Indonesia steers toward recovery
U.K. consumer confidence takes a tumble
Venezuela Union Leader Guilty of Treason
abstract: Carlos Ortega, the union leader and fierce opponent of President Hugo Ch√°vez who helped lead an antigovernment strike that shuttered the oil industry three years ago, was sentenced to 16 years in prison for plotting against the government. Vice President Jos√© Vicente Rangel said Venezuela could not ''accept a crime'' he said had cost the oil industry $20 billion.   JUAN FORERO (NYT)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,019 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:    BYLER, William J., 23, Specialist, Army; Ballinger, Tex.; 101st Airborne Division.  GUY, Shaker T., 23, Sgt., Army National Guard; Pomona, Calif.; First Battalion, 184th Infantry.  HILL, Raymond D. II, 39, Capt., Army National Guard; Turlock, Calif.; First Battalion, 184th Infantry.  HODSHIRE, Michael P., 25, Sgt., Marines; North Adams, Mich.; Second Marine Division.  JOHNSON, Adam R. , 22, Pvt., Army; Clayton, Ohio; 101st Airborne Division.  KADING, Matthew R., 32, Sgt. First Class, Army Reserve; Madison, Wis., 983rd Engineer Battalion.  MARTIN, David J., 21, Pfc., Army; Edmond, Okla.; 101st Airborne Division.  ROJAS, Kenny D., 21, Pfc., Army; Pembroke Pines, Fla.; Third Infantry Division.  TESSAR, Jonathan, 36, Sgt. First Class, Army; Simi Valley, Calif.; 101st Airborne Division.  WOOD, William W., 44, Col., Army National Guard; Panama City, Fla.; First Battalion, 184th Infantry.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 45 In Chechnya Mysteriously Ill
abstract: A mysterious illness has sickened at least 45 people in Chechnya, many of them children and teachers from a village school, a spokesman for the emergency services in southern Russia, Oleg A. Grekov, said in a telephone interview. The cause of the outbreak, which began late last week, remains unclear, though some of the victims are gravely ill with symptoms that include respiratory difficulties, fever and loss of consciousness. A local doctor cited a nerve or chemical agent as a possible cause, but other officials discounted that. Chechnya's prosecutor announced an investigation into sanitary conditions at the school, in Starogladkovskaya, about 40 miles from Grozny.   STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

headline: German parties set for final showdown
Mentor Leaves Options Open on Its Bid for Medicis
abstract: The cosmetic medical device company Mentor indicated yesterday that it would not take Medicis Pharmaceutical's blunt rejection of its $2.2 unsolicited billion takeover proposal as the final word.      In Mentor's view, the benefits of joining its breast implant and liposuction equipment businesses with Medicis's antiwrinkle drugs and prescription skin therapies are so clear that there is every reason to hope a deal will eventually be struck.

headline: Letter from Asia:Chance at top UN seat gets the juices flowing
Letters
abstract: Madison Avenue.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Opposition Party Excluded
abstract: Barely two weeks after President Nursultan Nazarbayev followed an eyebrow-raising 91-percent re-election victory with promises of democratization, his government refused to register the main opposition party, Authentic Ak Zhol. Its four leaders accused him of aiming to destroy opposition to his 16-year rule, which has been marked by oil-fueled growth, corruption and nepotism. One of the four, Bulat Abilov, said he was charged this week with a felony involving a property transaction dating from 1999, before he went into politics.    CHRISTOPHER PALA (NYT)

headline: Time Inc. picks new chief editor (but you won't notice)
Dresdner to merge two key units
Briefly: Investigation urged into reporter's death
Boeing offers warning with profit
U.S. and Iraq Step Up Effort to Block Insurgents' Routes
abstract: A few miles outside this sleepy river town, marked in many places with black spray-painted scrawls hailing the network of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, called Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, American troops are building a desert outpost of plywood huts protected by dirt-filled blast barriers and surrounded by a high berm.     American military commanders see this effort as a crucial step in their strategy of cutting off the supply of foreign fighters that has fed the insurgency and threatens to tip the country into civil war.

headline: Stem cells, with ethics
Perry Mason, Meet Your Expert Technology Witness
abstract: Lawsuits over who can profit from ideas and innovation are increasingly a foundation of technology industry, so companies are competing to assemble teams of expert witnesses--technical specialists and technology-savvy economists who will help sway judges and juries on intensely complex merits of patent cases; thriving industry in expert witnesses, who are paid as much as $1,000 an hour, has become part of fabric of global patent system and increasingly contentious legal combat that surrounds it; photo (M)

headline: Barrick Gold Offers to Buy Placer Dome for $9.2 Billion
abstract: Barrick Gold made an unsolicited, $9.2 billion offer for Placer Dome today in a bid to become the world's largest gold mining company.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Uribe Announces Re-Election Run
abstract: Colombian President Alvaro Uribe announces that he will seek re-election in May after country's highest court rules he can seek second consecutive term; Uribe, with popularity rating above 70 percent, vows to continue fight against Marxist rebel groups (S)

headline: Deal Is Reached on Easing Gaza Crossings
abstract: Israel and the Palestinian Authority clinched a rare agreement and settled a bitter dispute on Tuesday when they decided to allow Palestinians to travel in and out of the Gaza Strip with relative freedom.      Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice announced the deal after mediating the marathon negotiations that lasted through the night.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: Poll Officials Dismiss Loser's Fraud Claims
abstract: The National Elections Commission dismissed George Weah's claim of fraud in the presidential election last month, which he lost by nearly 20 percentage points to Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf. Speaking at a news conference in Monrovia, the presiding officer of the commission, Joseph Blidi, said the evidence presented by Mr. Weah's campaign was ''grossly insufficient.'' Mr. Weah, above, a former soccer star, contends that the vote was rigged, and his supporters have clashed with the police and peacekeepers in Monrovia in the past few weeks. Mrs. Johnson-Sirleaf, the Harvard-educated economist who will be inaugurated next month as president and as the first woman elected head of state in modern African history, just completed a trip to the United States during which she met several top administration officials, including Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice.   LYDIA POLGREEN (NYT)

headline: Stalking the Ferocious Clay Pigeon
abstract: MY wife pointed the business end of a 20-gauge Browning over-and-under at the pupil of my left eye. The twin muzzles of the shotgun were so close I could smell the cleaning oil. I squinted at the tiny silver sighting bead mounted on the rib above the top barrel. Then I sucked a long hard breath, all of a sudden feeling weak-kneed and squirmy.     Alison raised the stock up from her right armpit. She was wearing a green-quilted shooting jacket, an Herm√®s scarf, and the kind of look she gives me when she's about to conclude an argument.

headline: Article Says Diabetes Pill Would Increase Coronary Risks
abstract: An article in a leading medical journal said yesterday that a proposed diabetes pill, Pargluva, seemed to significantly increase heart attack and stroke risks.      An accompanying editorial said the drug's sponsors, Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merck, had been ''disingenuous'' in submitting data to the Food and Drug Administration that ''may have fostered an illusion of safety.''

headline: Briefly: Panel is formed to help war-affected countries
Germany Frees '85 Hijacker Who Killed American Sailor
abstract: German parole board releases Mohammed Ali Hamadi, Lebanese terrorist jailed 19 years ago for killing American Navy diver Robert Dean Stethem during TWA hijacking in June 1985; photos; US vows to pursue him; Stethem's body was dumped on tarmac of Beirut airport two days into 17-day standoff that shocked Americans; last 39 hostages were released more than two weeks later; other hijackers are thought to be still at large; Hamadi remains under indictment in US but was allowed to fly to Lebanon before US could discuss taking custody; US requested extradition when Hamadi was arrested in 1987 but Germans refused, worried about two German kidnap victims then in Lebanon; Hamadi was convicted in Frankfurt court and sentenced to maximum life in prison with parole possibility in 15 years; full term would have been 25 years (M)

headline: 3M Finds Chief Without Reaching for a Star
abstract: Five years ago, 3M selected a star manager in W. James McNerney Jr., a General Electric division head who had been hailed as a leading candidate to succeed John F. Welch Jr. at the helm of G.E.      Five months ago, Mr. McNerney abruptly left 3M to join Boeing. And yesterday, 3M named George W. Buckley, the low-profile leader of the Brunswick Corporation, as its new chairman and chief executive.

headline: A 2nd bid for Canada steel maker
U. of Michigan Becomes 10th College to Join Boycott of Coke
abstract: When students at the University of Michigan return to campus next week after the holiday break, they will find the Coke machines and fountain dispensers empty.      The university, which has 50,000 students on three campuses, on Thursday became the 10th college to stop selling Coca-Cola products because of concerns arising from accusations about the company's treatment of workers in bottling plants in Colombia and environmental problems in India.

headline: Divisive points in world trade talks
Designer of Supercomputers Leaves Cray to Join Microsoft
abstract: Burton Smith, a longtime supercomputer designer and chief scientist at Cray, has resigned to take a position at Microsoft.     Mr. Smith was a founder of Tera Computer, which in 2000 acquired Cray Research from Silicon Graphics. The company, which was based in Seattle, was renamed Cray.

headline: Do Your iPod Shuffle on the Sunny Side of the Street, and Recharge It
abstract: For decades now, solar power has seemed like the stepchild of the energy industry, a technology with potential but few popular uses. But now a product called the Soldius1, made by a Dutch company, is putting solar power to use in popular gadgets.      Plug your iPod or cellphone into the Soldius1, and place the charger in direct sunlight to recharge your device in two to three hours. (The charger works on overcast days as well, but it takes longer.)

headline: Bad Year for Tommy But Not for Thomas J.
abstract: The last year may have been a cruel one for Tommy Hilfiger, the corporation, but it has been kinder to Thomas J. Hilfiger, the corporation's honorary chairman and principal designer.      Now that the company has settled a federal investigation into its accounting, its stock is rising on speculation about a buyout. That run-up has increased the value of Mr. Hilfiger's stake by more than $25 million in 2005.

headline: Guidant Settles Suit on Death of Recipient of Heart Device
abstract: The Guidant Corporation, the maker of defibrillators, has agreed to settle a lawsuit over the death of a 21-year-old man who used a company-made heart device that failed, a lawyer representing the man's family said.     The agreement with the family of the man, Joshua Oukrop, who died in Utah on March 14, may be the first civil settlement related to Guidant's recall of 109,000 heart defibrillators, lawyers said.

headline: U.S. and Europe welcome end to German stalemate
U.S. Military Death Toll Reaches 2,000 in Iraq
abstract: The American military death toll in Iraq reached 2,000 by some counts today, and President Bush warned of further losses to come as he defended the increasingly unpopular war.

headline: Bush unveils multipronged 'crash program' to defend against avian flu
Seven & I will buy department store chain
Sesame Street Goes Global: Let's All Count the Revenue
abstract: When a squeezable -- and bankable -- star named Elmo made a belated appearance in France this year, long after his Muppet birth in the United States, doubts emerged immediately about the puppet's proper French esprit.      Was Elmo too sweet? Did the google-eyed creature with a crimson shag and the voice of a child lack sufficient Gallic irony?

headline: Swiss Re Is Reported to Be Selling Investment Bank
abstract: The insurance company Swiss Re has put its research and investment banking subsidiary Fox, Pitt, Kelton on the block, according to an executive briefed on the matter.

headline: Nigeria plane crash kills 107, mostly children
FreeFlow: Thai plan: Not just a fleeting idea?
THE CHURN
abstract: Deal Makers       Morgan Stanley, Lazard and J. P. Morgan Cazenove are advising Marconi of Britain on the sale of its international services and telecommunications equipment businesses to Ericsson of Sweden for $2.1 billion. Enskilda Securities is advising Ericsson.

headline: India and Pakistan open more links
Odd Coalition Opposes Criminalizing Patent Violations
abstract: For once, declared adversaries are on the same side of an argument in the technology industry: Both sides are urging European lawmakers to drop legislation that would impose prison time on patent violators and that they say would stifle innovation across Europe.     Heavyweights like Nokia and Microsoft on one hand, and the grass-roots Foundation for a Free Information Infrastructure on the other, are making common cause against wide-ranging legislation proposed by the European Commission that would criminalize all intellectual property infringements, including patents. The law would provide blanket protection to all forms of intellectual property through the 25 countries of the union.

headline: Saddam's trial resumes
Insurgents kill brother of top Shiite politician
Dutch mourn Theo van Gogh's death
Power Companies Enter the High-Speed Internet Market
abstract: American utility companies are beginning to offer broadband Internet services over their power lines, challenging cable and phone companies that now dominate market; customers with broadband over power line, or BPL, simply plug baseball-size jack into outlet to connect; two biggest commercial BPL services in US are operated by Current Communications, which uses power lines run by Cinergy, local utility in Cincinnati, and city of Manassas, Va, which has teamed up with ComTek Communications Technology; dozens of other utilities across country are testing services and hiring specialists like Current and ComTek to run it; photo (M)

headline: The Un-Mall on Bleecker Street
abstract: Emerge NYC, shopping space recently opened on Bleecker Street in NoHo section of Manhattan, contains 26 open-fronted boutiques and another 26 glass counter spaces, each run by designer selling his or her upscale handmade clothes, bags, jewelry, accessories or fine art directly to customers; Nicholas Petrou, who came up with idea, selects designers to maintain balance of products and interesting aesthetic mix aimed at appealing to shoppers who want to buy unique pieces; photos (M)

headline: Russian Prosecutors Accuse Yukos of Money Laundering
abstract: Russian prosecutors on Wednesday raided offices affiliated with Yukos, the oil company in a tax dispute with the Kremlin, and for the first time accused its employees of money laundering.      The Prosecutor General's Office said in a statement that it was investigating as much as $7 billion in illegal money transfers out of Russia.

headline: Blair says EU must modernize or lose out
Merkel shares history with aide
Upload, Store, Play and Share in a Few Clicks
abstract: David Pogue column on TransMedia's new Web service called Glide Effortless that lets user upload favorite photos, MP3 files, video clips and ever Word, PowerPoint or PDF documents; photo (M)

headline: Transition to Digital Gets Closer
abstract: House of Representatives votes to require complete transition from analog to digital television signals on Feb 17, 2009, and to provide millions of households with coupons to buy converter boxes to keep their sets working after transition; households would get two coupons, each worth $40 toward purchase of $60 converter box, for total cost to government of $900 million to $1.5 billion; Feb 17 date was chosen because it will come two weeks before Super Bowl and a month before NCAA basketball tournament; consumer groups say that coupons will not be nearly enough for all analog television sets and that many consumers will still need to pay $20 or more to upgrade each television set in their home that is not connected to cable or satellite service (M)

headline: Fidelity National to Buy Sedgwick
abstract: Fidelity National Financial, the biggest United States title insurer, has agreed to buy Sedgwick CMS Holdings for $635 million to offer third-party claims management services to Fortune 500 companies.     The Marsh & McLennan Companies, the world's largest insurance broker, and Trident II, one of the buyout funds it used to manage, are the principal selling shareholders, Sedgwick said yesterday in a statement.

headline: World Briefings: Europe, Africa, Middle East
abstract: EUROPE.

headline: Senate Is Set to Require Details on Secret Prisons
abstract: The Senate is poised to approve a measure that would require the Bush administration to provide Congress with its most specific and extensive accounting about the secret prison system established by the Central Intelligence Agency to house terrorism suspects.     The measure includes amendments that would require the director of national intelligence to provide regular, detailed updates about secret detention facilities maintained by the United States overseas, and to account for the treatment and condition of each prisoner. The facilities, established after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, are thought to hold two dozen to three dozen terrorism suspects, including Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is said to be the mastermind of the attacks.

headline: Chancellor says Germany will not be "blackmailed"
Poland, in reversal, keeps forces in Iraq
World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Supreme Court Bans Fringe Party
abstract: Russian Supreme Court bans National Bolshevik Party; ban is first against any political party in Russia's modern history and is seen by party leader Eduard Limonov as Kremlin effort to silence dissent (S)

headline: JWT Loses Another Unilever Account
abstract: Unilever North America drops JWT as ad agency for Ragu line of pasta sauces, assigning account to Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide (S)

headline: Leader of Taiwan urges island to bolster defense
In-flight cellular service may spell end to an oasis
My Songs, My Format
abstract: There are many pocketsize digital music players available, but they fall into two groups: Apple's iPod products and everything else. That split, rooted in technology as well as style, poses a challenge for music lovers who want to upgrade their devices.     IPods, the most popular music players with more than 70 percent of the American market, can play MP3 music files, a popular digital audio compression format. But for the most part, Apple steers its customers to songs in another format, called Advanced Audio Codec (AAC), which most non-Apple devices cannot play.

headline: People
abstract: Roundup of executive changes in ad industry (S)

headline: Virgin Group Gets Financing for Low-Fare Airline in U.S.
abstract: Virgin Group raises $177.3 million needed to start low-fare airline in US; airline, Virgin America, will operate 17 narrow-bodied Airbus A320 planes on longer-distance domestic routes between major cities (M)

headline: EU looking into report of secret CIA jails
Opting out of conference on Muslim nations
Officials hope to lift logjam at trade talks
World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Angry Commuters Burn Trains
abstract: Johannesburg commuters burn 19 train cars and 9 engines in Soweta area after breakdown in service; is third such incident since October as South Africa's commuter trains continue to be plagued by breakdowns (S)

headline: Pakistan Quake Rocks South Asia; Over 18,000 Killed
abstract: A powerful earthquake centered in the Hindu Kush mountains of Pakistan on Saturday morning sent tremors across South Asia, killing more than 18,000 people, including at least 1,600 in remote northern Pakistan, among them hundreds across both sides of disputed Kashmir.      Maj. Gen. Shaukat Sultan, Pakistan's chief army spokesman, who announced the toll on Sunday, said at least 45,000 people had been injured, a vast majority on the Pakistani side of Kashmir. He said that ''so far there are many areas which have not been reached'' by the army, but that military units were expected to reach all of them by the end of the day.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Owner of Store Chains Rewarded
abstract: Phillip Green, owner of Britain's biggest clothing retailer, Arcadia Group, awards himself 1.2 billion pounds ($2.1 billion) payout, largest such one-time payout ever given to British executive from publicly traded company (S)

headline: Rule sought to limit aid for fishing
Trade Officials to Hold Talks to Save a Global Agreement
abstract: Trade ministers from around world agree to hold meetings in London and Geneva through coming week in effort to rescue plans for global trade pact that is at impasse over agriculture issues; talks coincide with concerns that differences over farm policies could derail December gathering in Hong Kong of trade ministers from 148 countries; critics have warned of possible street violence during conference; top trade officials from US, European Union, India, Brazil and Australia will meet and are scheduled to bargain over agricultural issues; US and EU have each made fresh offers in recent weeks to reduce subsidies and tariffs; EU says deal can only be valid if other countries agree to list of rules (M)

headline: Greenspan warns of oil's 'drag' on world growth
Oil companies get back to business in Libya
Uzbek regime arrests a leader of country's decimated opposition
Signs of improvement in Eastern Europe
Santander Investing in Philadelphia Bank
abstract: Banco Santander Central Hispano of Spain gains toehold in United States with $2.4 billion deal for 19.8 percent of Sovereign Bancorp of Philadelphia, and option to buy whole bank after 2008; Sovereign plans to use proceeds to purchase Independence Communty Bank of Brooklyn, which has 120 branches in New York metropolitan area, for $3.6 billion; photo (M)

headline: W.T.O. Chief Is Cautiously Optimistic on Trade Pact
abstract: Considerable progress toward a global free trade pact is possible, the director general of the World Trade Organization predicted, but many obstacles remain.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honda Posts Profit, Raises Forecast
abstract: Honda Motor, Japan's third-largest carmaker, reported higher profits in the first half of the fiscal year and raised its full-year earnings forecast as its fuel-efficient vehicles drew American buyers. In the six months ended Sept. 30, Honda reported net profit of 244.3 billion yen ($2.1 billion), up 1.2 percent from last year. Sales in the period jumped 10.5 percent to 4.6 trillion yen ($40 billion). Honda said it expected record sales this year, led by its Accord and newly redesigned Civic sedans, and it expected most of the sales gains to come in the United States, where soaring gas prices were pushing consumers toward higher-mileage vehicles.   Martin Fackler (NYT)

headline: Cheney renews attack on prewar-data critics
U.S. trade deficit surgesas storms lift oil prices
Europe Expected to Require Keeping of Phone-Call Data
abstract: The European Parliament is expected to approve legislation Wednesday that would require telecommunications companies to keep details on their clients' phone calls, faxes and e-mail messages for six months to two years to help combat terrorism.      The legislation, written in September, is coming up for a vote in record time. Though it generally takes a year to 18 months to bring a law to a vote, the countries that make up the union back the legislation, which comes in the wake of terrorist attacks in London last summer and Madrid last year.

headline: Doses of Reality, In-Flight and Out
abstract: JetBlue Airways and American Express join for contest to promote JetBlue Card, and contest will be promoted on JetBlue's in-flight satellite television system as well as on Web site; promotion is indicative of efforts by marketers to forge emotional bonds between brands and consumers, particularly through experiences sponsored by brands rather than through conventional advertising (M)

headline: Torture's role in Chinese justice
Briefly: Court rejects lawsuit on visits to Yasukuni
Governments Tremble atGoogle's Bird's-Eye View
abstract: Increased openness in digitally networked world is causing security concerns in governments around world; several nations voice alarm about Google Earth, free software that marries satellite and aerial images with mapping capabilities, offering detailed displays of government buildings, military installations and other important sites within their borders; India, whose laws sharply restrict satellite and aerial photography, is particularly incensed, as are South Korea and Thailand; there is little they can do but protest; American experts in and outside government agree that focus on Google Earth as security threat appears misplaced; note same images Google acquires from variety of sources are available directly from imaging companies, as well as from other sources; photos (M)

headline: Wal-Mart Movie Opens With Fracas in Manhattan
abstract: Wal-Mart consultant John Marino is told to leave Manhattan theater at premiere of film Wal-Mart: The High Cost of Low Price after film's director Robert Greenwald accuses him of trying to secretly record film; incident is latest chapter in escalating public relations battle between Wal-Mart and its critics; Rick Jacobs, chairman of Brave New Films, which is distributing film, says he is considering filing charges against Wal-Mart and Marino for attempted piracy (M)

headline: Pakistanis vow to continue rescue efforts
Frank Lowe Is Back, Looking for Clients
abstract: ALTHOUGH it happened 16 years ago, Andrew Robertson, now the president and chief executive at BBDO Worldwide, can still recall the details of his first and only job interview with the legendary British adman Frank Lowe.     The tale involves a palatial home in a fancy London neighborhood, a butler in striped pants, a rooftop garden and a declaration by Mr. Lowe, then the chairman of the agency now known as Lowe Worldwide, that Mr. Robertson ''knew nothing about advertising,'' Mr. Robertson said, ''and my only hope to learn anything about it was to come to work for him.''

headline: A FRIEND IN NEED
abstract: Once indifferent to politics, Wal-Mart's founding family has learned the value of having -- and supporting -- friends in high places.     One such friend is Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California. Last year he vetoed a bill that would have forbidden employers to lock workers inside businesses, a practice Wal-Mart has used. Last month he vetoed a bill that would have required California to identify the employers of people who are paid so little that they qualify for government health services. Again, Wal-Mart is the No. 1 example.

headline: Cautiously, China Honors Leader Linked to Tiananmen Unrest
abstract: With security heavy and a veil of secrecy, China on Friday officially rehabilitated a former Communist Party leader whose death in 1989 set off huge student demonstrations.     About 350 people attended what the state media called a ''discussion meeting'' at the Great Hall of the People in Tiananmen Square to remember the former leader, Hu Yaobang, who would have been 90 years old on Sunday. State news media confirmed that the event had been held but provided few details.

headline: Pakistan quake toll rises
World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Debut For Electronic Passports
abstract: Germany begins issuing 'e-Pass,' electronic passport with biometric data like digital photograph and, in 2007, digital fingerprints; is one of first European Union countries to create such passports, which United States requires for visa-free visits (S)

headline: U.S. Convenes Peace Talks on Darfur, but Rebels Are Mostly Absent
abstract: The American effort to encourage an end to the carnage in the Darfur province of Sudan suffered a blow on Tuesday when the leaders of the largest faction there walked out of a meeting that had been called by Robert B. Zoellick, the deputy secretary of state, to promote unity among competing groups.     ''We can't sit with them as equals,'' said Saif Haroun, an officer of the group, nodding toward his rivals.

headline: Turnover at Top Fund of Fidelity
abstract: Fidelity Investments says Robert E Stansky will retire as manager of its flagship Magellan fund, ending disappointing reign at helm of one of largest and best-known mutual funds; Stansky will be succeeded by Harry W Lange, who has been manager of Fidelity's Capital Appreciation Fund; Fidelity also announces that Steven Kaye, manager of Growth and Income Fund, has decided to step down for other opportunities in firm; Kaye will be succeeded by Timothy M Cohen, manager of Fidelity Export and Multinational Fund; moves come at time when Fidelity is struggling to regain its old reputation as maverick stock picker (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Spain Looks Into C.I.A.'s Handling of Detainees
abstract: Investigative judge in Palma, Spain, orders police inquiry to be sent to Spain's national court to consider whether Central intelligence Agency is routing planes carrying terrorism suspects through Majorca as part of its so-called rendition program, under which US bypasses normal extradition procedures to secretly transfer suspects to third countries, where suspects are allegedly tortured; programis focus of several European investigations (M)

headline: Europe's Central Bank Keeps Rate, but Hints It May Rise
abstract: With oil prices high and likely to stay that way for the foreseeable future, the European Central Bank signaled on Thursday that it was edging toward its first interest rate increase since 2000.     The bank left the benchmark rate unchanged at 2 percent, but its president, Jean-Claude Trichet, said, ''we will move, if needed, at any time.''

headline: Gadgets of the week:Don't sit still, do play
Colombia's Highest Court Delays Abortion Ruling
abstract: The country's stringent abortion laws ban the procedure even when the life of the woman is in danger.

headline: New Snags in Oil Talks by Indonesia And Exxon
abstract: The Exxon Mobil Corporation has run into a new impasse with Indonesia's state-owned oil company over plans to develop the country's largest known oil reserve, prompting the government to warn that it will take over the project if an agreement is not reached by the end of the year.     After signing a contract with the government of Indonesia in September that ended four years of squabbling over how to split revenue from an oil field near Cepu on the island of Java, Exxon Mobil and the state-owned oil company Pertamina are now in a dispute over how the project should be run.

headline: How do you manage: Not growing, and happy about it
Gay Britons Signing Up as Unions Become Legal
abstract: From Brighton to Birmingham and beyond, gay and lesbian couples began registering Monday for the first ceremonies later this month legally recognizing same-sex unions in Britain.     As a new law permitting what are called civil partnerships came into force, at least 1,200 couples scheduled ceremonies to take place beginning Dec. 19 in Northern Ireland, Dec. 20 in Scotland and Dec. 21 in England and Wales.

headline: Briefly: Israeli airstrike kills 4 with explosives in car
World Briefing | Europe: Swiss Order Russian Nuclear Expert To U.S.
abstract: Swiss court orders extradition of Yevgeny O Adamov, former Russian nuclear energy official, to United States to stand trial on charges of stealing more than $9 million from US Department of Energy; Russian request for extradition was denied earlier (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Rises
abstract: Canada's merchandise trade surplus reached 5.6 billion Canadian dollars in August, up from 4.9 billion dollars in July; trade surplus with US reached 8.9 billion Canadian dollars in period (S)
