headline: At Tokyo Auto Show, a Focus on Fuel, Not Fenders
abstract: Focus of Tokyo Motor Show is fuel-efficiency, not style of car; Toyota is displaying its Fine-X, fuel-cell concept vehicle powered by electric battery and low-pollution hydrogen cell; Mazda is featuring Premacy, minivan with rotary engine fueled by hydrogen that is supposed to go on sale in US as early as 2008; General Motors is offering Sequel, sport utility vehicle that represents technological leap over hybrids; photo (M)

headline: Wal-Mart Memo Suggests Ways to Cut Employee Benefit Costs
abstract: Wal-Mart's executive vice president M Susan Chambers sends internal memo to board proposing numerous ways to hold down spending on health care and other benefits while seeking to minimize damage to retailer's reputation; recommends hiring more part-time workers, discouraging unhealthy people from working at Wal-Mart, reducing 401(k) contributions and wooing younger, and presumably healthier, workers by offering education benefits; voices concern that workers with seven years' seniority earn more than workers with one year's seniority, but are no more productive; suggests that company arrange for 'all jobs to include some physical activity,' to discourage unhealthy job applicants; acknowledges that Wal-Mart has to walk fine line in restraining benefit costs because critics have attacked it for being stingy on wages and health benefits; acknowledges that 46 percent of children of Wal-Mart's 1.33 million US employees are uninsured or on Medicaid; proposed plan would save company more than $1 billion a year by 2011; photos (M)

headline: Showdown on Constitutional Change Is Coming in Hong Kong
abstract: Beijing-backed leaders said they would demand that the legislature vote on a change to their plan for limited democracy.

headline: UN assails China forwide use of torture
Telekom plans huge spending for 2006
Briefs: German trade surplus expands
Dispute Over Natural Gas Prices in Ukraine
abstract: The Russian natural gas company Gazprom is demanding that Ukraine pay Western European rates for Russian gas -- more than four times what it pays now -- or hand over control of its gas pipeline network to a consortium to be run by Russia, Germany and Ukraine.     Gazprom is threatening to cut supplies if talks break down, just as Ukraine heads toward the coldest months of winter, and ahead of the country's first post-Orange Revolution parliamentary elections in March.

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,966 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:    ADAMS, Mark P., 24, Sgt., Marine Forces Reserve; Morrisville, N.C.; Second Marine Division.    BOSWELL, Samuel M., 20, Specialist, Army National Guard; Elkridge, Md.; 243rd Engineer Company.    CEO, Bernard L, 23, Specialist, Army National Guard; Baltimore; 243rd Engineer Company.    CONNER, Brian R., 36, Sgt., Army National Guard; Baltimore; 243rd Engineer Company.

headline: Iran's President Suffers Third Defeat in Choice of Oil Minister
abstract: The Iranian Parliament rejected Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's third nominee for the sensitive leadership of the ministry of oil.

headline: Venezuelan Thrives on Seeing Threats From 'Mr. Danger'
abstract: The White House may be focused on Iraq and the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, but in Venezuela, President Hugo Ch√°vez's most pressing concern seems to be the Bush administration. Or, as he frequently puts it, the administration's grand plans to kill him and invade this oil-rich country.     The threats are so great, Mr. Ch√°vez has said, that he has been forced to cancel numerous public appearances and create a civilian militia force that will make the Yankee hordes ''bite the dust.'' And he warns that if the Americans are so foolish as to invade, ''you can forget the Venezuelan oil.''

headline: Financial Executive Set to Quit Stewart
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, which is on track to report its first profit in two years in February, said yesterday that its chief financial and administrative officer, James Follo, planned to resign in March.     Howard Hochhauser, 34, vice president of finance and investor relations, will become acting chief financial officer when Mr. Follo, 45, leaves, the company, which is based in New York, said in a statement. Mr. Hochhauser joined the company in 2000 and was named to his current job in 2002.

headline: EU restates its demand, but studies Iran's request
Jury Finds That Former Analyst Misled Investors
abstract: A federal jury found yesterday that a former analyst at Robertson Stephens, Paul Johnson, violated federal securities laws by omitting from his research reports important facts about his holdings.     The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Mr. Johnson of deceiving investors by failing to disclose his financial stake in companies he was recommending. After a two-week trial, a jury in Manhattan agreed that Mr. Johnson had violated securities laws.

headline: Top Regulator Says Sarbanes-Oxley Act Audits Are Too Costly and Inefficient
abstract: Public Co Accounting Oversight Board chairman William McDonough says audits of internal controls at American companies, as required by Sarbanes-Oxley Act, have been both too costly and not as good as they should be; board report looks at how companies complied with act, which requires audits; report is issued on McDonough's final day as chairman of board; no successor has yet been named (M)

headline: Ivory Coast's Ethnic Lines Harden, Hobbling Economy
abstract: Ivory Coast's on-and-off civil war began in 2002 when rebels seized northern half of country; at heart of conflict is ethnic tension over fertile land; on one side are those who see themselves as native Ivorians, mainly southern Christians and animists who control government; on other side, mostly Muslim, are those whose forebears came from neighboring countries or who are native northerners; result is that economy is in shambles, infrastructure is crumbling and future is uncertain; photos; map (M)

headline: Trouble brewing in oil-rich Norway
What to Tell the Company as You Walk Out the Door
abstract: Q. You've resigned from your job, and the human resources department has requested an exit interview. How do you make sure that your last impression is a good one?    A. Much like an initial job interview, the exit interview requires employees to act with dignity, said Maggie Craddock, president of Workplace Relationships, an executive coaching firm in New York City. ''As tempting as it might be to blow it off, the exit interview is not a time to go in and say, 'I'm out of here,' '' Ms. Craddock said. ''How you leave often is what sticks with people about you after you've gone, so it's critical to handle the exit interview professionally.''    Q. What purpose do exit interviews serve?    A. They aren't mandatory, but it's generally a good idea to participate if asked. For employees, the meetings can provide closure for their tenure at a company. For employers, they can help unearth facts about the workplace environment. Beth Carvin, chief executive of Nobscot, a human resources software company in Honolulu, says the best companies use this information to improve the workplace for those who remain.

headline: Indonesian Police Continue Search for Clues in Bombings
abstract: Police are seeking two Malaysian men whom the authorities now suspect of being the masterminds behind Saturday's bombings that killed 22 people.

headline: Hurricane Wilma grows into dangerous Category 5
Youth Power in Liberia: From Bullets to Ballots
abstract: War took James Garmey's childhood. It came at night, in the form of armed men battering down a door and carrying him off, the 8-year-old son of a rural customs collector, to be a soldier for the warlord and future president Charles Taylor.      ''I went to training,'' said Mr. Garmey, now 22, speaking in the smooth patois of the Liberian street, letting consonants and bits of grammar slip away. ''I was small, but I learned to hold gun and after a while went to battlefront. I fire gun, I defend my area.''

headline: Report Links TV Ads and Childhood Obesity
abstract: A federal advisory institution said today that there was compelling evidence linking television advertising and the rise of childhood obesity in the U.S.

headline: Six Kuwaitis sentenced to death on terrorist charges
South Korea ratifies rice trade pact
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Demand for Natural Gas Exceeds the Supply, Threatening Winter Shortages and High Prices  Demand for natural gas is exceeding production for a variety of reasons, among them a shutdown of some production capacity after recent Gulf of Mexico hurricanes. The result could be a squeeze in the energy market this winter, particularly if the weather is cold. Homeowners and businesses that use natural gas are expected to pay sharply higher utility bills. [Page C1.]    A Profit and a Strong Holiday Forecast at Wal-Mart  Wal-Mart posted its smallest quarterly income gain in four years but promised a strong holiday shopping season. Net income for the quarter ended Oct. 31 rose 3.8 percent to $2.4 billion, or 57 cents a share, from $2.3 billion, or 54 cents a share, while sales rose to $75. 4 billion from $68.5 billion. [C1.]    Russia Challenged by a Wealth of Oil Income  Russia, the world's second-largest oil exporter after Saudi Arabia, is taking in $500 million a day from crude oil exports and the cash is gushing faster than the nation can absorb it without generating inflation. [C1.]    Knight Ridder Begins to Explore Its Sale  Under growing pressure from shareholders, Knight Ridder, the publisher of 32 newspapers, including The Miami Herald and The Philadelphia Inquirer, said that it was considering a sale of the company. Knight Ridder, which is contending along with the rest of the industry with falling circulation and tepid revenue growth, said it had hired Goldman Sachs to help it evaluate ''strategic alternatives.'' [C1.]    Federal Reserve Nominee Faces Hearing Today  Ben S. Bernanke, President Bush's nominee to lead the Federal Reserve, will have to fend off contrasting perceptions at his confirmation hearing today. Some Democrats worry that he will focused on inflation at the expense of jobs, while bond investors worry that he might be soft on inflation. Mr. Bernanke, a former professor at Princeton University and a Fed governor from 2002 until earlier this year, is expected to win Senate confirmation. [C1.]    Koch Adds Paper to a Portfolio of Oil and Asphalt  In making a $13 billion bid for Georgia-Pacific, Koch Industries, a privately-held energy concern, will leapfrog Cargill to become the nation's biggest private company and add household names like Brawny paper towels and Quilted Northern bath tissue to a portfolio of oil and asphalt. [C3.]    Hospital Care Said to Improve When Pay Is Linked  Linking hospital payments to the quality of patient care can significantly improve the level of care, Medicare officials said in announcing results of the experimental performance-based bonus system for hospitals. [C3.]    Deal Unlikely as Internet Governance Talks Near End  On the eve of the conclusion of four years of high-level talks on Internet governance, a figurative ocean separates the American position -- that the Internet works fine as it is -- from most of the rest of the world, including the European Union, which says the Internet is an international resource whose center of gravity must move away from Washington. [C14.]    Host Marriott Buys Hotels From Starwood for $3.4 Billion  The Host Marriott Corporation will buy 38 hotels from Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide for about $3.4 billion to expand its upscale and overseas hotel and resort holdings. [C3.]    Insurer's Profit Falls as a Result of Hurricanes  American International Group said third-quarter earnings fell 36 percent from a year ago because of losses from Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. [C3.]    Microsoft to Introduce a Computer for Science  Microsoft plans to introduce its first entry into the market for high performance scientific and technical computing. [C14.]    Administration Officials Repeat Trade Demands in China  In speeches and interviews here just six days before President Bush arrives in Beijing, the United States trade representative, Rob Portman, left, and the deputy secretary of commerce repeated previous demands for China to protect American copyrights, trademarks and patents, and that more American companies be allowed to compete in China's domestic market. [C6.]    A Winemaker Focuses on Deals Instead of the Harvest  Donald L. Triggs, chief executive of Vincor International, would normally be focusing on the grape harvest at this time of year, but this season, he is focusing on giving his shareholders a better deal than the $1.4 billion Canadian ($1.18 billion) takeover bid from Constellation Brands that he rejected. [C5.]    Major Stock Gauges Finish With Little Change  Stocks were little changed. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.13 points, to 10,697.17. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 1.01 points, to 1,233.71, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 1.52 points, to 2,200.95. [C12.]    Visa USA Shifts Ad Agencies on Creative Account  Visa USA is unexpectedly dismissing its creative agency for the last two decades, the flagship New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, and shifting the assignment to another Omnicom agency, TBWA/Chiat/Day. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C13.]

headline: Price competition hurts earnings at Nissan
2 Sued on Trading Charges
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued two former hedge fund managers in San Francisco yesterday, asserting they used a loophole in a Bear Stearns trading system to place thousands of illegal mutual fund trades at other investors' expense.     Brent Federighi, 34, and Michael Hoffman, 42, who managed about $130 million in the Ilytat hedge funds, took advantage of a Bear Stearns system that allowed them to buy or sell mutual fund shares after a 4 p.m. regulatory cutoff, the S.E.C. said in a complaint filed in federal court in San Francisco. The so-called late trades caused about $49 million of losses for the mutual funds and their other shareholders, the S.E.C. said.

headline: Hemisphere Summit Marred by Violent Anti-Bush Protests
abstract: President Bush's troubles trailed him to an international summit meeting here on Friday as anti-Bush protesters turned violent just blocks from the gathering site, and Hugo Ch√°vez, Venezuela's fiery populist leader, rallied a soccer stadium filled with at least 25,000 people against the United States.     Mr. Ch√°vez, who has tried to use the summit meeting to stage a showdown with Mr. Bush, pronounced dead a free trade accord backed by Mr. Bush, the Free Trade Area of the Americas. Left-wing groups throughout Latin America have long opposed the agreement, and some governments want more generous terms from Washington, so Mr. Bush had come here with hopes of jump-starting the stalled negotiations.

headline: A world without easy oil: What now?
United Airlines Financial Plan Gains Approval From Creditors
abstract: Creditors of the UAL Corporation have approved its plan to repay debt, paving the way for the company to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February, the company said yesterday.      A sufficient number of creditor votes were cast for the plan, UAL, which is based in Elk Grove, Ill., said in an e-mailed statement. The results permit the company, the parent of United Airlines, to seek approval of the reorganization plan from Judge Eugene R. Wedoff of United States Bankruptcy Court in Chicago. Judge Wedoff will consider the proposal on Jan. 18.

headline: N. Korea vows to buildown light-water reactors
Tickling the Ivories and the Keyboard in One Device
abstract: Modern musicians, even those not yet out of grade school, are increasingly multitaskers, juggling computers and musical instruments. The combination can be a fruitful one, but bouncing between keyboard and, well, the other kind of keyboard requires a bit of a rubber-arm act.     The Creative Prodikeys PC-MIDI multifunction keyboard lets you play music as you type, or vice versa. The keyboard, available now for $39, has a simpler design than earlier Prodikeys models and connects to the computer through a U.S.B. jack. It features customizable ''hotkeys'' that can be set to launch favorite programs, along with buttons to control audio and video playback.

headline: Wal-Mart, stalled in Japan, to try harder
Do Companies Need a Little Democracy?
abstract: Floyd Norris column on need for greater shareholder say in how corporations are run; says that while shareholders legally own companies, they have little influence over them in practice; notes suggestion put forward by Leo E Strine Jr, Delaware vice chancellor, for change in state laws to allow contested elections of directors--outside of takeover contest--every three years; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Government To Make 'Bolivarian Computers'
abstract: Venezuelan government is working with China to produce about 80,000 'Bolivarian computers' in 2006, priced to be affordable to as many Venezuelans as possible; computers will be made by new state company Technological Industries of Venezuela (S)

headline: When Answers (With Ads) Are Just a Phone Call Away
abstract: THE new technology start-up company AskMeNow hopes to play concierge to business travelers who have a cellphone or BlackBerry but no access to the Internet for hotel recommendations, weather forecasts or stock quotes.     The service works like this: After registering at www.askmenow.com and downloading the free software onto a cellphone or BlackBerry, users can call a toll-free number any time, leave a question and receive an answer in a text message, usually within a few minutes.

headline: U.S. and France Agree Iran Must Stop Making Nuclear Fuel
abstract: France said that Iran should be allowed to have a civilian nuclear power program as long as it acquires the nuclear fuel elsewhere.

headline: Consumer Prices Slowed in October, but Energy Costs Stir Inflation Fears
abstract: The consumer inflation rate dropped significantly in October and touched its lowest level since June as surging gasoline prices fell from their peak in September, the government reported yesterday.     But lower prices at the pump, which have receded still more in November, may not be enough to tame inflation in the coming months as heating bills start climbing and businesses pass their higher costs on to customers, some economists said.

headline: Cambodia Profits From Killing Fields and Other Symbols
abstract: There is little to see here but gaping pits in the ground and a glass-fronted tower that holds some of the 8,000 skulls of people who were slaughtered here.     This is the most venerated of the hundreds of killing fields in Cambodia, and over the decades it has become a place to remember the 1.7 million people who died during the brutal rule of the Communist Khmer Rouge from 1975 to 1979.

headline: Talks With Iran on Nuclear Plans Resume; Little Progress Is Seen
abstract: Negotiators for Britain, France and Germany meet with Iran for first time since talks over Iran's nuclear development program were suspended four months ago in bitterness; delegates say two sides agreed to hold further talks in Jan, but it seems virtually certain there will be no resumption of substantive talks then; talks have foundered on Iran's insistence on developing nuclear program on its own soil that would include technology that would enable it to enrich uranium to produce material that could be used either to generate electricity or to produce bomb (M)

headline: Profile: Samuel A. Alito
In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Insurgents Attack Afghan Police Station, Killing 6 Officers
abstract: Afghan police officers suffered heavy casualties when they came under attack by suspected Taliban insurgents overnight in a police station in southern Afghanistan, police officials said Saturday.      Six policemen were killed and two were wounded in the fighting, which lasted from midnight until 3 a.m., according to the police. Three other police officers were also killed Friday in two other attacks.

headline: Annan Defends U.N. Official Who Chided U.S.
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan defends Louise Arbour, UN high commissioner for human rights, after comments she made about detention and torture came under criticism from US Amb John R Bolton; is seeking meeting with Bolton to make his point in person (M)

headline: For generation 'ex,' a self-help magazine
Stocks: Delphi's troubles drag down GM and Wall St.
What's Ahead: Blue Skies, or More Forecasts of Them?
abstract: Nation's economic forecasters are all but unanimous in predicting that coming year will not bring recession, but high energy costs, cooling housing market and other signs point to slowing of economic growth; forecasters polled by Philadelphia Fed believe economy will expand 3.4 percent next year, down from 3.6 percent this year; however, Joseph H Ellis of Goldman Sachs says 2 percent growth is more likely, arguing that slowing of inflation-adjusted pay growth will hurt consumer spending; graph (M)

headline: The Workplace: Who wants to be a CEO millionaire?
Citing New Medical Report, Milosevic's Lawyers Urge Postponement in War Crimes Trial
abstract: The declining health of Slobodan Milosevic has led an international medical team to call for an immediate halt to his activities and has renewed doubts about whether his long war-crimes trial can be completed next year.      Lawyers for Mr. Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, said three doctors, from France, Russia and Serbia, examined him on Nov. 4 at the United Nations detention center in The Hague, where he has spent the past four years.

headline: Stock Offerings This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:     CBOT Holdings, an initial public offering of 3.2 million shares. Credit Suisse First Boston and J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: Jung biographer blocks changes to book
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: In Europe, Disagreement Continues Over Whether Interest Rates Should Rise  The European Central Bank has settled the debate over when it plans to tighten credit, signaling a rate increase next week. The debate over whether it should do so rages on. The bank's president, Jean-Claude Trichet, left, has invoked the specter of rising inflation as the main reason to lift rates from 2 percent -- a level, he notes, that is historically low. Inflation in Europe is running at roughly 2.3 percent, above the bank's threshold of 2 percent. Some economists, however, forecast that it will fall back below 2 percent by next summer. [Page C1.]    European stocks paced declines by stocks worldwide after a measure of German business confidence fell more than economists had predicted. DaimlerChrysler and Siemens were among the shares that fell. [C5.]    W.T.O. Chief Not Counting on a Consensus  Pascal Lamy, the new director general of the World Trade Organization, does not even plan to propose a comprehensive agreement before trade ministers from 149 nations and customs territories gather in Hong Kong on Dec. 13. Instead, Mr. Lamy intends to issue a fairly broad outline of where the different sides stand on a range of issues, said Keith Rockwell, the chief W.T.O. spokesman. ''He's not going to try to force a consensus that's not there,'' Mr. Rockwell said. [C1.]    An Ambitious Plan for a Chinese City  The extensive chemical spill in the Songhua River that threatens the water supply of Harbin in northeastern China has focused attention on the environmental and economic challenges faced by the country's withering rust belt. Long before Harbin's officials were forced to confront the contamination of the city's water supply, however, they had embarked on a radical step, one increasingly common among cities in China: they had begun efforts to move the center of the city north, across the winding Songhua, to a large plot of farm land. [C1.]    New Orleans Bank Continues Its Struggle  Nearly three months after Hurricane Katrina, reconstruction of the New Orleans economy is turning out to be slower and more complex than many people first thought, as businesses like Liberty Bank and Trust are discovering. Basic services like electricity, water and sewerage are still lacking in large swaths of the city, including the New Orleans East neighborhood, home to four of Liberty's eight New Orleans branches. [C1.]    At Lehman, a Different Kind of Risk Management  In preparing for the unlikely but frightening possibility of a bird flu pandemic, Lehman Brothers is focusing on two issues: how to enable people to work from home -- which requires resolving connectivity and technology issues -- and, as an industry, how to connect companies to one another to prevent a financial panic. Street Scene. [C4.]

headline: Rice Presses For Fair Voting In Central Asia
abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, beginning a trip to Central Asia, urged the region's leaders on Monday to hold ''elections that are free and fair,'' even though in one state she plans to visit nearly all the likely opposition candidates have been jailed and in another laws have been passed that stack the odds in favor of the present rulers.     During her visits this week to Kyrgyzstan, Kazakhstan and Tajikistan, all former Soviet republics, she will raise difficult and conflicting issues as Russia looks on warily. They include military basing rights, energy and economic relationships, and drug trafficking problems in the region. But Ms. Rice made it clear that promoting democracy would be central to her mission.

headline: 19,000 jobs will be cut at Deutsche Telekom
Officials bear down on breaking trade impasse
Swiss back ban on modified crops
Referral of Iran to UN put off
A black news anchor makes news in France
Polish Election Appears Headed for a Runoff
abstract: A former labor activist from the Solidarity trade union appeared to have come in first in Poland's hotly contested presidential election on Sunday, but surveys of voters leaving the polls indicated that he would not win the majority he would need to avoid a runoff in two weeks.      Donald Tusk, 48, an unabashed free-market advocate who advocated a 15 percent flat tax for Poland, received 38.4 percent of the vote, according to the polls on Sunday night commissioned by Polish state television. The official vote tally was not expected until Monday, but unless the polls were wildly inaccurate, it seemed unlikely that any candidate would end up with a majority.

headline: Tax-Shelter Inquiry Focuses on Restaurant Operator
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service has been looking at a questionable tax shelter sold to big corporations that may have improperly allowed large tax deductions through murky transactions with the company's own private insurers.      The shelter, called Insureco, was sold by the accounting firm KPMG in the late 1990's, according to papers filed by the Justice Department in an unusual dispute involving Yum Brands, which owns the Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC chains.

headline: 9/11 panel to single out FBI
A Little Bit Hollywood, a Little Bit Washington
abstract: HOWARD S. JONAS, the founder, chairman and controlling shareholder of the IDT Corporation, is by most accounts -- including his own -- a maverick. ''Wall Street can go to hell,'' he jotted in his 1998 memoir ''On a Roll,'' which recounted his rise from selling roadside hot dogs near his boyhood home in the Bronx to taking IDT public nine years ago. ''I'm going to ignore the quarterly numbers and run my business for the long run.''      But lately, it seems, the feeling is mutual. Mr. Jonas, a serial entrepreneur and budding media mogul, has become a target of shareholder activists, who accuse his unusual and politically connected company of shabby governance.

headline: Siebel Wins Suit Dismissal
abstract: A federal judge in San Francisco dismissed a class-action lawsuit against Siebel Systems, saying investors failed to show that the company misled them before it disclosed its Siebel 7 software was not selling as well as expected. Siebel, a big maker of customer service software, made the sales disclosure in 2002.

headline: Officials warn of more deaths from quake
Youths Make Spirited Case at Climate Meeting
abstract: Young people from as far as Australia who came to Montreal for meetings on global warming spend evening at party given by local nonprofit group called Apathy Is Boring; young attendees have been staging daily demonstrations, mostly lighthearted, to highlight importance of meetings for their generation; photo (M)

headline: DataBank: OCTOBER 3-7; Inflation Fear Sends Stocks Down for the Week
abstract: Despite a rally on Friday, the stock market had its worst week in months, giving up ground amid concerns about inflation.     Richard W. Fisher, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said on Tuesday that inflation was at the high end of a range in which the Fed is comfortable. Other Fed officials also made statements last week suggesting the central bank would continue raising short-term rates this year.

headline: How do you manage? Keep it short, make a connection - and no jokes!
Chirac and Blair play down dispute
Annan Warns Eritrea That U.N. May Leave Border
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan announces possible end to UN peacekeeping efforts along border between Eritrea and Ethiopia; says Eritrea's ban on use of UN helicopters in area is severely compromising ability of 3,300-person monitoring mission to operate effectively (S)

headline: Gadgets of the week: Skype adds video calling
A 'Chemistry' Reaction
abstract: A trade association for the nation's major chemical companies is seeking the right, um, formula for convincing consumers that the products they produce are as necessary for modern-day living as hydrogen and oxygen are for making water.

headline: Europe Entertains an American Offer to Cut Farm Aid
abstract: European Union's trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, cautiously welcomes proposal Rob Portman, US trade representative, to slash some agricultural subsidies by 60 percent over next five years in exchange for tariff reductions of 55 percent to 90 percent; says European Union is willing to go 'substantially beyond' proposed American cuts, but declines to comment on whether Europe could meet American demands on tariff reduction; farms groups in US say cuts in subsidies would cause some economic pain, particularly for crops like corn and soybeans; critics of Portman's plan say subsidy cuts would not address main long-term issue of declining commodity prices and unchecked tendencies by farmers to overproduce; Portman photo (M)

headline: French, Seeing Terror Plot, Arrest 20 During Raids in Paris Region
abstract: French police say they arrested more than 20 people, including Islamic militants and petty criminals, in Paris area who were believed to be plotting terrorist acts in France; say most of suspects are Tunisian or Algerian, or French citizens of North African descent; intelligence official claims group was committing common crimes to finance terrorist acts; police have not determined whether group had precise plans for terrorist attack (M)

headline: Producer of Syringes Is Sued Over Firing
abstract: The former director of immunization at Becton, Dickinson & Company, which makes hypodermic syringes, has filed a lawsuit against the company saying that he was wrongfully terminated.     The former director, Zeil Rosenberg, said in a complaint filed yesterday in Superior Court in Bergen County, N.J., that he was fired in December 2004 because he objected to the company's shipping medical supplies to Iraq in 2001 without the approval of the federal government and because he disagreed with marketing plans for a new syringe.

headline: G.M. Temporarily Waives Cuts in Prices It Pays Delphi
abstract: General Motors will give Delphi Corp some temporary financial assistance while talks continue on rescue plan; Delphi says it is giving United Automobile Workers union more time to negotiate before company files motion in bankruptcy court asking for permission to terminate its labor agreements; union calls on Delphi to drop its demand for steep cuts in wages and benefits; GM spun off Delphi six years ago, but thousands of Delphi workers still have right to return to GM if jobs are available; that is unlikely because GM plans to close all or part of 12 plants and eliminate 30,000 hourly jobs over three years (M)

headline: ONE OF THE GANG
abstract: Marsh & McLennan's new finance chief, M. Michele Burns, has spent most of her life in Georgia, but she will arrive at the company's headquarters in Manhattan in March with plenty of New York attitude about perks and money.     In her previous two jobs, at the Mirant Corporation and Delta Air Lines, she was paid handsomely even as her employers struggled. At Mirant, an Atlanta-based energy company now in its 17th month of bankruptcy court protection, she received $4.1 million over her 20-month tenure; Mirant will pay $4.1 million more in severance.

headline: A glimpse behind the hedge fund curtain
Boeing plans superjumbo to battle Airbus
Kurds Are Flocking to Kirkuk, Laying Claim to Land and Oil
abstract: Clusters of gray concrete houses dot the barren plains surrounding this city, like seedlings scattered here by winds blowing down from the mountainous Kurdish homeland to the north.     The villages are uniformly spartan, except for the red, green and white flag of Iraqi Kurdistan sprouting from many rooftops, even though this province is not officially part of the Kurdish autonomous region.

headline: 2 Years of Dinnertime Quiet, Thanks to the Do-Not-Call Registry
abstract: WE all know the feeling. It's dinnertime, or bedtime for the children, or the middle of a good television show and the phone rings. Is it your mom? Your work?     Or even worse -- is it the dreaded telemarketer who immediately reveals herself with the perky mispronunciation of your name?

headline: With multiple tours in combat, the odds dip
Annanurges talkson Kosovo
Attacks at U.S.-Based Hotels in Amman Were Minutes Apart
abstract: At least 57 people were killed and more than 300 injured in what appeared to be a coordinated attack by suicide bombers.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Ban On Gay Priests Not Absolute
abstract: A new Vatican instruction on homosexuals in Catholic seminaries would not ban all gay candidates outright but would place tighter restrictions on their admission than is often current practice, according to several news reports from Italy. Quoting a Vatican official, National Catholic Reporter, one of three outlets reporting on the document yesterday, said that the long-expected instruction was approved last month by Pope Benedict XVI and lays out three conditions in which seminaries should exercise ''prudential judgment'' on candidates: if they have been unable to be celibate for three years, if they are part of ''gay culture,'' or if their homosexual orientation is ''strong, permanent and univocal'' in a way that the all-male environment of a seminary would be too strong a risk. The document is expected to be released by November, the reports said.   Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: Briefs: Thousands protest president's longer term
Suicide Bombing Kills at Least 5, Israeli Police Say
abstract: The blast left the street covered with blood and overturned fruit crates as rescue workers rushed to scene.

headline: Corrections
abstract: The Square Feet article last Sunday, about the design of the Jay Monahan Center for Gastrointestinal Health in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to a facility being erected opposite it on East 70th Street. It is a new center for ambulatory care and medical education, not for ambulatory care alone, and it is being built by Weill Medical College of Cornell University, not by New York-Presbyterian Hospital.

headline: Memo Passed On; Job Is Lost
abstract: Freelance researcher at Conde Nast, Andrew Krucoff, loses his job, apparently because he leaked internal information to Gawker.com, Web site that makes fun of just about everything; Gawker breaks the news; photo (M)

headline: Revamping at Merck to Cut Costs
abstract: Merck & Co plans to close five manufacturing plants by 2008 and lay off 7,000 employees, about 11 percent of its work force, as it struggles with falling sales and profits; cuts are latest sign of problems faced by major drug makers as patents on some of their most profitable medicines expire; Merck in June will begin to face low-priced generic competition on Zocor, cholesterol-lowering drug that is its top-selling medicine, with sales of $4.5 billion expected in 2005; about 3,500 of jobs Merck plans to eliminate are in US, with rest overseas; layoffs will save company total of almost $4 billion by 2010, or $1 billion a year; Merck's chief executive Richard T Clark says layoffs and plant closings, which will cost about $2 billion by time they are finished in 2008, are only part of broader overhaul of Merck's corporate structure; Merck will announce reorganization of its research and sales divisions on Dec 15; company's former pristine image has been sullied by thousands of lawsuits over Vioxx, painkiller that Merck stopped selling in September 2004 after clincial trial showed Vioxx could cause heart attacks (M)

headline: Finding Savings Around the Fire
abstract: ERIC GEIGER thinks of the wood stove he just bought for his family's home in Norfolk, Mass., as an investment with benefits. Because the cost of natural gas is expected to soar this winter, he has bought a fireplace insert, a wood stove designed to fit into an existing fireplace.      ''When we heard that fuel costs were going to go up 50 percent, that fueled us to go get it,'' said Mr. Geiger, 45, a handyman partial to puns.

headline: South Korean Tells Japan's Leader to Stop Visiting Shrine
abstract: President Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea urged Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan to stop visiting a nationalistic Japanese war memorial in a meeting here between the leaders on Friday, saying the visits raised fears of a revival of Japanese militarism.     The bilateral talks, which took place on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting, took place just a month after Mr. Koizumi's latest trip to the Yasukuni Shrine, a memorial that commemorates Japan's war dead, including high-ranking war criminals from World War II. The visit aggravated Japan's already strained relations with its Asian neighbors.

headline: Meet a New Mercury, Enjoy a Free Coffee
abstract: With car shoppers browsing so often online, they are less likely to visit showrooms and fall under the spell of that new-car smell and gleam. So marketers of the new Mercury Milan aren't waiting for you to come to the cars; they are coming to you, and buying you a cup of coffee.      The so-called random acts promotion was introduced on a recent Friday morning in Philadelphia, where regulars at Mums & Pops Cafe got their morning coffee free.

headline: North Korean reactors canceled
Nintendo sales fall, but forecast rises
Socialists in France bury their differences
Puppies to Pet, Monsters to Battle, Movies to Make
abstract: THIS will be remembered as a notable year for gaming hardware, featuring the release of Sony's PlayStation Portable and Microsoft's Xbox 360. In terms of games themselves, this year has not measured up to last year.     Some brilliant games have emerged, like Resident Evil 4, God of War and Jade Empire, but these have been interspersed with others that have not reached above pretty darn good. Still, some amazing games have turned up.    NINTENDOGS       For a while I thought Nintendo's double-screened DS hand-held device was destined to be a cute, pointless gimmick. I was proved wrong this summer. Game designers showed that the DS touch screen could heighten the game experience with such titles as Advance Wars: Dual Strike; Trace Memory; Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney; and, most notably, the puppy simulator Nintendogs. When I first heard of a game in which you raise dogs I thought it sounded dumb, but as those puppies squirmed happily as I petted the touch screen and sat when I shouted ''sit'' into the DS microphone, I was proved wrong once again. Easily the most adorable game of the year.     (Developed and published by Nintendo for Nintendo DS; $30; for all ages.)    GUILD WARS  An increasing number of multiplayer online role-playing games now exist in which a player wanders the countryside battling monsters, running errands and looking for better weapons and more powerful spells. And while I was almost as impressed with this year's City of Villains, it lost out in my heart to the deeper game play of Guild Wars. With an engaging battle system, gorgeous graphics and far more effective storytelling than is found in any other persistent-world game, Wars has become my all-time favorite in its class. It is also the perfect game for budget-conscious gamers; unlike the vast majority of such games, there is no monthly fee. If you are Donald Trump, saving $15 a month may not mean much, but I find it irresistible.     (Developed by ArenaNet and published by NCsoft for Windows 98/ME/2000/XP; $40; ages 13 and up.)    BURNOUT LEGENDS       The PlayStation Portable is the first hand-held console to nail racing games, and no game displays this better than Burnout Legends. The series' high-speed, crash-happy races are more exciting than anything else on the virtual road, so it is no surprise that Burnout Revenge is the best racing game of the year for the Xbox and PlayStation 2. What is amazing is that Legends brings the same intense, manic energy to something that fits in your pocket.      (Developed by Criterion and published by Electronic Arts; $50; for ages 10 and up.)    PHOENIX WRIGHT: ACE ATTORNEY       The most outrageous episodes of ''Ally McBeal'' exhibited a more faithful portrayal of the legal system than Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney does. In Phoenix Wright, perjury is treated as mildly inappropriate, and witnesses receive great leeway if they hand the judge a box lunch. But if this detective-adventure game gets every point of law wrong, it does get every aspect of game play right, with intelligent puzzles and wildly funny dialogue threaded through interrelated stories filled with improbable plot twists. It is fortunate that the game, my favorite of the year, comes with its own lawyer: anything this fun is bound to be illegal.     (Developed and published by Capcom for Nintendo DS; $30; for ages 13 and up.)    F.E.A.R.       A perfect combination of spooky chills and frenetic thrills, F.E.A.R. is everything you want in a first-person shooter, unless, that is, you want a plot that holds together. While the narrative is weak, the game moves the player assuredly through challenging firefights punctuated by ghostly scares. With a first-rate online multiplayer mode, F.E.A.R. is the most necessary shooter of the year. It's also a game that demands the most from your computer; you can buy it for $40, but if you want to play F.E.A.R. at maximum detail level, budget an extra $1,500 for a new computer.     (Developed by Monolith Productions and published by Vivendi Universal Games for Windows 2000/XP; $60 (DVD) or $40 (CD); for ages 17 and up.)    THE MOVIES       The Movies is two games bundled together. One is a terrific tycoon game where you take on the role of a Hollywood mogul, keeping your actors happy and producing award-winning films. The other is a moviemaking game that lets you create cinema scene by scene and upload the results to movies.lionhead.com. My favorite game-based movie so far is ''Scholastic Films: Intelligent Design,'' which hilariously outlines the evils of empirical reasoning. The game part of The Movies is about building a powerhouse studio, but for aspiring filmmakers the game is about something else entirely: getting your film listed as the most popular on the game's Web site.      (Developed by Lionhead Studios and published by Activision for Windows 98/ME/2000/XP; $60 (DVD) or $50 (CD); for ages 13 and up.)    GUITAR HERO       Guitar Hero may or may not be the greatest music game ever, but it is certainly the coolest. While Dance Dance Revolution has people frenetically stamping the floor, and Karaoke Revolution Party emulates the wacky joy of real karaoke, Guitar Hero has the player churning out grinding, wailing, crunchy guitar riffs. Sure, all you are really doing is pushing buttons on a plastic guitar peripheral, but play the game for a half-hour and you'll be so convinced you're Jimi Hendrix that when you go outside you'll wonder where your groupies went.     (Developed by Harmonix and published by RedOctane for PlayStation 2; $70 including guitar controller; for ages 13 and up.)    FIRE EMBLEM: THE SACRED STONES       The folks at Intelligent Systems have had a great year churning out extraordinary turn-based strategy games. Besides the standout Nintendo DS game Advance Wars: Dual Strike, they created two first-rate games in the Fire Emblem series, one for GameCube and one for Game Boy Advance. The strategy role-playing game Fire Emblem: The Sacred Stones is the best Game Boy Advance title of the year. Soldiers' strengths and weaknesses are balanced beautifully. By throwing out the role-playing tradition that allows you to resuscitate fallen warriors, the game makes your every decision feel as if it's a matter of life and death. Intelligent Systems understands perfectly the nature of hand-held games: they are designed so you can stop playing at a moment's notice, but so compelling that you hate to do so.     (Developed by Intelligent Systems and published by Nintendo; $30; for all ages.)    BROTHERS IN ARMS: ROAD TO HILL 30       First-person shooters make battles immersive and chaotic; strategy games make the same battles cerebral exercises in planning. Some games try to do both, like the interesting Kingdom Under Fire: The Crusaders, but no game has done this quite as elegantly as Road to Hill 30. This game lets you crawl across the battlefield and fire on the enemy, but you can also zoom to a bird's-eye view of the battlefield, letting you map a strategy, which often involves having the rest of your squad pin down the enemy with gunfire while you sneak behind them. It's still to a great degree an intellectual exercise, but one with a visceral punch.     (Developed by Gearbox Software and published by Ubisoft for PlayStation 2, Xbox, Windows 2000/XP; sequel is $50, but the original has been marked down; for ages 17 and up.)    RESIDENT EVIL 4       Not many games can terrify players for an entire year, but the horror survival game Resident Evil 4 frightened GameCube owners in January and did the same for PlayStation 2 owners in October. The game is a radical departure from the series, retaining the creepy atmosphere but replacing shuffling zombies with spry, homicidal villagers and racing the player through wonderfully varied game play. Changes can be scary, but these turned out so well that they are the only thing in the game that won't give you a fright.     (Developed and published by Capcom; $40; for ages 17 and up.)

headline: Briefly: Romney won't seek 2nd term as governor
Iraqi Insurgent Blamed for Bombings in Jordan
abstract: The leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, dispatched three men, and possibly a woman as well, from Iraq to carry out the suicide bombing attacks here on Wednesday night, Jordanian security officials said Saturday.     Jordanian security, they said, has foiled some 150 attempted attacks by Mr. Zarqawi's group since April 2004 -- and another 10 this year alone. The officials spoke on the condition that they not be identified because their work is covert.

headline: EU leaders agree on budget
Briefly: 3 people are stabbed near the White House
Israel calls northern Gaza area no-go zone
Sharon and Abbas Delay Meeting Because of Disagreements
abstract: The two sides could not agree on the release of Palestinian prisoners and Israeli troops pullbacks in the West Bank.

headline: Senator calls for fairness on Alito
A.M.D. Chooses Agencies Owned by WPP Group
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices in Sunnyvale, Calif., has named two agencies owned by the WPP Group to handle duties on its account, with spending estimated at $20 million.     The San Francisco office of Y&R, part of the Young & Rubicam Brands division of WPP, will serve as the lead agency for North American advertising and marketing communications. The San Francisco office of the Mediaedge:cia unit of WPP will handle the media part of the account.

headline: How to Sell Body Sprays to Teenagers? Hint: It's Not Just Cleanliness
abstract: ADVERTISERS long ago mastered the trick of playing on teenage insecurity. For years, they hawked acne products like Oxy and Clearasil with ubiquitous ads in print and on television, convincing teenagers that clearing their skin would improve their social status.      Now, the acne parade is giving way to a new marketing effort tackling another teenage fear: sweat. Body sprays and deodorants are being aimed at teenage boys and girls with a new zeal, from the Axe line by Unilever to Tag from Gillette and Secret Body Spray from Procter & Gamble. The body sprays Tag and Axe have taken a nearly identical selling approach, telling teenage boys that using the products will make them irresistible to the opposite sex.

headline: Blair condemns Iran on terrorism and Israel
Ireland shaken by sex abuse report
Concern Over Higher Rates Pushes Share Prices Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 82.29 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,805.87; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 8 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,249.48; Nasdaq composite index is little changed, rising 0.11 point, to 2,232.82; price and yield for 10-year US Treasury note noted; graph; chart on key US interest rates (M)

headline: With Interest: Planting the seeds for compromise
British Phone Executive Is Content to Observe Mergers
abstract: Deal fever may be threatening to overtake the European telecommunications industry, but Ben Verwaayen, the chief executive of BT, wants nothing to do with it.      ''I firmly believe this is an industry that has to reinvent its reason for existing,'' Mr. Verwaayen said in a recent interview at his company's headquarters here. ''Companies will have to change what they need to sell, change how they sell, and therefore change their culture.''

headline: New Suitor Makes Higher Bid for Troubled Heart Device Maker
abstract: Boston Scientific makes surprise bid to acquire Guidant Corp for about $25 billion in bold move to snatch Guidant from Johnson & Johnson Inc, which last month agreed to buy device maker for $21.5 billion; offer could spark battle for control of Guidant; Johnson & Johnson in November sharply lowered it original $76-a-share offer for Guidant to $63.08 a share, after declaring that recent recalls and probes involving its heart devices damaged company's prospects; Boston's Scientific's bid, which is worth $72 a share in cash and stock, reflects its view that Guidant's problems are manageable and overshadowed by potential for vast profits, particularly from defibrillators; Boston Scientific's chief executive James R Tobin comments (M)

headline: Merkel Takes Over as Germany's Chancellor
abstract: Angela Merkel, the leader of the conservative Christian Democratic Party, is the first woman to hold the position.

headline: Head of Tokyo exchange quits over trade mishap
Powerful Earthquake Strikes Iran, Killing 10
abstract: The quake caused major destruction in seven villages in southern Iran and was also felt in Oman and the United Arab Emirates.

headline: ECB lifts rate for first time in 5 years
On Advertising: Tense times in cellphone industry
Denmark detains 4 in plot inquiry
Rail strike in France is new test for leaders
Blair Ally Resigns in Britain Amid 2nd Scandal
abstract: David Blunkett resigned from the cabinet today after acknowledging mistakes in the way he handled private business interests.

headline: South American Trade Bloc Moves to Admit Venezuela
abstract: Presidents and ministers from Mercosur, South America's biggest trade bloc, will meet Thursday and Friday to begin the process of granting membership to Venezuela, a move that business leaders fear could undermine efforts to ease regional trade and foster ties with other blocs.     At a meeting in Montevideo, Uruguay, the four members of the trade bloc -- Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay -- are expected to formally begin negotiations to bring Venezuela into Mercosur, a group that seeks to standardize tariffs and trade practices throughout the region.

headline: Sunnis Accuse Iraqi Military of Kidnappings and Slayings
abstract: Mounting evidence suggests Iraqi forces are carrying out executions in Sunni areas, even as US military pushes largely Shiite Iraqi security forces into larger role fighting insurgency; hundreds of accounts of killings and abductions emerge in recent weeks, mostly from Sunni civilians who say relatives were taken away by Iraqis in uniform without explanation; some bodies have been found with signs of torture, some have vanished and others have turned up alive in prison, including those found tortured in Interior Ministry bunker; Min Bayan Jabr and other officials deny government role but many claims are substantiated by human rights group and by Sunni leaders; one community group reports documenting death or disappearance of 700 Sunni civilians in last four months; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent ad account changes (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tightening Reins On Private Groups
abstract: Russia's lower house of Parliament gave final approval to legislation that would impose new government oversight for charities and other private organizations. Critics, at home and abroad, have complained that the legislation will allow the government to shut down organizations involved in political or other activities seen as critical of the Kremlin. The legislation still requires approval from the upper house, or Federation Council, and President Vladimir V. Putin's signature before becoming law. Mr. Putin has in the past vetoed controversial legislation that appeared to have Kremlin backing, but he has expressed support for the charity-oversight bill, saying it was needed to protect Russia from terrorism and foreign interference in domestic politics.   STEVEN LEE MYERS (NYT)

headline: 2 U.S. soldiers are charged with assault
A preference for stability or a flexible labor market?
Iran Is Reported To Continue Nuclear Activity
abstract: Iran reportedly resumes converting uranium despite European requests that it abstain from such work pending new round of negotiations on its nuclear activities; resumption is reported by diplomat close to International Atomic Energy Agency; Iran has apparently rebuffed European proposal that would allow Iran to do some converting of uranium provided product made would be sent outside country, presumably to Russia, for final processing that would allow it to be used to generate power (M)

headline: Norway keeping its distance fromEU
U.S. to base nuclear ship in Japan
Text: Bush's announcement
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid for Drax Is Dropped
abstract: The Constellation Energy Group, the owner of three nuclear plants in the United States, and the Blackstone Group buyout firm dropped a ¬£2.23 billion ($3.84 billion) bid for the British energy company Drax Group, which refused the offer because it was too low. A significant majority of Drax shareholders did not support the bid, the company said yesterday in a statement. The bidders for Drax, which operates Europe's biggest coal-fired power plant and is based in Selby, England, also included the Perry Capital hedge fund and the buyout company, Hellman & Friedman. Drax is the second British utility in two days to reject a takeover offer as inadequate as companies bet that soaring energy prices will raise earnings. Scottish Power, Britain's fifth-largest power provider, said on Tuesday that an ¬£11.3 billion ($19.4 billion) proposal from E.ON of Germany was too low, prompting E.ON to withdraw the bid.

headline: Briefly: Senators' bill punishes Japan on beef imports
In Sweden, a feminist locomotive stalls on the tracks
Israelis backtrack on Hamas
News Analysis: U.S. breaks with tradition in putting its subsidies into play
Sectarian Hatred Pulls Apart Iraq's Mixed Towns
abstract: Abu Noor's town had become so hostile to Shiites that his wife had not left the house in a month, his family could no longer go to the medical clinic and mortar shells had been lobbed at the houses of two of his religious leaders.      ''I couldn't open the door and stand in my yard,'' he said.

headline: Protesters block site in Alps for a 2nd day
World Briefings: Asia, Europe, Middle East
abstract: ASIA.

headline: New Israeli-Palestinian Violence Puts Truce in Doubt
abstract: Israel launched new airstrikes on Friday evening on northern Gaza, killing a Palestinian militant in his white Subaru and wounding another just after they had fired a rocket toward Israel, according to the Israeli Army, citing visual evidence from a helicopter and a drone.     The strikes came as Defense Minister Shaul Mofaz expressed doubt that Israel could make peace ''with the present leadership of the Palestinians,'' given their reluctance to crack down on terrorist groups. He added, ''I don't think a Palestinian state will see the light of day in the coming years.''

headline: Ex-Chief of Qwest Is Indicted
abstract: Joseph P Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, is indicted on charges of insider trading involving stock sales worth more $100 million; allegedly sold more than 2.5 million shares of Qwest stock in first half of 2001, knowing that company was in danger of missing its financial targets; Nacchio photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Former Chief Executive of Refco Is Charged With Securities Fraud  The former chairman and chief executive of Refco, one of the world's largest commodities brokerage firms, has been charged with securities fraud, accused of hiding $435 million in the months before the company was taken public. The executive, Phillip R. Bennett, 57, of Gladstone, N.J., was arrested Tuesday night and charged in a criminal complaint yesterday by federal prosecutors in Manhattan. [Page C1.]    Apple Unveils a Video-Playing IPod  Apple Computer introduced an iPod that can play video -- along with an online shop to fill it with television shows, short films and music videos. [C1.]    Toy Industry Moves Into Consumer Electronics  Having failed to beat the electronics industry, the toy business will join it in a big way this Christmas, offering everything from cellphones for 6-year-olds to video projectors for 8-year-olds in an effort to hold on to children who are casting aside Lego and G.I. Joe to play with their parents' gadgets. [C1.]    Google and Comcast May Seek to Buy Part of AOL  Google and Comcast are in talks with Time Warner to buy a portion of America Online, according to several people with knowledge of the negotiations. The joint bid was widely seen as a way to head off Microsoft, which has also been negotiating to buy a minority stake in AOL. [C1.]    British Court Upholds One of Pfizer's Lipitor Patents  A British court provided a mixed verdict for Pfizer on a crucial patent dispute, upholding one of the company's patents on Lipitor, its best-selling cholesterol-lowering medicine, but invalidating a second one. Shares of Pfizer, the world's biggest drug company, closed up more than 2 percent in the United States after the verdict was announced. Still, they are trading near an eight-year low, in part because of investors' concerns about a related Lipitor patent challenge in the United States, a far larger market. Market Place [C3.]    Trade Negotiators to Meet Again Next Week  Trade ministers ended three days of talks aimed at overhauling farm subsidies and import tariffs without reaching a deal, but they agreed to meet again next week. [C4.]    Automakers' Sales Are Soaring in Russia  With revenues from Russia's oil exports pulsing through the economy, car sales in the country have surged, benefiting global automakers. [C4.]    Major U.S. Stock Gauges End the Day Lower  The Dow Jones industrial average fell 36.26 points, to 10,216.91. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 7.19 points, to 1,177.68, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 23.62 points, or 1.15 percent, to 2,037.4. [C11.]    U.S. Regulators Approve Sale of Flu Vaccine  Federal drug regulators announced that they had approved for sale about 1.5 million doses of flu vaccines from Chiron, raising hopes that there will be ample vaccine supplies this flu season. [A16.]    Amtrak Board Approves Separate Unit for Northeast  The Amtrak board has approved an essential step in the Bush administration plan to break up the railroad, voting to carve out the Northeast Corridor, the tracks between Boston and Washington, as a separate division. [A14.]    Charges Are Dropped Against Former Broker  The New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, dropped criminal charges against a former broker at Bank of America, Theodore C. Sihpol III, left, whom he had accused of helping a hedge fund trade mutual funds illegally. Earlier in the day, Mr. Sihpol agreed to a $200,000 fine and a five-year ban from the securities industry to resolve related fraud charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission. He neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. [C3.]    Northwest Seeks Approval to Void Labor Pacts  Northwest Airlines said that it had asked a bankruptcy judge for permission to void its labor contracts if its employee unions do not agree to concessions worth $1.4 billion a year. [C5.]    Ad Campaign Promotes What Is Hard to Say  Grand Marnier has introduced an advertising campaign this fall to sell its $225-a-bottle vintage liqueur, Cuv√©e du Cent Cinquantenaire. The fact that the name of the liqueur is hard to pronounce is part of the marketing. [C3.]    Makers of Tablet PC's Go After the Masses  Tablet PC's, with and without pens, have taken hold in some segments like education and health care, and computer makers continue to introduce models with features aimed at general consumers, professionals and management-level business users. Circuits. [C7.]

headline: China warns of Harbin penalties
Cheaper roaming: One phone but two numbers
Immigrant Rioting Flares in France for Ninth Night
abstract: France's worst urban violence in a decade exploded for a ninth night on Friday as bands of youths roamed the immigrant-heavy, working-class suburbs of Paris, setting fire to dozens of cars and buildings while the government struggled over the violence and the underlying frustrations fueling it.     The unrest, which has also spread to other parts of France with large North African and Arab populations, prompted the American and Russian governments to warn citizens visiting Paris to avoid its poor, outlying neighborhoods. France reduced train service to Charles de Gaulle Airport after two trains became targets of rioters earlier in the week.

headline: S.& P. Cuts G.M. Rating to Lowest in 52 Years
abstract: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services cut its rating on General Motors' debt two more notches into junk status on Monday, putting the automaker at the lowest level in the 52 years that S.& P. has been assessing its creditworthiness.     And if G.M.'s financial position continues to deteriorate, Scott Sprinzen, an automobile analyst for Standard & Poor's, said, it is ''not far-fetched'' that G.M. may ultimately be forced to seek bankruptcy protection to restructure its debt and its labor contracts.

headline: Judge Backs Arbiter Order Against Nokia
abstract: By Dow Jones/AP.

headline: A Nervous Secularist in Basra
abstract: Scene in Basra, Iraq, on Election Day; Majid al-Sari of Basra, candidate from one of Iraq's smaller parties, expects to win seat in Iraq's first full-term Parliament; he is secular Shiite belonging to party led by Sunni Arab; says he faces threats from both Sunni insurgents and shadowy Shiite militias that wield influence in Basra's police force; photo (M)

headline: Hilton Bid for British Hotels
abstract: The Hilton Hotels Corporation, the third-largest American hotelier, has offered to buy the lodging unit of the Hilton Group of Britain and reunite the businesses after four decades.      Hilton Group, based in Watford, England, is considering the offer, a spokeswoman, Linda Bain, said yesterday. Shares of the British company gained as much as 19 percent on investor optimism the deal will allow the company to focus on its faster-growing Ladbrokes gambling unit.

headline: Dutch will open terror trial of 14 Muslims
Chechen rebels mount major attack
At Hussein Trial, Witness Tells of Torture
abstract: A woman said intelligence agents had tortured her and flung her into Baghdad's notorious Abu Ghraib jail in the early 1980's when she was just 16.

headline: New Rites of Passage
abstract: Toy industry will be pushing electronics for preteens this Christmas season in bid to lift sales, which are down 5 percent this year after dropping 3 percent in 2003 and again in 2004 amid brutal price wars between Toys 'R' Us and Wal-Mart Stores; push to sell consumer electronics to preteens is touching off debate about whether products qualify as toys, as manufacturers contend, and whether it is wise to break down one of last barriers between children's play and adult technology; some electronic items for preteens that will be offered detailed; photos (M)

headline: France's opposition struggles to cohere
Entr'acte: An old weapon revived: U.S. cultural diplomacy
Suicide bombers kill scores at police academy
Jury absolves Merck & Co. in Vioxx user's heart attack
Campaigning for Parliamentary Elections in Iraq Kicks Off
Key rates
