abstract: At least 8 people were killed and 20 wounded Friday in an attack on a congregation of a minority Muslim sect, the Qadiani, also known as Ahmadis, who are considered heretics by orthodox Muslims.      The attack, in central Pakistan, raised fresh concerns about the protection of minorities in Pakistan, a majority Sunni Muslim state.

headline: Pacific nations call for trade deal
New Offer by Europe on Trade Is Assailed
abstract: The European Union on Friday made what it called its most sweeping offer yet to cut its agricultural tariffs in an effort to prevent the collapse of global trade talks.     But the proposal came under immediate attack from all directions: from the United States and Brazil for being inadequate and from France for going too far.

headline: THE CHURN
abstract: Deal Makers       Morgan Stanley is advising Allergan on its $3.2 billion offer for Inamed. Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher is Allergan's legal adviser. Inamed, which says it is weighing the offer, is being advised by J. P. Morgan Chase and the law firm of Morrison & Foerster. In March, Inamed agreed to an offer from Medics Pharmaceutical, which is being advised by Deutsche Bank Securities and the law firm of Latham & Watkins.

headline: Echoes of 1986? Not in Bush's Tax Reform Panel
abstract: TWENTY years ago, President Ronald Reagan found himself politically weakened by large budget deficits, the Nicaraguan contra imbroglio and a Congress that was partly controlled by his Democratic opponents.     Yet Mr. Reagan managed to push through a sweeping overhaul of the tax code that, at least for a few years, stood as a victory of bipartisan common sense over high-priced special interests.

headline: Briefly: House passes bills to drill in Arctic and cut deficits
Needs of Quake Survivors Overwhelm India and Pakistan
abstract: With temperatures plummeting, India faced an acute shortage of tents, leaving earthquake survivors in villages of Kashmir to spend their seventh night outdoors.

headline: DataBank; Stocks Climb for the Third Week in a Row
abstract: The stock market rose for the third consecutive week, buoyed by strong corporate earnings and by a decline in the price of oil.     Oil prices fell 5 percent during the week, with a barrel of crude for December delivery ending at $57.53 in New York on Friday, its lowest close since July -- before the crushing blows of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita.

headline: Car Bomb Kills 30 in Iraq
abstract: A suicide car bomb exploded near an American convoy at the entrance to the main hospital in Mahmudiya, killing at least 30 Iraqis and wounding dozens of others. In other attacks, 5 American soldiers and at least 15 more Iraqis were killed. Page A22.

headline: Afghan Parliament Opens, and Finds Democracy Is a Bit Untidy
abstract: Two houses of Afghan parliament hold first sessions, providing glimpse of untidy Afghan-style democracy; upper chamber, House of Elders, ignores rules of procedure and lower chamber, House of the People, bogs down in debate; Sebaghatullah Mojadeddi is elected chairman of House of Elders (S)

headline: Trial resumes without Saddam
Price Tag of Guidant Is Lowered
abstract: Johnson & Johnson will pay $4 billion less than originally agreed to acquire Guidant, troubled maker of implantable heart devices, under revised $21.5 billion deal; new agreement is apparent acknowledgment by Guidant of how significantly its outlook has declined because of disclosures about product problems, device recalls, investigations and lawsuits; move clears way for Johnson & Johnson to become major player in market for defibrillators and pacemakers, lucrative product area it has long sought to enter (M)

headline: Miers withdraws her nomination
Iran President Risks New Rebuff on His Nominee for Oil Minister
abstract: Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad risks second rebuff from Parliament by nominating another little-known figure for post of oil minister; nominee, Sadeq Mahsouli, is member of Republican Guard who is said to have no experience in oil business; Foreign Min Manouchehr Mottaki announces that Ahmadinejad would replace more than 40 of Iran's ambassadors by Mar, another move expected to bring criticism (M)

headline: A Political Rival of Mubarak Loses His Seat in Parliament
abstract: Pres Hosni Mubarak's strongest political foe, Ayman Nour, loses his parliamentary seat in elections to candidate from ruling party; Nour claims his supporters and members of his party had been harassed and intimidated by his opponent's supporters; calls election 'a farce'; he drew world attention when he was arrested three months after he formed his party; case was seen as effort to silence outspoken opposition figure; government denies having interfered in election; photo (M)

headline: Probe Supports Allegations of C.I.A. Prisons in Europe
abstract: A Swiss investigator said that evidence suggests American agents kidnapped and illegally transferred terror suspects.

headline: Putin's Candidates Sweep Chechnya Elections
abstract: First parliamentary elections in Chechnya since 1999 result in overwhelming victory for party loyal to Russian President Vladimir V Putin; Putin praises results as final step to order in republic, while Chechnya's separatists call election farce (S)

headline: AMEX HANGOVER
abstract: What's worse for a company: A chief executive who gets a $241,000 bill for charges on his corporate credit card for one evening at a strip club? Or one who refuses to pay, saying he spent a fraction of that, leading to a lawsuit that earns him the nickname ''Lap Dunce'' in a New York tabloid?      Just ask Savvis Communications, which placed its C.E.O., Robert A. McCormick, on an unpaid leave after American Express sued for nonpayment. Mr. McCormick said he spent only about $20,000, according to the suit; the club, Scores, says it has signed receipts for every cent.

headline: Bush backs EU efforts to cut agricultural subsidies
Thomas H. Lee Partners Files Suit Against Former Refco Executives
abstract: Thomas H Lee Partners, private equity firm, sues former executives of Refco, collapsed futures and commodities brokerage firm, seeking to recover at least $245 million of $453 million paid by three Lee funds to buy 57 percent of Refco in 2004; names Philip R Bennett, Tone Grant and Santo C Maggio; Bennett photo (M)

headline: China keeping closer eye on phone text messages
As Election Nears, Canada's Prime Minister Proposes Tax Cuts
abstract: In the opening salvo of the national election campaign, Prime Minister Paul Martin's wobbly Liberal government on Monday proposed more than $25 billion dollars in corporate and personal tax cuts over the next five years.     Coming two weeks after a federal inquiry found evidence of money laundering and campaign finance irregularities by the Liberal Party in recent years, the tax proposals seemed intended to refocus debate in time for a general election that will probably take place in January.

headline: Yahoo takes on Skype with low-cost calling
Beating a path to British shrines
'Open skies' progress
MTV and movie bolster Viacom
Election in Moscow testsnational issues
Currencies: Dollar rise resumes on rate speculation
Three Sizes of Data to Go, All in the Same Small Package
abstract: The race to cram more data into less space has led Memorex to increase the capacity of its tiny Mega TravelDrive hard drives from four gigabytes to as much as eight gigabytes.      The Mega TravelDrives, measuring 1.75 by 1.96 by 0.56 inches, have built-in U.S.B. connectors that can be folded in protectively when not in use, and blue- light-emitting diodes that flash during data transfers.

headline: Honeywell Buys Maker of Gas Detectors
abstract: Honeywell International, the world's largest maker of airplane cockpit controls, agreed to buy First Technology of Britain for about ¬£207 million ($366 million) to expand in gas detection gear.     Honeywell, based in Morris Township, N.J., offered 275 pence a share for First Technology, 35 percent more than the closing price on Dec. 9, the last trading day before the British company said it had received a takeover offer. Honeywell will also assume ¬£107 million (about $190 million) in debt.

headline: Public pensions go more private, OECD finds
Briefly: U.S. execution brings total since 1977 to 999
DaimlerChrysler Profit Falls; Sales Improve in 2 Divisions
abstract: DaimlerChrysler says third-quarter profit dropped by more than one-fifth even as business steadily improved in its Chrysler and Mercedes-Benz divisions; earnings fell 21 percent, to $910 million; DaimlerChrysler discloses that Securities and Exchange Commission served it with subpoena in September seeking information in connection with continuing investigation of General Motors' pension accounting (M)

headline: Ties to Industry Cloud a Clinic's Mission
abstract: Dr. Eric J. Topol, a cardiologist, has been perhaps the most public face of the prestigious Cleveland Clinic Foundation, a prominent medical center regarded as one of the nation's best.      Not shy in the media spotlight, Dr. Topol has cultivated the persona of a Naderesque crusader against drugs he deems dangerous, as well as their makers. Some of his most impassioned criticism has been aimed at Merck and its drug Vioxx, the painkiller the company withdrew from the market over questions about its safety. But he has also been outspoken recently about other drugs.

headline: Cheney says 9/11 changed the rules
Indonesian Students Skeptical About U.S. Policy, but Not America
abstract: President Bush's designated hitter for America's image in the Muslim world, Karen P. Hughes, and 16 students from Indonesia's largest Islamic university shared a stage here on Friday morning. But that was about all they shared.     Ms. Hughes, the under secretary of state for public diplomacy, began by inviting the students to tell her what they were studying and what their hopes were.

headline: Control of Quake Relief Is Gamble for Pakistan Army and Chief
abstract: News analysis: Pakistani Army, country's most powerful institution, is dominating every aspect of earthquake relief; risk to army is that if relief is not distributed efficiently or fairly, Gen Pervez Musharraf's government will feel the heat (M)

headline: Briefly: Plane carrying 117 crashes after takeoff
Australian Officials Accuse 16 Men of Plotting Terrorist Attacks
abstract: Sixteen men arrested during sweeping raids in Sydney and Melbourne, Australia, were charged Tuesday with belonging to a terrorist organization and plotting terrorist attacks.     The men had chemicals similar to those used in the London bombings this summer, officials said, but no evidence has emerged linking the men to any outside group like Al Qaeda or Jemaah Islamiyah.

headline: St. Jude Medical to Acquire Competitor
abstract: St. Jude Medical, the nation's third-largest maker of implantable heart defibrillators, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a smaller rival, Advanced Neuromodulation Systems, or A.N.S., for about $1.3 billion in cash.     A.N.S. specializes in devices that deliver very small, precise doses of electricity or drugs to nerve sites to treat patients suffering from chronic pain or other nervous system disorders. The deal would give St. Jude a foothold in a fast-growing market. A.N.S. also makes products to stimulate spinal cord activity.

headline: Placing Ads in Some Surprising Spaces
abstract: THE parade of mainstream advertisers starting to use nontraditional media is growing almost as long as that march through Manhattan yesterday sponsored by a certain department store.      Joining the throng are the Budget Rent a Car unit of the Cendant Corporation and the toy maker Hasbro. Budget turned to blogs to promote a contest with a scavenger hunt motif, buying advertisements on 177 blogs bearing names like BuzzMachine, Gizmodo, Jossip, Largehearted Boy, Overheard in New York, Stereogum and The Superficial.

headline: Chief of Quanta Capital, a Reinsurer, Resigns After Storm Losses
abstract: Quanta Capital Holdings, a Bermuda-based reinsurer, said yesterday that its chief executive, Tobey J. Russ, had resigned.      The company recently posted a quarterly loss because of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita.

headline: Wireless Know-How Helps Crisis Victims Reach Loved Ones
abstract: MAC DEARMAN is a gregarious storyteller with deep ties in rural northeastern Louisiana. So when he saw a crowd outside a local church the day after Hurricane Katrina hit, he stopped by to see who had died.     What he found instead intensified his involvement in the world of wireless networks. At the church in Mangham, La., there was a sign, Welcome Katrina Evacuees; inside, newcomers from Waveland, Miss., and New Orleans were crying because they could not find their families.

headline: Iran asks Russia to clarify fuel plan
Iraqi Civilians Killed in Rebel-Held House Bombed by U.S.
abstract: It was the first acknowledgement of civilian casualties since an operation along the Syrian border began last Saturday.

headline: Entr'acte: Bombings' fallout puts arts world on defensive
Moscow vote mirrors a nationwide dispute
South Korea's shift to foreign investment
U.N. Report Says Syria Is Arming Palestinian Militias
abstract: Lebanon is facing an "increasing influx of weaponry and personnel from Syria" to Palestinian militia groups, a United Nations report said today.

headline: Sri Lanka conflict goes 'from bad to worse'
Traces from bombs tested in New Delhi
Buying Used Just Could Turn Out to Be the Next New Thing
abstract: The idea of buying used goods, especially when advanced around the holidays, sounds rather pathetic, as if one is living a real-life version of a Charlie Brown Christmas. Who would want something used?     The answer is anyone who wants to save money. In a host of categories, from books to compact discs to cars, it doesn't make sense to buy new anymore. Now, there are robust marketplaces for used products, which are just as good and significantly cheaper. New technologies make it easier for shoppers to compare prices from a large number of sellers.

headline: ECB hints at limits to scope of rate rises
German Court Convicts 4 in Plot Against Jewish Targets
abstract: The Middle Eastern men were convicted today of belonging to a terror group linked to Al Qaeda and of plotting attacks.

headline: GE and Honeywell lose merger appeal
News Analysis: Frenchness: Riots show one size doesn't fit all
Ethiopian Protesters Killed as East African Clashes Spread
abstract: Ethiopian security forces clash with protesters on streets of Addis Ababa, killing at least two dozen people and wounding 150 in escalation of discord over results of May parliamentary elections; witnesses claim hundreds of police officers and soldiers rounded up young men believed to be tied to opposition that is challenging governing party's victory; Information Min Berhanu Hailu voices regret about violence but disputes notion that police were quick to resort to force; claims opposition politicians instigated violence; photo (M)

headline: Attention All Employees: Ford Is Serious About Change
abstract: My way or the highway, Ford Motor's chief executive has told the company's employees.     In an e-mail message sent to employees on Monday, the chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., said those who could not support the company's drive for innovation should find something else to do.

headline: Entry Level: In the book market, the first word counts
Alaska Before You Die
abstract: Advertising, for the most part, avoids death as a subject, for obvious reasons: Putting people in the mood to buy something is rarely the occasion to remind them of their mortality.

headline: Hard-line Sri Lankan president swears in hawkish prime minister
Parmalat Creditors Approve a Return to Trading Shares
abstract: Creditors of the dairy company Parmalat Finanziaria have voted overwhelmingly to convert $14 billion of debt into shares. The move paves the way for the company to return to stock market trading this week, almost two years after it filed Italy's biggest bankruptcy case.     Over the weekend, Judge Giuseppe Coscioni, of the Parma, Italy, bankruptcy court, approved a vote by 72 percent of Parmalat creditors in favor of a listing.

headline: United hiring flight attendants
Briefs: Refco failed to disclose millions in accounts
For the Coffee Palate Too Refined for a Certain Large Chain
abstract: YOU may think these entrepreneurs are crazy when they talk about selling coffee beans for 40 bucks a pound. When they tell you that properly prepared single-origin coffee varietals have as much depth and complexity and nuance as the finest pinot noirs. When they talk ''latte art,'' handing you a three-shot latte topped by an artistic memento -- a rosetta -- formed when perfectly textured black-brown espresso foam intermingles with the stiff froth of steam-blasted milk.      But such talk is the norm in the high-octane world of specialty roasted coffee, named by Entrepreneur magazine last May as one of the nation's fastest-growing niche markets. Nationwide there are some 300 middle- to high-end specialty coffee roasters-retailers. At the top of this heap sit 25 to 30 strivers for whom coffee is not simply a commodity but a profitable artisanal beverage, like microbrew beer or fine wine.

headline: Scrabble Kings Vie for Linguistic Superiority
abstract: Canadian mathematician Adam Logan wins eighth World Scrabble Championships, London, defeating Pakorn Nemitrmansuk, 465-426, in final game of playoff; highlights of play discussed; photo of competitors and winning board (M)

headline: Palestinians Threaten to Postpone Parliamentary Elections
abstract: The leadership said it might postpone elections if Israel insists on barring Palestinian voting in East Jerusalem.

headline: European Talks on Turkey Stall As Austria Insists on Lesser Role
abstract: European foreign ministers broke off last-minute emergency discussions on Sunday over admitting Turkey to the European Union, but agreed to continue Monday in the hope of being able to open direct talks with Turkey later that day.      The ministers failed to resolve a standoff over Austria's insistence that Turkey be offered less than full membership in the European Union.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LiDestri Foods names Greenstone/Fontana as national agency for its Santa Fe Packing Company brands; America Online names Attik as first agency of record for AIM instant-messaging services (S)

headline: Major blow to Israeli coalition
World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Dividing Up Milosevic's Trial
abstract: Judges trying Slobodan Milosevic are evidently anxious to safeguard at least one part of his war crimes trial, which continues to be bogged down by the poor health of the former Yugoslav president. They propose to split up the enormous trial and to carve out the part, nearly complete, dealing with the 1999 war in Kosovo. This could lead to an early judgment. The rest of the case, dealing with the wars in Bosnia and Croatia, would then follow. Mr. Milosevic's high blood pressure and vascular problems once again forced the trial to stop this week, and judges have called hearings to discuss the proposed division of the trial on Tuesday.    Marlise Simons (NYT)

headline: Spaniards Making the Shift to the Mall
abstract: Like many middle-aged Spaniards, Javier Garc√≠a-Renedo grew up without a food court or an inflatable castle, or even a store directory telling him which way to go.     Mr. Garc√≠a-Renedo, 54, spent his childhood playing outdoors on the main street of the northern Spanish village of Reinosa. In fact, he saw his first shopping center in 1981, when he traveled to Long Island, the stomping ground of a generation of mall rats.

headline: 3 Sunni Leaders Form Alliance for Iraqi Elections
abstract: The move today signals an intent by Sunni Arabs to seriously engage in the political process in Iraq.

headline: Britain Urges End to Europe's Farm Subsidies
abstract: Gordon Brown, the chancellor of the British Exchequer, urged yesterday that Europe completely phase out subsidies, price supports and export refunds to its farmers to help unlock stalled global trade talks.     Speaking at a meeting of the Group of 7 finance ministers and central bankers in London, Mr. Brown proposed that the European Union overhaul what is known as the common agricultural policy, which sets subsidies and tariffs for its 25 member nations.

headline: Pleas made for calm after riots in England
Sunni Arab candidate is assassinated in Iraq
World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Jail Sentence For Judge In Crucifix Dispute
abstract: A judge was sentenced to seven months in jail for refusing to hear cases in protest of the presence of crucifixes in the nation's courtrooms. The judge, Luigi Tosti of Camerino, in central Italy, was convicted for failing to carry out his official duties. ''I was convicted because I am a minor-league citizen compared to Catholics,'' the judge said, declining to give his religion. He is appealing the verdict and is not required to begin his sentence unless those appeals fail.   Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: World Briefing: Middle East, Asia, Europe and Africa
abstract: MIDDLE EAST.

headline: Rains halt in Pakistan, but new landslides slow relief
Tamil Rebels Abduct 3 Sailors in Firefight with Sri Lankan Navy
abstract: The firefight at sea, off the northwestern coast, pushed the battered island nation ever closer to the precipice of war.

headline: ViewPoints: Batten down the hatches
Lawyers' Group Files Grievance Against Turkish Drinking Zones
abstract: Lawyers representing bar and restaurant owners in Ankara, Turkey, seek to prevent efforts to force establishments that serve alcohol to move outside city centers; secularists view such drinking zones as sign that governing party is returning to its Islamic roots, rekinding fears that there will be additional conservative moves to regulate social and political life; Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan backs regulation, saying it is duty of state to protect young people from alcohol addiction (M)

headline: Kazakhstan votes in presidential election amid accusations of dirty tricks
Democrat says Miers doesn't have votes now
Bhutan's king says he'll step down
Take This Into a Wi-Fi Hot Spot, and the World Is Your Phone Booth
abstract: Internet phone services like Vonage can offer numerous advantages over traditional phone lines: low monthly rates, call-forwarding and three-way calling, and the ability to phone from a home number anywhere. But the most exciting feature may be the ability to use open wireless networks.      With the Vonage F-1000 Wi-Fi phone from UT Starcom, Vonage subscribers, who pay about $25 a month for the service, can make calls anywhere within so-called open Wi-Fi hot spots, like those in airports and hotels. The phone is available on vonage.com for $129.99, before a $50 rebate.

headline: Trade Officials Haggle on Issues From Lower Tariffs to Cotton Subsidies
abstract: Trade negotiators from around the world moved behind closed doors in nearly around-the-clock meetings here as they homed in on reaching a narrowly worded four-part deal by Sunday night. But any agreement still faces formidable obstacles, officials said late Friday.     After spending much of the first three days of the conference denouncing one another at dozens of separate news conferences, many ministers -- including Rob Portman, the United States trade representative -- suddenly canceled public appearances in favor of long discussions with other ministers.

headline: Iranian's Oratory Reflects Devotion to '79 Revolution
abstract: Political analysts say Iranian Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's comments about Israel should be viewed in context of his aggressive work to roll clock back to early days of Iran's revolution; say he has moved to erase changes in foreign policy which evolved over eight years of rule by Pres Mohammad Khatami; says he seeks national unity through international isolation; notes his remarks coincided with firing of 40 ambassadors and diplomats, most of whom support some degree of improved ties with West, removal of reform-minded provincial governors, and replacement of pragmatists on Iran's nuclear negotiating team with members who hew to his thinking; Iranian analysts suggest he is trying to distract supporters who have begun to feel disappointed at his failure to provide financial relief; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: Canada has negotiated an airline trade liberalization agreement with the United States, Canada's transportation minister, Jean Lapierre, left, said yesterday. The deal stops short of allowing American airlines to move passengers between Canadian destinations. But it will make it easier for carriers based in the United States to transport passengers and cargo from Canadian cities to third countries. Canadian airlines will gain a similar right in the United States. ''It is my hope that this agreement will encourage the development of new markets, new services, lower prices and greater competition," Mr. Lapierre said in a statement. The agreement is scheduled to become effective on Sept. 1, 2006.   Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: Club Med posts a profit for 1st time in 5 years
Schr√∂der offers hint he will quit politics
Briefly: Katrina repair contracts reopened for bidding
British Tories Pick Leader to Challenge Blair at Polls
abstract: Britain's Conservatives chose David Cameron as their new leader and likely candidate for prime minister in next elections; he is 39-year-old product of some of country's most elite schools; his youthful looks and sleek self-confidence prompts comparisons to the young Tony Blair, who took over his Labor Party at age of 41; photo (M)

headline: A tax case could cost EU billions
Sometimes a Bumper Crop Is Too Much of a Good Thing
abstract: Illinois harvested 16 percent more corn per acre than expected despite parched-earth conditions, helping US produce its second-largest crop ever; agricultural technologies are ushering in era of surging production that is likely to outstrip global demand for years to come; bountiful harvest has only added to fundamental problem facing sector: too much success for its own good; seed technology allowed Midwest farmers to continue their relentless increase in production despite worst drought in Midwest in 17 years; even as businesses have cut employee benefits and have limited job security in face of more intense global competition, governments in rich countries have clung to one of oldest forms of trade protectionism: farm subsidies; chart; photos (M)

headline: Foreigners' hotels in Baghdad targets of blasts
The Front Lines in the Battle Against Avian Flu Are Running Short of Money
abstract: As the Bush administration and Congress prepare to spend billions of dollars to improve America's ability to combat avian flu, crucial needs are being left unmet on the front lines of the world's defenses against the disease, in some cases for lack of a few million dollars, international health officials said Saturday.     When Vietnam began detecting the disease in chickens nearly two years ago, it initially slaughtered and burned every chicken within three miles of an infected fowl in an effort to prevent the spread of the disease. But farmers, who received little compensation for slaughtered birds, strongly objected to sacrificing their flocks and sometimes sold their birds instead at roadside markets to unsuspecting drivers.

headline: Oracle Results in 2nd Quarter Meet Forecasts
abstract: The Oracle Corporation yesterday reported quarterly sales and profits that met Wall Street expectations as a strong performance in business software overcame sluggish growth in database software.     The results, though mixed, suggest that Oracle is achieving some success in its strategy of buying business software companies to supplement its main business in database software for corporations.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Inquiry Into Subsidies That Aided Berlusconi Company
abstract: European Union regulators threatened to outlaw more than 200 million euros ($240 million) in subsidies that helped a television broadcaster owned by Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy and the state-run RAI win digital TV viewers. The European Commission, the union's regulatory arm, said that government grants to help consumers buy or rent digital decoders in 2004 and 2005 may have given an unfair advantage to RAI and to Mediaset, owned by Mr. Berlusconi. Mediaset and RAI dominate Italy's television market. Both run three free-to-air channels, controlling about 90 percent of the market for TV advertising and viewers. ''The subsidy seems to help free-to-air operators enter the pay-TV market,'' said Europe's competition commissioner, Neelie Kroes, above. Sky Italia, a pay-TV satellite broadcaster, had complained about being ineligible for the aid. The investigation, likely to last a year or more, could result in Italy being forced to recover the money from the two million consumers who benefited.

headline: EU to lend aid to Mideast
The Psychology of Retailing
abstract: IF this holiday season you find yourself spending more on presents than you planned, we know just where to put the blame: store merchandisers, who have considered just about every way to separate you from your money.     In the current issue of Psychology Today, Michelle Bryner reveals some tricks of the trade:

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Deal With Libya On Deporting Terror Suspects
abstract: Libya agrees not to mistreat Libyan nationals deported by Britain on suspicion of involvement in terrorism; Britain is seeking similar agreements with Lebanon and Algeria (S)

headline: Court deals setback to Blackberry in the U.S.
Currencies: Dollar unchanged after U.S. retail report
BA looks at cuts in ground staff
Business Week Magazine to End Some Editions
abstract: Business Week magazine said Wednesday that it planned to stop publishing its English-language European and Asian editions at the end of the month and replace them with one global edition in English.     Business Week, which is owned by McGraw-Hill, said the magazine would rely on its Web site to enhance its international coverage. A spokeswoman, Kimberly Quinn, said about 60 jobs would be cut, mostly in the magazine's international operations.

headline: Advisory Commission Urges Congress to Get Tough on China Trade
abstract: A bipartisan advisory group plans to deliver a report to Congress today that is sharply critical of China's trade practices and endorses sanctions including a tariff on imports unless Beijing takes forceful steps to allow its currency to move in line with market forces.      The 222-page report, by the United States-China Economic and Security Review Commission, has more than 50 recommendations, including urging closer cooperation with China on coal-related programs intended to help wean both nations from their dependence on imported oil.

headline: I.B.M. to Buy Software Company for $865 Million
abstract: I.B.M. will buy Micromuse Inc., whose software is used to manage Internet-based computing networks that handle voice and video as well as data.

headline: Priest shortage dominates synod
Other Nations Hope to Loosen U.S. Grip on Internet
abstract: United Nations summit meeting in Tunis hears proposals for replacing US control of Internet through Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (Icann) with some sort of international structure; most of world, including European Union, believes that Internet is international resource whose center of gravity must move away from Washington; US dismisses European view as 'top down' control of Internet, as opposed to private-sector-led, 'bottom up' approach of Icann (M)

headline: Alito has hefty r√©sum√© and record that recalls Scalia's
Inflation Jumped 1.2% in September to a 25-Year High
abstract: Inflation rose to its highest monthly rate in more than 25 years in September, the government reported yesterday, but excluding a surge in energy costs, prices were restrained through most of the economy.     The consumer price index, which has been rising steadily through much of the year, jumped 1.2 percent last month, the fastest monthly pace since March 1980, the Labor Department reported. Still, the core inflation rate, which excludes volatile energy and food prices, rose just 0.1 percent, a rate that has stayed steady for the last four months.

headline: NOT MY JOB
abstract: With all the concern about keeping track of the tens of billions of dollars in federal reconstruction aid pouring into the Gulf Coast, one might think that fighting mismanagement and corruption would be high on the list of priorities for President Bush's handpicked on-site coordinator, Donald E. Powell, the former chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Commission.     Mr. Powell, however, doesn't see it that way. ''That's not my job,'' he said after speaking at an annual awards dinner held by American Banker, the trade newspaper, at the Palace Hotel in Manhattan. ''I'm involved in long-term planning. FEMA is overseeing the spending. FEMA is involved in the process right now of recovery. When it involves long-term spending, I will be involved.'' Ah, yes, the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Most reassuring.   Jane L. Levere

headline: Running a Seattle-Area Mall as a Family Business
abstract: It has been more than a decade, but Kemper Freeman Jr., the owner of the leading enclosed mall in the Pacific Northwest, can still taste his irritation as he recalls a briefing by a top Nordstrom executive to a group of young Wall Street analysts.     The analysts had probably all graduated at the top of their college classes, but they seemed indifferent to the finer points of retailing, said Mr. Freeman, a soft-spoken but talkative man of 64. ''They were not paying any attention,'' he said. ''It was like being in a room of peacocks. They were much more interested in showing off to each other.

headline: Russian forces storm rebel holdout
THE CHURN
abstract: Morgan Stanley, RBC Capital Markets and Goldman Sachs are advising Inco on its roughly $11 billion offer for Falconbridge; CIBC World Markets is advising Falconbridge; Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers advised Lincoln National on its $7.5 billion acquisition of Jefferson-Pilot; Fidelity Investments appoints John W Callahan president of Fidelity Institutional Retirement Services; succeeds William C Carey, who recently became president of Fidelity Registered Investment Advisor Group; Columbia Management names J Frederick Copper head of its international equities team; James R Renner, head of Wells Fargo's leasing and equipment finance business, will retire at end of year; Renner will be succeeded by John McQueen; Michael J W Rennock joins New York office of Winston & Strawn as partner; Bear Stearns hires four senior analysts for its fixed-income research team: Eric Hausler, Frank Henson, Masumi Goldman and Alberto J Bernal-Leon (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merck to Close Five Plants And Lay Off 7,000 Employees  Merck, the drug maker, plans to close five manufacturing plants by 2008 and lay off 7,000 employees, about 11 percent of its work force, as it struggles with falling sales and profits. The cuts follow a similar announcement from Pfizer in March and are the latest sign of the crisis faced by major drug makers as patents on some of their most profitable medicines expire. In June, Merck will begin to face low-priced generic competition on Zocor, a cholesterol-lowering drug that is its top-selling medicine. [Page C1.]    Muted Criticism From U.S. Over Yuan  Instead of accusing China of currency manipulation, the Treasury Department expressed disappointment that trading in the yuan is ''highly constricted'' and said it would ''intensely scrutinize'' China's practices in future reports. The agency's comments provoked an angry reaction from American manufacturers, some lawmakers and outside trade analysts. [C1.]    Despite Setbacks at Qwest, Investors See Potential  Investors have warmed to Qwest Communications, the smallest of the four Bell companies, even though it recently lost a bidding war for MCI and its balance sheet is heavy in debt. Market Place. [C1.]    Artery Treatment's Popularity Concerns Experts  The growing popularity of a treatment called carotid stenting has some experts worrying that too many doctors and patients, spurred by medical device makers, may embrace it without fully understanding that it is generally as risky as surgery -- and potentially riskier in some cases. [C1.]    G.M. Offers Some Temporary Assistance to Delphi  General Motors said that it would give the Delphi Corporation some temporary financial assistance while talks continued on a rescue plan. And Delphi said it was giving the United Automobile Workers union more time to negotiate before it files a motion in bankruptcy court asking a judge for permission to terminate its labor agreements. G.M. spun off Delphi six years ago, and it estimates that it faces a potential burden of up to $11 billion for its former workers' pensions and retirement health care costs and other obligations. [C4.]    Radiologist's Work for Plaintiffs Draws Scrutiny  Critics of product liability litigation over asbestos and silica have focused on a radiologist whose reports were often used to support claims by people seeking compensation for lung injury caused by inhalation of asbestos. [A1.]    U.S. Seeks Mediation in Talks With Air Traffic Controllers  The head of the Federal Aviation Administration called for mediation in talks with air traffic controllers, saying negotiations were near an impasse. [A20.]    Sales of Existing Homes Declined 2.7% in October  Sales of existing homes fell 2.7 percent last month and the inventory of houses and condominiums on the market rose to the highest monthly level in more than two years, an industry trade group reported. [C4.]    Stocks Decline Along With Oil Prices  Stocks fell as energy stocks tumbled on a big drop in oil prices. The Dow Jones industrial average was down 40.90 points, to 10,890.72. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 10.79 points, to 1,257.46, and the Nasdaq was down 23.64 points, to 2,239.37. [C11.]    Argentine President Ousts Economy Minister  Bringing an abrupt end to an alliance that had grown uneasy and even contentious, Argentina's president, N√©stor Kirchner, left, fired his economy minister, Roberto Lavagna, the main architect of the country's recovery from the worst economic crisis in its history. No explanation was given for Mr. Lavagna's departure, but at a news conference a couple of hours later, he made it clear that he had been asked to leave. Domestic and foreign investors immediately made clear that they harbored doubts about the shift. [C10.]    Supreme Court Accepts Patent Case Involving EBay  The Supreme Court accepted an appeal by eBay in a closely watched patent case and agreed to revisit the rules under which courts grant injunctions against a company found to be infringing another's patent. [C9.]    Cowell Is Set to Return to 'American Idol'  Simon Cowell, the star of the Fox network's biggest hit show, ''American Idol,'' cleared the way for his continued participation in that program when he settled a suit by Simon Fuller, the British producer of the series. [C6.]    Royal Ahold to Pay $1.1 Billion to Settle Suits  Royal Ahold, the Dutch supermarket giant, said that it would pay shareholders worldwide $1.1 billion to settle class-action lawsuits that were threatening to derail the company's turnaround. [C10.]    Agency's Moves Show Nontraditional Emphasis  The Momentum Worldwide division of the McCann Erickson Worldgroup is bolstering its creative ranks. The move underscores the growing attention paid by big agencies to realms outside traditional advertising, like promotions, public relations and sponsorships. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]    Where Sophisticated Airline Food Is Not an Oxymoron  In contrast to the situation on commercial airlines, the cuisine on private jets is steadily improving. Itineraries. [C8.]

headline: Despite Hurricanes, Conoco Says Profit Almost Doubled
abstract: ConocoPhillips said yesterday that third-quarter profit almost doubled after hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico curbed supplies and sent oil and natural gas prices to record highs.     The company, based in Houston, said it suffered disruptions from the hurricanes, particularly Katrina and Rita, which were more than offset by higher energy prices.

headline: Without Cash, Budget Airline Faces Closing
abstract: Independence Air, a low-fare airline that filed for bankruptcy protection last month, may stop flying Jan. 7 unless it gets new financing from an investor or buyer, the company said yesterday in a notice to union workers.      The carrier, a unit of FLYi of Dulles, Va., also said in the notice, which was sent to union workers like pilots and mechanics, that all operations would cease by Jan. 21 if it was unable to secure significant external investment or a sale of all or substantially all of its operations before Jan. 7.

headline: Tory leadership vote narrows U.K. field to 3
But Where Do You Put the Quarters?
abstract: Dream Arcades does not want you to throw out your old Xbox when the Xbox 360 usurps its place under the television. The company's kits can turn anything -- from an Xbox to a standard PC -- into a classic upright or tabletop arcade game machine.      The cabinet kits, which start at $659 plus shipping, include controllers with trackballs and full construction schematics, as well as a collection of 80 Atari classic video games and music jukebox software. The customer can supply any combination of monitor and PC or game console; the cabinets even work with the diminutive Mac Mini. Some cabinets are also sold with new or refurbished computers.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retailer Posts Surprise Rise in Sales
abstract: Marks & Spencer, one of Britain's largest clothing retailers, said quarterly revenue rose for the first time in two years as food sales rebounded and fashion sales steadied. Sales at outlets open at least a year gained 1.3 percent in the fiscal second quarter ended Oct. 1. That beat the median analyst estimate of a 2 percent decline. Sales fell 5.4 percent in the first quarter. First-half profit may beat analysts' estimates, the company said. Shares of the company rose 13.25 pence, to 397.25 pence.

headline: Norway's coalition to pull troops from Iraq
A.I.G.'s View on Suits
abstract: The American International Group Inc. employees facing possible lawsuits from the Securities and Exchange Commission are not ''senior corporate officers,'' the chief executive, Martin Sullivan, said.      A.I.G., which said yesterday that certain unidentified employees had received so-called Wells notices from the S.E.C. in connection with accounting inquiries, would have to identify any senior managers, Mr. Sullivan said on a conference call with analysts today.

headline: Secret prison adds to divisions in Iraq
Text of Fed Statement on Interest Rates
abstract: Text of statement by Federal Reserve after its monetary policy panel decides to raise its benchmark interest rates quarter-point (M)

headline: Republican lobbyist nears deal in fraud case
Chad Backs Out of Pledge to Use Oil Wealth to Reduce Poverty
abstract: Chad's government announces at meeting with World Bank that it plans to alter law it passed five years ago pledging to use money it earns on oil exports on poverty reduction; World Bank helped Chad build $4.2 billion pipeline to export oil with proviso that it pass such law; Chad now says it will funnel more money into its general budget and increase spending on military; photo (M)

headline: Rice Reaches Pact on Keeping Central Asia Base
abstract: Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, meeting with the new leaders of Kyrgyzstan, reached agreement on Tuesday on long-term rights to maintaining an air base here for servicing military aircraft on missions to Afghanistan.     The United States and allied forces may continue to use the base, adjacent to the international airport here, ''until the situation in Afghanistan is completely stabilized,'' President Kurmanbek S. Bakiyev said at a news conference.

headline: Ex-Powell aide assails Bush's foreign policy
World Bank's Former Chief Will Be Hired by Citigroup
abstract: Citigroup says James D Wolfensohn, who left as president of World Bank last spring after 10 years at helm, will serve as global strategy adviser to senior management and clients; he will also become chairman of Citigroup International Advisory Board in 2006; appointment comes one day after Shengman Zhang, World Bank managing director from China, is named vice chairman of Citigroup's global banking division and head of its public sector group; photo (M)

headline: F.D.A. Puts Restrictions on Guidant
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday released a warning letter it sent to the Guidant Corporation, restricting the ability of the company to win approval for some new medical products. In the letter, sent a week ago, the agency said Guidant, the heart device maker, had not fully responded to its concerns about manufacturing procedures at the company's biggest plant.     The F.D.A. said that in parts of the company's operations, Guidant did not have adequate controls, procedures and methods to validate product improvements it was making. The agency gave Guidant 15 days to respond. Along with suspending some new product approvals, the F.D.A. said it would no longer issue new export permits for devices made at the company's plant in St. Paul.

headline: Seoul scientist faces new inquiry
Stampede kills at least 42 in southern India
Vatican Considers Consigning Limbo to Oblivion
abstract: This month, 30 top theologians from around the world met at the Vatican to discuss what happens to babies who die without baptism.

headline: Online: Business Talk
abstract: A new online readers' forum on business issues will have a fresh question each week. This week: Do you think the era of broad employer-based health coverage is over? The discussion can be joined at http://forums.nytimes.com/top/opinion/readersopinions/forums/businesstechnology/businesstalk/index.html.

headline: Sydney to expand police authority
Phone giants, and workers, struggle as industry changes
Two Advisers Defrauded at Least 8 Clients, S.E.C. Says
abstract: The co-founders of Amerindo Investment Advisors, Alberto W. Vilar and Gary Tanaka, defrauded at least seven investors in addition to Lily Cates, the mother of the actress Phoebe Cates, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in court documents.     In court papers filed late Thursday in Manhattan, the S.E.C. said that Mr. Vilar, 65, and Mr. Tanaka, 62, stole at least $17 million from investors, who include an 80-year-old Manhattan woman with diabetes, a friend of Mr. Vilar who died of cancer in 2003, and a woman who claims she is a former girlfriend of Mr. Vilar.

headline: Official vote count gives ruling party lead in Azerbaijan election
France Is Trying, Discreetly, to Integrate Television a Bit
abstract: Audrey Pulvar's posture straightens incrementally as a television producer counts down from five in a broadcast studio here, and at 7:30 p.m. sharp, her image flashes onto screens across the country.     ''Bonsoir,'' she begins before delivering the day's news on France 3, a state-run channel.

headline: Text Hackers Could Jam Cellphones, a Paper Says
abstract: Researchers at Pennsylvania State University warn that malicious hackers could take down cellular networks in large cities by inundating their popular text-messaging services with equivalent of spam; say cellphone companies provide text-messaging service to their networks in way that could allow attacker who jams message system to disable voice networks as well; say that since message services are accessible through Internet, cellular networks are open to denial-of-service attacks that occur regularly online, in which computers send so many messages or commands to target that rogue data blocks other machines from connecting; cellular companies acknowledge that such attacks are possible, but say they have developed systems to prevent effective ones; other specialists say those systems would face many of same obstacles as those that try to block denial-of-service attacks; drawing (M)

headline: Deal reached on Gaza border crossings
Auto Supplier Delphi Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Delphi, the nation√Ç¬ís largest auto supplier, filed for bankruptcy-court protection on Saturday, the largest filing ever in the domestic auto industry.

headline: China economy even larger than thought
World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Protest Over Tent Camp Move
abstract: The police in Muzaffarabad, the flattened capital of Pakistani-controlled Kashmir, wielded batons against a crowd of 200 earthquake survivors protesting an order to leave their makeshift camp because it lacked drinking water and adequate sanitation, Pakistani officials said. Several people were injured, and 10 were arrested. The police say they want to move the residents of the crowded 350-tent camp into two new and bigger ones in the city with better conditions. ''We will use force, if we have to, to shift these people tomorrow,'' a police official said.   Salman Masood (NYT)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 1,946 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Saturday:    CABINO, Shayne M., 19, Lance Cpl., Marines; Canton, Mass.; Second Marine Division, Second Marine Expeditionary Force.  CHERAVA, Nicholas O., 21, Cpl.; Ontonagon, Mich.; Second Marine Division, Second Marine Expeditionary Force.  FRYE, Jason L., 19, Pfc.; Landisburg, Pa.; Second Marine Division, Second Marine Expeditionary Force.  KENNY, Patrick B., 20, Lance Cpl., Marines; Pittsburgh; Second Marine Division, Second Marine Expeditionary Force.  McVICKER, Daniel M., 20, Lance Cpl., Marines; Alliance, Ohio; Second Marine Division, Second Marine Expeditionary Force.  RAINES, Carl L. II, 20, Lance Cpl., Marines; Coffee, Ala.; Second Marine Division, Second Marine Expeditionary Force.

headline: Plane Crashes in Nigeria; All 117 Aboard Are Probably Dead
abstract: A passenger plane carrying 117 people crashed Saturday night in a town 30 miles north of Nigeria's largest city, Lagos, after passing through an electrical storm shortly after takeoff.      No survivors were found in the flaming wreckage of the 737 Boeing aircraft, the Nigerian Red Cross told Reuters.

headline: Norwegian Storm Over Russian Trawler Dies Down
abstract: A minor incident with a private trawler surged into a diplomatic storm, with a response from the military of Norway and Russia.

headline: Unilever says it will keep its dual structure intact
Q&A: The cost of gold
People
abstract: Paul Venn is named North American managing partner, overseeing Detroit-area operations of Young & Rubicam and Wunderman divisions of Young & Rubicam (S)

headline: Achievement or Disaster: Which Is Remembered Best?
abstract: Remains of speedboat that crashed and sank into Coniston Water in 1967 are at issue as Britons debate how to commemorate Donald Campbell and his quest to break his 300 mph record; he died when boat crashed; efforts to restore his boat as functioning replica are opposed by some who say crash is part of whole Campbell story; photo; map (M)

headline: GM cutting 30,000 jobs and closing auto plants
De Beers Will Pay $250 Million to Settle Diamond Pricing Suits
abstract: De Beers, the world's biggest diamond miner and marketer, said Wednesday that it had agreed to pay $250 million to settle four civil class-action lawsuits filed against it in the United States.      The settlement ends 11 years of litigation against De Beers by four groups of plaintiffs who accused it of overcharging for diamonds in the United States, a DeBeers spokeswoman, Lynette Hori, said.

headline: Group of Private Equity Firms Launches $12 Billion Bid for TDC
abstract: The bid for Denmark's dominant telephone company, TDC, could set a new benchmark for leveraged buyouts in Europe.

headline: BellSouth Profit Rises, but Sales Decline
abstract: BellSouth Corp says profit rose 2.3 percent in third quarter, to $817 million; sales dipped 0.5 percent, to $5.07 billion; photo (M)

headline: Research in cloning declared a fabrication
IHT to add Bloomberg business section
Among Makers of Memory Chips for Gadgets, Fierce Scrum Takes Shape
abstract: Nestled in a valley in central Japan, surrounded by forested hills and terraced rice paddies, is one of the world's most sophisticated -- and secretive -- semiconductor plants.     Inside the windowless plant, built by the Japanese electronics maker Toshiba, tiny cranelike robots shuffle along automated production lines, moving stacks of silicon wafers the size of dinner plates. Masked technicians watch as rows of tall machines grind the wafers, etch circuits on their surfaces and cut them into tiny rectangular computer chips.

headline: Rumsfeld and South Korea Defense Chief Agree to Keep Status Quo
abstract: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and his South Korean counterpart on Friday reaffirmed the commitment of both nations to ''a solid combined defense posture,'' and agreed to ''accelerate discussions'' on whether South Korea should gain command of its military forces in times of war.     A statement issued after Mr. Rumsfeld's meeting with Defense Minister Yoon Kwang Ung made clear that any changes in wartime control of South Korean military forces, as well as any decision on a shift in America's nuclear guarantee for the South, would be postponed to the future.

headline: Ch√°vez Restyles Venezuela With '21st-Century Socialism'
abstract: Firmly in power and his revolution now in overdrive, President Hugo Ch√°vez is moving fast to transform Venezuela's economy by bucking free-market planning with what he calls 21st-century socialism: founding state companies, seizing abandoned private factories and establishing thousands of cooperatives and worker-run businesses.     The populist government is reorganizing the country's colossal oil industry, taking a bigger share from private multinationals. Planners are reorganizing the banking system, placing stringent restrictions on lending while creating state banks. Venezuela is also developing a state-to-state barter system to trade items as varied as cattle, oil and cement as far away as Argentina and as near as Cuba, its closest ally.

headline: 3 go on trial in '91 killing of Croatians
Wall Street Journal downsizes - to tabloid
Defense lawyer in Saddam trial is found dead
Zarqawi's Family Members Condemn His Actions
abstract: Family members of the terrorist leader Abu Musab al Zarqawi renounced him in an advertisement appearing today in Jordan's three main newspapers.

headline: Gunmen kidnap lawyer for Saddam co-defendant
World Business Briefing | Europe: Plan to Ease Cross-Border Bank Mergers
abstract: The European Commission will revise banking laws to make it harder for national authorities to block takeovers of local banks from abroad, Charlie McCreevy, Europe's commissioner in charge of the internal market, said yesterday. The Dutch bank ABN Amro encountered numerous difficulties when it tried to buy Banca Antonveneta of Italy this summer. Attempts by the Bank of Italy and a rival Italian bidder to block that acquisition are now being investigated. A yearlong study concluded that existing rules grant too much discretion to local authorities.    Paul Meller (NYT)

headline: Making the Best of the Tyco Mess
abstract: Can education thwart greed?

headline: Court Seeks Arrests of Ugandan Rebels
abstract: The International Criminal Court in The Hague confirmed Friday that it had issued its first arrest warrants, seeking the arrest of the leader, Joseph Kony, and four commanders of the Lord's Resistance Army rebel movement in Uganda.     The court, the first global human rights tribunal with a permanent mandate, has been working in The Hague since 2002 despite resistance and a continuing boycott by the United States.

headline: A Nobel winner takes on New Year's resolutions
DDB Chicago Wins LensCrafters Account
abstract: Luxottica Retail awards LensCrafters eyewear ad account to Chicago office of DDB Worldwide (S)

headline: 'Clone-Gate' scoop boomerangs on South Korean news show
Lone Senate foe of the Patriot Act gets backup
Official at stem cell hubsees harm from scandal
Chairman Nominee May Bring a New Openness to the Fed
abstract: Federal Reserve is likely to become more open, less mysterious and perhaps less intriguing under new Federal Reserve chairman Ben S Bernanke; in article he wrote with other academics--long before Pres Bush nominated him to succeed Alan Greenspan--Bernanke bluntly argued that Fed needed to base its credibility on more than mystique of its chairman; photo (M)

headline: In Strong Terms, Rome Is to Ban Gays as Priests
abstract: New Vatican document excludes from priesthood most gay men, banning in strong and specific language candidates who are actively homosexual, have deep-seated homosexual tendencies or support so-called 'gay culture'; appears to allow ordination only for candidates who experienced 'transitory' homosexual tendencies that were 'clearly overcome' at least three years before ordination as deacon, last step before priesthood; several critics say language will make it nearly impossible for men who believe their basic orientation is gay--but who are celibate--to become priests; anticipation of document, leaked by Italian Catholic Web site, has divided Catholics, especially in US, igniting debate over whether this is appropriate response to recent sex scandal and whether celibate gay men can still be good priests (M)

headline: Benedict condemns torture and terrorism
Free flow: Private firms in fast lane on autobahn
Rivals pressing Telekom on all sides
Two Utilities Said to Hold Merger Talks
abstract: The parent of Florida Power and Light is in advanced talks to acquire the Constellation Energy Group for more than $11 billion, according to people briefed on the negotiations. A deal would create a utility behemoth with operations all along the East Coast, from Maine to Florida.     The talks come as deal-making in energy has reached feverish heights. Oil and gas deals alone have totaled $180 billion so far this year, the most activity since 1998, according to Thomson Financial.

headline: Atomic Agency Delays Action on Iran
abstract: International Atomic Energy Agency delays taking any action on Iran's nuclear program, even as British delegate, speaking for Europe, says process described in documents offered to Iran 'has no other application other than the production of nuclear warheads' (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: New Rescue Vessel In The Works
abstract: The navy announced that it was set to begin construction of a new naval rescue vessel, whose need was highlighted in August when Russia was unable to save a disabled naval submarine by itself. The new vessel, to be constructed in St. Petersburg, is to be delivered by 2010, Vladimir Masorin, the navy's commander in chief, told Interfax. Its keel is expected to be laid today. Russia's dearth of high-seas rescue equipment was evident in August when a small rescue submarine became entangled off its Pacific coast. Unable to free the vessel alone, the navy called for American and British help, and an unmanned British rescue vehicle was able to save the submarine and its seven-man crew.   C. J. CHIVERS (NYT)

headline: Cendant's Shares Slide on News of Breakup Plan
abstract: Cendant's shares drop 6.6 percent following announcement that it will be divided into four publicly traded companies; Cendant reduces its earnings projection for fourth quarter to 23 cents to 26 cents a share, 3 cents to 4 cents less than its previous estimate (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: U.S. Helicopter May Have Taken Fire
abstract: United States Army helicopter providing earthquake relief in Pakistani-controlled area of Kashmir may have been fired on by rocket-propelled grenade; helicopter was not hit and Pakistani officials believe blast may have been from dynamite being used to clear roads in area (S)

headline: Judging Pension Plan by a Percentage Choice
abstract: The investigation of General Motors' pension accounting, which the automaker disclosed on Wednesday, appears to be focused on whether G.M. has the data to justify the numbers it has reported to investors -- something securities regulators have long been warning companies they would have to provide if challenged.      In broad terms, the Securities and Exchange Commission wants to know whether G.M. has accurately measured the value of the benefits it is to pay its workers after they retire.

headline: Russia's struggleover Islam's place
Iraqis vote on new constitution
Free Flow: Bigger freighters, and more of them
BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: G.M. Announces Turnaround Plan That Includes 5,000 More Job Cuts  General Motors unveiled details of a three-year blueprint to revive its fortunes, including 5,000 job cuts on top of 25,000 previously announced. But analysts questioned whether the plan was enough, saying it lacked the speed and breadth that have helped major rivals stage comebacks. [Page A1.]    G.M. workers across the country met the news with a mixture of shock, resignation and frustration with the company's management. [C1.]    J.P. Morgan Chase to Offer Hedge-Like Fund  In the latest sign that hedge funds are going mainstream, J.P. Morgan Chase is marketing a mutual fund, the Highbridge Statistical Mutual Fund, which will be overseen by Highbridge Capital Management, the $9 billion hedge fund firm that the bank acquired last year. Market Place. [C1.]    Barriers to the Top for Women in Advertising  Despite their notable rise in the ad business, women have a long way to go, especially as creative directors, the people who are ultimately responsible for the output of an agency. [C1.]    Mentor Plans to Continue Pursuit of Medicis  The cosmetic medical device company Mentor indicated that it would not take Medicis Pharmaceutical's blunt rejection of its unsolicited $2.2 billion takeover proposal as the final word. In Mentor's view, the benefits of joining its breast implant and liposuction equipment businesses with Medicis's anti-wrinkle drugs and prescription skin therapies are so clear that there is every reason to hope a deal will eventually be struck. [C4.]    Dow Average Closes at Highest Level Since March  The Dow Jones industrial average rose 53.95 points, to 10,820.28, its highest close since March 10. The advance put the Dow into positive territory for the year. The S.& P. 500 added 6.58 points, to 1,254.85, and the Nasdaq gained 14.60 points, to 2,241.67. [C6.]    U.S. Bans Poultry Imports From British Columbia  Federal agriculture officials banned poultry imports from mainland British Columbia after Canadian officials reported finding a duck at a poultry farm that was sick with the flu. [A20.]    Two Lawsuits Are Filed Against Sony BMG  In separate actions, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a digital rights advocacy group in California, and the Texas attorney general filed lawsuits against Sony BMG, claiming it violated consumers' rights and traded in malicious software. [C6.]    America Online Makes Video Distribution Deal  America Online reached an unusual arrangement with a start-up company that will allow almost any producer of video content to distribute programming on its service, splitting revenue from advertising or fees. [C15.]    Microsoft Plans to Make Software Formats Available  Microsoft announced that it would seek approval to make the software formats behind its Office programs an ''open standard'' that it would license free to competitors, partners and developers. [C6.]    Intel and Micron Technology Plan Chip Venture  Intel and Micron Technology announced a venture to manufacture NAND flash-memory chips in an effort to tap into one of the chip industry's fastest growing segments. [C6.]    Putin Agrees to Set Schedule for Pipeline to Japan  Japan won a promise from President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to establish within a year a construction timetable for a pipeline that would carry Siberian oil to the Sea of Japan. [A8.]    Capitalizing on Environmental Concerns  Cargill is among a cadre of companies profiting from concerns -- by shareholders, communities and consumers alike -- about global warming, leaking landfills and other potential environmental woes. [C1.]    Goldman Sachs announced a policy that details how its 24,000 employees -- be they bankers, analysts or purchasing agents -- should promote activities that protect forests and guard against climate change. [C3.]    Google to Give $3 Million for Digital Library  The Library of Congress is set to announce a $3 million gift from Google to help the library begin building a World Digital Library, a project that aims to digitize and place on the Web significant primary materials from national libraries and other institutions around the world. James H. Billington, left, the librarian of Congress, said the World Digital Library would be modeled after the library's American Memory Project, which has been digitizing and placing on the Web millions of historical artifacts. [C6.]    Google executives said that the company planned to move quickly to capitalize on its new Google Base database service, adding a feature that permits merchants to provide local shopping information. [C3.]

It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Wednesday:    JOPLIN, Brian K., 32, Petty Officer Second Class, Navy; Hugo, Okla.; Helicopter Mine Countermeasures Squadron 15.
