abstract: With an eye on the Jan. 23 election, the Bloc Qu√É¬©b√É¬©cois is emphasizing issues that appeal to immigrants, like fighting discrimination and increasing social assistance.

headline: Brazil President's Party Secretly Got $3 Million From Cuba, Magazine Says
abstract: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 31 - During Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva's successful presidential campaign in 2002, his Workers' Party received up to $3 million in illegal campaign contributions from the government of Cuba, according to the cover story in the current issue of Brazil's leading weekly newsmagazine.

headline: A Toast to a Liqueur (if You Can Say It)
abstract: Grand Marnier introduces advertising campaign to sell its $225-a-bottle vintage liqueur, Cuvee du Cent Cinquantenaire; tagline on print advertising reads, 'Hard to find, impossible to pronounce, and prohibitively expensive'; campaign was created by ad agency Walrus; photo (M)

headline: Energy, the Hot Deal Field, Is Likely to Get Still Hotter
abstract: The ConocoPhillips acquisition of the natural gas producer Burlington Resources for $35.6 billion will cap what has already been a frothy year for energy deals. Even before the deal, which was approved by the boards of the two companies Monday night, Chevron bought Unocal, Chinese and Russian companies cut deals from Venezuela to Kazakhstan, and even Warren E. Buffet, the famed value investor, bought a power company.     But this year may be a warm-up. Bankers and analysts specializing in energy say that deal volume in 2006 could rival records set during the last fervor of mergers in the late 1990's. The reason, they say, is that the battles over the world's energy resources show no sign of easing.

headline: A C.E.O. Who Carries a Big Stick
abstract: L'AFFAIRE Cyberonics began a week ago Tuesday. That evening, Cyberonics, a small Houston-based medical device maker, held an invitation-only educational program for psychiatrists. The company was in the process of introducing its new product, an implantable device for people who suffer from treatment-resistant depression. It was using the event, held simultaneously in 48 cities, to recruit psychiatrists to the cause.     Just about everything about the new device, called the VNS Therapy System, is steeped in controversy. (VNS stands for vagus nerve stimulator.) The data about its effectiveness is muddy. The Food and Drug Administration initially declined to approve it for commercial use, then changed its mind and signed off on it in July. It is expensive -- about $15,000 -- and nobody knows whether health insurers will be willing to reimburse depression patients who want to try it. Or whether psychiatrists will support it. For Cyberonics, which has only one other product on the market (a similar device for epilepsy sufferers), it is a huge roll of the dice. If the VNS Therapy System fails in the marketplace, it will be a disaster for the company -- and its stock price.

headline: Palestinians celebrate opening of Gaza border
Italy and U.S. museum near art claim deal
Quake Strains 58-Year-Old Fault Line
abstract: The latest face-off between India and Pakistan in the aftermath of the Oct. 8 earthquake centers on the question of how to deliver aid across the heavily fortified Line of Control that divides Kashmir.      That line is the central source of their dispute of more than a half-century -- as well as virtually the epicenter of the quake. Since it struck, the two sides have fired off proposals and counterproposals on how to best assist survivors on each side. Relief has been offered and rejected. Credit and blame have been assigned.

headline: Return of the Junk Fax
abstract: IN the hierarchy of annoying advertisers, the porn spammers and the pump-and-dump stock promoters dwell at the bottom. Not far above them are junk faxers, who spew unsolicited advertisements to your fax machine, using your phone line, your ink and your paper in the process.     Most junk faxes have been illegal since 1991. Since then, a federal law and Federal Communications Commission regulations have kept most machines free of unsolicited ads. But that may be changing. Why? ''Because Congress just pumped new life into the junk fax industry,'' according to the Electronic Privacy Information Center (epic.org), which issued a communication on the subject this week.

headline: Little fizz in China's stocks
Zimbabwe Said to Permit U.N. to Build New Homes
abstract: Zimbabwe government continues to deny that its campaign in spring to demolish country's urban slums created nationwide housing crisis; but it now appears to have relented about allowing United Nations to construct 2,500 homes to aid victims of mass evictions (M)

headline: Names of the Dead
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,106 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following American yesterday:    RICHARDSON, William D., 30, Staff Sgt., Marines; Houston; Third Marine Aircraft Wing.

headline: Former Peruvian President Fujimori taken into police custody in Chile
Thousands march for Irish labor
World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Deflation Expected to End by March
abstract: Japan's central bank says seven-year bout of deflation will end in March, increasing chances that policy makers will raise interest rates from almost zero (S)

headline: Rove offers testimonyon agent leak
Executives Gone Wild: It's Not a Pretty Sight
abstract: THERE is a scene in the old gangster movie ''Murder, Inc.'' in which a prominent member of that entity, a certain Abe ''Kid Twist'' Reles -- ably portrayed by Peter Falk -- is asked why he always wants more when he already has so much. ''Don't ask questions,'' he shouts in response. ''What've you got hands for, huh? Take!''     Then there was a scene I recall from my childhood during the Army-McCarthy hearings in 1954. After Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin said some nasty thing about a young attorney working for Joseph N. Welch, the canny Boston lawyer representing the Army, Mr. Welch asked Mr. McCarthy: ''Have you no decency, sir? At long last, have you no sense of decency?''

headline: In a Kashmiri Town, a Painstaking Recovery Effort
abstract: In Muzaffarabad, the capital of Pakistani-controlled Kashmir, the remains of the dead are slowly being unearthed for burial.

headline: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.     At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.95 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 4.26 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 3.78 percent.

headline: Briefly: S&P gives TUI marginal rating
Debate but Little Finality on Mideast Streets
abstract: After months of anticipation, the first findings of the United Nations investigation of the killing of Rafik Hariri, the former prime minister of Lebanon, overtook Beirut and Damascus on Friday, dominating conversations and blaring in news broadcasts at almost every restaurant and shop.      Many Lebanese stayed home or in their offices, fearing violence resulting from the release of the report. Perhaps the only thing selling well in many popular commercial districts was a special edition of the newspaper Al Mustaqbal, owned by the Hariri family, which published the 54-page report in its entirety in Arabic. Booksellers and newspaper stands sold out of the special issue within minutes, and some people even took to scalping it for five times the price.

headline: Six Flags Appoints a Chief as Its Chairman Takes Hold
abstract: Six Flags, the theme park company at the center of a roller-coaster battle for control, named a new chief executive last night in a move that suggests its new chairman, Daniel M. Snyder, has a firm grip on the company.     Mark Shapiro, a former ESPN executive who joined the Six Flags board late last month, was appointed to the company's top post in a bid to reverse its lackluster performance and enhance its entertainment industry ties. The board also ended an extended auction process, during which it had solicited bids to sell the company. Mr. Shapiro succeeded Kieran E. Burke.

headline: Indians Find They Can Go Home Again
abstract: Standing amid the rolling lawns outside his four-bedroom villa, Ajay Kela pondered his street in the community of Palm Meadows. One of his neighbors recently returned to India from Cupertino, Calif., to run a technology start-up funded by the venture capital firm Kleiner, Perkins, Caufield & Byers.      Across the street from Mr. Kela is another Indian executive, this one from Fremont, Calif., who works with the outsourcing firm Infosys Technologies. On the other side is the top executive of Cisco Systems in India, who returned here after decades in the Bay Area and New York.

headline: Tension mounting in EU budget talks
BUSINESS BRIEFS
abstract: Broadest Measure of Foreign Trade Shows Slight Improvement in 3rd Quarter  America's current-account deficit -- the broadest measure of international trade -- showed a slight improvement in the July-to-September quarter although it was still at the third-highest level in history. The Commerce Department reported that the deficit in the current account totaled $195.8 billion in the third quarter. That was down 1 percent from the deficit of $197.8 billion in the April-to-June quarter. The third-quarter figure was below the $205 billion imbalance that had been forecast. Analysts said payments by foreign insurance companies to settle damage claims stemming from hurricanes helped to narrow the gap. Analysts are predicting that the current-account deficit for 2005 will set a record, exceeding $800 billion, and that it will rise above $900 billion next year. (AP)    President to Leave Philadelphia Federal Reserve  The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, Anthony M. Santomero, announced that he planned to step down early next year, leaving a third vacancy at the top of the central bank. Mr. Santomero's resignation occurs as Ben S. Bernanke, whom the White House has nominated to be the next Fed chairman, prepares to succeed Alan Greenspan early next year. Mr. Santomero was a voting member this year on the committee that sets interest rates. Next year, the Philadelphia Fed president will not be a voting member of the committee, under the rotating system that gives the 12 regional Fed presidents a vote every second or third year. A search committee of the Philadelphia bank will choose Mr. Santomero's successor, and the Bush administration must still nominate two people for open spots on the Fed's seven-member board of governors. (REUTERS)    Johnson & Johnson to Buy Maker of Insulin Pumps  Shares of the Animas Corporation, a maker of insulin pumps, soared after Johnson & Johnson said that it had agreed to acquire the company for about $518 million to capitalize on the growing demand for diabetes treatment. Once the acquisition closes, Animas, based in West Chester, Pa., will operate as a stand-alone entity under LifeScan, a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary that sells blood glucose monitoring systems. Animas shares rose $5.83, or 32 percent, to $24.03. The boards of both companies have approved the deal, which is expected to close in next year's first quarter, pending approval from antitrust regulators and Animas shareholders. (AP)    Adobe Shares Soar as Profit Forecast Exceeds Estimates  Shares of Adobe Systems, a maker of graphic design software, surged 11 percent, the most in three years, after the company's profit forecast exceeded analysts' estimates. Adobe said its fiscal 2006 profit, minus some costs, would be $1.26 to $1.30 a share. Adobe reported $510 million in fourth-quarter sales, also topping analysts' estimates. Profit for the quarter gained 38 percent on demand for new versions of its Photoshop and Illustrator programs. Adobe completed the $3.4 billion acquisition of Macromedia this month. The purchase gives Adobe Web design programs and Macromedia's Flash, video software that is used in 98 percent of personal computers. Adobe shares rose $3.89, to $38.82. The stock has advanced 24 percent this year. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)    Bass Family Announces Deal to Sell Pipeline Company  The Bass family, long synonymous with oil and wealth in Texas, confirmed that it had agreed to sell the pipeline company Sid Richardson Energy Services, for $1.6 billion in cash to the Southern Union Company. The deal will give Southern Union, a natural gas distributor, one of the nation's largest networks of gas pipelines, at more than 22,000 miles crisscrossing the Gulf of Mexico, the Southwest, the Midwest and Canada. Southern Union already operates pipelines in 17 states. The Bass family put Richardson Energy on the market in May to capitalize on the rising value of gas operations, and received several offers, officials with the company said. (AP)    Tape With Data on 2 Million People Is Lost  A subsidiary of the LaSalle Bank Corporation said yesterday that a tape containing information on two million residential mortgage customers was lost as it was being transported to Texas from Chicago. The subsidiary, the ABN Amro Mortgage Group, said that it had no indication that the data had been misused, but that it was notifying the customers and had arranged for them to enroll in a credit monitoring service for 90 days at no cost. (AP)

headline: Trade Leader for Europe Refuses to Cut Farm Tariffs
abstract: Peter Mandelson, trade representative for European Union, says talks to reach new global trade deal are 'too big to fail,' but refuses further cuts to Europe's contested farm tariffs; calls on members countries of World Trade Organization to accept 'tailored development package' that would remove all tariffs and quotas on exports from poorest countries; also seeks to dispel critics' portrayal of European Union as enemy of farmers in poor parts of world, saying he refuses to make cuts that would eliminate preferential access Europe offers to African and Caribbean countries; photo (M)

headline: Scrushy proclaims innocence
Spend/Thrift: Counting the ways to use that bonus
$1.2 Billion Deal for Swedish Company
abstract: Two private equity firms agree to buy Swedish telecommunications company Com Hem for one billion euros, or $1.2 billion; firms are Providence Equity Partners and Carlyle Group (M)

headline: Suicide Bombing Attack on a Bus in Baghdad's Main Terminal Kills 30
abstract: A suicide bomber shoved aside a fare collector at Baghdad's main bus terminal on Thursday, forced himself onto a crowded bus and blew himself up, causing an enormous explosion that killed at least 30 people and reduced the bus to a charred, mangled husk, witnesses and police officials said.     Separately, an Islamic insurgent group claimed in an Internet posting to have executed a kidnapped American security consultant, according to the SITE Institute, which tracks jihadist Web sites. The posting neither named the consultant nor provided evidence to back the claim.

headline: Smaller Video Producers Seek Audiences on Net
abstract: Video delivered over Internet, which has been embraced by media and Internet giants like Viacom and Yahoo, is becoming way for smaller producers to reach audience without having to cut deals with movie studios and big networks that are traditional gatekeepers of television; host of new ventures is starting to cater to publishing and advertising needs of smaller video creators as interest in video soars; new start-up called Brightcove has developed system of online video production tools that makes it easier for small operations to distribute video programs as well as charge for them; Dan Myrick, co-director of 1999 film The Blair Witch Project, is turning to Internet to deliver whole series called The Strand of Venice, moody drama set in Venice, Calif; viewers will go to Myrick's Web site where 50-minute pilot episode is available free; future episodes will cost 99 cents, for 30-minute film; Oxygen Media and Scripps Networks are among small to medium-size producers that are experimenting with expanded lineups of video content, improving navigation between videos and creating business model for video services; Eco-Nova Productions, Halifax company that specializes in programs on shipwrecks, is creating new section on its Web site that follows company's explorations day by day; program is in form of a blog; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Sears to Buy Rest of Chain
abstract: Sears Holdings offered 835.4 million Canadian dollars (about $719 million) for the 46.2 percent of Sears Canada it does not own. The move followed an announcement last week that Sears Canada is to pay shareholders 2 billion Canadian dollars in a special dividend after raising 2.3 billion Canadian dollars on the sale of its credit card division.   Ian Austen (NYT)

headline: French/West/Vaughan Expands in New York
abstract: French/West/Vaughan, a public relations agency based in Raleigh, N.C., is expanding its operations in New York through two acquisitions for undisclosed terms.     French/West/Vaughan is absorbing the business, employees and clients of Jody Donohue Associates and Burton Luch Public Relations.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Nokia Net Up 29% on China Sales
abstract: Nokia says third-quarter profit rose 29 percent on surge in sales of lower-priced cellular telephone models in China; net income climbed to 881 million euros ($1.06 billion); revenue increased 18 percent, to 8.4 billion euros (S)

headline: LOOKING AHEAD
abstract: JUMP BALL -- In the past few months, Cablevision announced, then dropped plans to go private, and it offered a huge dividend that benefited the controlling shareholders, the Dolan family. Now, it's fighting with the musicians' union over music for the Rockettes. Say this for Cablevision, which reports earnings this week: it's more entertaining than the Knicks. (Monday.)    PUMPED UP -- When are oil profits too high? When the Senate notices and drags industry executives to Capitol Hill to explain themselves. Representatives from Exxon, ConocoPhillips, Chevron and Shell are expecting to be grilled during a Senate hearing over the industry's recent revenue figures. (Wednesday.)    WINDOW SEAT -- Two of the country's struggling airlines, their situation made worse recently by escalating energy prices, are scheduled to report earnings this week. Delta Air Lines, which is still operating under bankruptcy court protection, recently announced another round of cuts and layoffs. US Airways, coming out of bankruptcy proceedings, is still planning its merger with AmericaWest. (Wednesday.)    FLAT SCREEN --Dell Inc. faces something new this earnings report: uncertainty. Long a bellwether of the technology sector, Dell issued a disappointing forecast on slowing sales and has also struggled to replicate in home entertainment its success in personal computers. (Thursday.)    THATAWAY -- Two media companies with opposite agendas, DreamWorks Animation SKG and the News Corporation, report their earnings this week. DreamWorks is still sorting through offers for its live-action film business from suitors like NBC Universal and Paramount while the News Corporation, led by Rupert Murdoch, has been in a buying mood. The company has recently made big bets on Internet companies, including a $580 million offer for Intermix Media, the parent company of MySpace.com, the social networking company. (Thursday.)    TRADE WINDS -- High energy prices and the effects of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita are likely to be felt on September's trade figures. Economists are forecasting an imbalance of $61 billion. But economists are predicting a more favorable result from the preliminary report of the University of Michigan Consumer Sentiment Index. (Thursday.)    ECONOMIC INDICATORS -- Consumer credit for September (Monday); wholesale inventories for September (Wednesday); import prices for October and jobless claims for the week of Oct. 31-Nov. 5.(Thursday.)

headline: Major rally held in Baku to protest vote results
Turkey charges editor again
French rail strike winds down
U.S. and North Korea Spar on Sanctions
abstract: Six-nation nuclear talks ended today on the same inconclusive and irresolute note they began with three days earlier.

headline: Blair Implicates Iran in Iraqi Bomb Attacks on British Troops
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that Britain believed Iran had supplied insurgents in southern Iraq with technology used in lethal bombing attacks on British troops there.

headline: Bush's statement after Miers' withdrawal
World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Elevator Makers Accused of Price Fixing
abstract: Europe's antitrust regulator has accused the world's biggest elevator manufacturers of running a price-fixing cartel in the global elevator and escalator market. Antitrust officials would not identify the manufacturers, but people close to the investigations said that formal charges were made Monday against four companies: Otis, a unit of United Technologies of the United States; Schindler Holding of Switzerland; Kone of Finland; and ThyssenKrupp of Germany. Kone and ThyssenKrupp said they were studying the statement setting out the charges. Otis and Schindler were not available for comment. The companies have two months to respond to the accusations. During that time, they can request a hearing before the European Union's antitrust authorities.   Dan Bilefsky (IHT)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Moody's Raises Credit Rating
abstract: Moody's Investors Service raises Brazil's credit rating, saying surge in exports and reduction in debt denominated in foreign currencies will make it easier for country to make bond payments (S)

headline: Israeli and Palestinian to Discuss Steps to Peace
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas plan to meet next week for talks on advancing peace efforts after Israel's recent withdrawal from Gaza Strip; both men say they are committed to internationally backed peace plan known as the road map, plan that has been dormant for two years; Gaza continues to be source of friction, with Islamic faction Hamas firing rockets into Israel and Israel responding with airstrikes (M)

headline: Proposed Cuts in the Factory and in the Fields
abstract: GLOBALIZATION exacted a toll on Delphi workers, who until now had been able to hold onto their generous wages and benefits, as the company said it would use bankruptcy court protection to cut wages or send jobs overseas. It was a rude shock for some skilled employees, and signaled that automakers were more likely to demand significant cuts in pay and benefits as they negotiated with labor unions.     Meanwhile, the Bush administration tried to breathe life into moribund talks on reducing tariffs and subsidies for agriculture. Another corporate scandal erupted, mergers heated up in one industry and Apple sought to extend its lead in mobile media by introducing a video version of its iPod.    WORKERS' BLUES -- Delphi's decision to seek bankruptcy protection has set up a showdown with the United Automobile Workers that could presage radical changes in the entire auto industry. Delphi, the country's biggest auto parts maker, told the U.A.W. that it must cut labor costs by two-thirds to compete with companies that make parts in Mexico and China.

headline: Intel to Bring Out a Server Chip With Several Processors
abstract: Intel Corp is expected to unveil server processor that has four microprocessors on single piece of silicon; Advanced Micro Devices introduced dual-core server chip in spring; technology speeds performance while preventing overheating that can plague high-performing processors (M)

headline: P.&G. Purchase Will Cut Profits
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co says that purchase of Gillette Co will cut profit by as much as 13 cents this quarter and 26 cents this fiscal year (S)

headline: A Tax Resister Is Convicted on 5 Counts
abstract: Tessa David, the wife of a leading promoter of a contention that most Americans are tricked into paying income taxes, was convicted yesterday by a federal jury in Philadelphia on five counts of willful failure to file tax returns, her lawyers said.     Ms. David, 45, was convicted three months after her husband, Larken Rose, 37, was convicted on the same charges in another trial in Federal District Court in Philadelphia. Her lawyers, Ellen C. Brotman and Anna M. Durbin, said there would be no comment.

headline: Tougher Year Lies Ahead for OPEC
abstract: OPEC, which was able to maintain solidarity in 2005 thanks to high prices, high production and high demand, is expected to face more divisive climate in 2006, when rising non-OPEC production could force it to consider production cuts to keep prices from falling too low; one item that OPEC ministers may discuss when they gather in Kuwait City on Dec 12 is setting minimum price that group would agree to defend; before recovering with arrival of cold weather on US East Coast, oil prices dropped $15 a barrel in three months from their high of $69.81, and price of 'OPEC barrel,' which is composite of 11 crude oils representative of cartel's actual production, recently dipped below $50 before recovering to $52.88 on Dec 7; photo (M)

headline: Approval of Cancer Drug Lifts Celgene Stock
abstract: Shares of the Celgene Corporation rose 5.9 percent yesterday after regulators approved the company's Revlimid capsule for a rare blood cancer, a treatment that will cost pharmacies $215 to $225 a pill.     The Food and Drug Administration cleared Revlimid for myelodysplastic syndromes, which cause anemia and infections.

headline: Iran Reports Making Bid to Resume Nuclear Talks
abstract: Iran says it has asked three European countries involved in stalled negotiations over its nuclear program to resume talks; at same time, it says it has allowed United Nations inspectors to visit military site, in reversal of earlier decision; Germany, Britain and France had stopped talks after Pres Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's government defied agreement by resuming work at uranium conversion plant; Europeam countries say work at plant must be suspended before they resume talks (M)

headline: Lawyer's Slaying Raises Questions on Hussein Trial
abstract: The execution-style killing of a defense lawyer in the trial of Saddam Hussein and some top associates shocked Iraqi and American officials on Friday and renewed doubts about whether it is possible to hold a fair trial in the midst of a war that has spurred a wave of revenge killings against people linked to Mr. Hussein.     A group of a dozen armed men seized the lawyer, Sadoun al-Janabi, from his Baghdad office at 10 p.m. on Thursday and his body, with two bullet wounds to the head, was found in a rubbish-strewn lot nearby about an hour later, an Iraqi police spokesman said. The killing occurred less than 36 hours after Mr. Hussein's trial began on Wednesday, with live television coverage that identified Mr. Janabi by name and showed close-ups of him presenting arguments in the court on behalf of his client, Awad Hamed al-Bander, the former head of the Revolutionary Court under Mr. Hussein.

headline: Leak-case Web site
Tokyo Exchange Struggles With Snarls in Electronics
abstract: What exactly is going on at the Tokyo Stock Exchange?     Last month, a computer glitch shut down trading on the exchange, the world's second-largest after the New York Stock Exchange, for almost an entire day. Then last week, a typographical error by the Mizuho Securities brokerage generated a $330 million loss. On Friday, the prime minister demanded corrective steps, and regulators began an investigation.

headline: Colombia Government Threatens Death Squad
abstract: Colombian government warns of military strikes against United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, country's largest death squad; warning comes day after third high official of Colombian secret police is forced to resign amid disclosures that secret police were preparing to sell intelligence to right-wing paramilitaries (S)

headline: Leading diamond appraiser in bribery inquiry
Medicare Says Bonuses Can Improve Hospital Care
abstract: Medicare officials says government's experimental performance-based bonus system for hospitals has shown that linking hospital payments to quality of patient care can significantly improve level of care; under three-year tst program, involving about 270 hospitals, Medicare is paying 123 that were top performers an additional $8.85 million, first time it has paid performance bonuses (M)

headline: Ex-Official at Wal-Mart Wins Ruling
abstract: Benton County, Ark, circuit judge, Jay Finch, tosses out part of Wal-Mart's lawsuit against its former vice chairman, Thomas M Coughlin, citing agreement that bars Coughlin and company from suing each other; Wal-Mart sued to prevent Coughlin from collecting about $12 million worth of retirement benefits; has accused Coughlin of using company funds to pay for personal items (M)

headline: Focusing on Quake Aid, Pakistan Delays F-16 Purchase
abstract: Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, said Friday that he would postpone the purchase of F-16 fighter jets from the United States as his country grappled with the devastation caused by the Oct. 8 earthquake, which has claimed more than 73,000 lives.      The president made the announcement while visiting Muzaffarabad, the flattened capital of the Pakistani-controlled part of Kashmir, the Himalayan region claimed by both India and Pakistan. The 7.6-magnitude earthquake razed almost all major cities and towns in Pakistani Kashmir and caused severe destruction in northern Pakistan.

headline: Ukraine confirms bird flu
U.S. agrees to relocate base from Okinawa
Hollywood Unions Object to Product Placement on TV
abstract: Writers Guild of America and Screen Actors Guild denounce creeping practice of integrating commercial products into story lines of television shows, including The Apprentice, All My Children and even prime-time scripted hits like Desperate Housewives; say 'stealth advertising' deceives audiences and forces writers and actors to do jobs they were not hired for; call for clearer disclosure to viewers and for greater say in matter by actors and writers (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Holiday Spending on Internet Shows Increase Over Last Year  American consumers spent 26 percent more money online over the holiday weekend than they did in 2004, according to newly released figures. And after a long weekend of pointing and clicking, millions kept right on shopping at work Monday, beginning at 9 a.m., retailers said, validating the holiday shopping season's latest buzz phrase, Cyber Monday. [Page C1.]    By most measures, the economy appears to be booming, but that does not mean the broad economic picture will be better next year. Investors, whose stock-buying had been fueling an end-of-year rally, fear that the latest positive figures will lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates more than expected. In turn, that could further slow the housing market, dampen consumer spending and crimp corporate profits. [A1.]    Icahn Enlists Wasserstein for Time Warner Fight  Carl C. Icahn, who is leading a group of dissident investors in a campaign against Time Warner and its board, said that he had hired Bruce Wasserstein and his firm, Lazard, to help advance the fight. [C1.]    Capus Named President of NBC News Division  Nearly a year after shepherding the handoff from Tom Brokaw to Brian Williams as the executive producer of ''NBC Nightly News,'' Steve Capus, left, was promoted to president of the network's news division. The appointment, which was announced by Jeff Zucker, president of NBC Universal Television Group, caps a meteoric year for Mr. Capus, 42, who was promoted to senior vice president of the news division in June and acting president in September. Mr. Capus assumes his job, in which he will oversee not only NBC News but also the MSNBC cable channel and Web site, at a moment of rapid transformation in broadcast news and in television over all. [E1.]    Impasse on Subsidies Could Lead to Lawsuits, Experts Say  A failure by the United States and the European Union to make significant progress toward reducing agricultural subsidies in the coming trade talks in Hong Kong could bring upon a slew of legal challenges to farm-support programs on both sides of the Atlantic, trade and agricultural experts say. [C1.]    Intel Is Set to Announce Home Media Partnerships  Intel is expected to announce that it has entered into partnerships with several movie, music and game providers to introduce content that would work with its new Viiv technology for home media centers. [C4.]    Moscow Utility Warns of Winter Blackouts  Moscow could face rolling blackouts during periods of extreme cold this winter, the head of the electricity monopoly said, dramatizing the need for fresh investment in the country's crumbling electrical grid. [C5.]    Dubai to Acquire British Shipping Company  Dubai, the upstart sheikdom of the United Arab Emirates, has agreed to purchase the British shipping company Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation for ¬£3.3 billion ($5.7 billion). [C5.]    Australia to Pour Surpluses Into Fund for Pensions  The Australian government has elected to plow roughly $15 billion in surpluses, together with the $18.5 billion it expects to earn from the sale of the rest of its former phone monopoly into a professionally managed investment fund. The goal is to raise the $103 billion that the government estimates it will need by 2020 to pay pensions owed to its workers. [C5.]    Advertisers Encourage Holiday Self-Indulgence  Some retailers are playing to one of the season's guilty pleasures: shoppers buying gifts for themselves. Advertising. [C1.]    Dow Average Fails to Sustain Early Rally  The Dow Jones industrial average lost 2.56 points, or 0.02 percent, to 10,888.16, after gaining almost 70 points early in the session. The S.& P. 500 was up 0.02 point at 1,257.48, while the Nasdaq fell 6.66, to 2,232.71. [C9.]    F.C.C. Chairman Proposes Cable Package Changes  Kevin J. Martin, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, proposed that cable and satellite television companies provide customers with more choices to reject some channels as part of a broader effort at combating indecency on the airwaves. [C3.]    Calpine's Stock Plummets as It Replaces Top Officials  Calpine, a producer and seller of electricity, replaced its chief executive and its chief financial officer, as it struggles with a $17 billion debt load and a recent court ruling that restricts its ability to buy fuel for its plants. Calpine's stock and bonds fell sharply on speculation that the company might file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Calpine has been weighed down by accounting and power pricing issues that arose from the Enron collapse and the California power crisis. [C9.]    Fox Network Signs Cowell to a Five-Year Contract  The Fox network announced that it had signed its most important star, Simon Cowell of ''American Idol,'' to a five-year contract. [C4.]    Plan Would Allow Proxies to Be Sent Via Web  Corporations would be allowed to post proxy statements and annual reports on Web sites, instead of sending them through the mail, under a plan proposed Tuesday by federal regulators. [C8.]

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 29 in Crowded Baghdad Restaurant
abstract: The bombing, one of the most deadly in the Iraqi capital in recent months, was claimed by Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia.

headline: World Briefing: Asia, Africa, Europe
abstract: ASIA.

headline: Briefly: Serono soars as it studies sale
Indonesian generals tell of gold miner 'support'
Telef√≥nica to Buy British Phone Company for $31.5 Billion
abstract: The deal brings together O2's 25 million mobile customers in Britain, Germany and Ireland with Telef√É¬≥nica's 145 million customers, mainly in Spain and Latin America.

headline: Merkel is dealt another setback
Viacom Executive Is Leaving for Post at Fox's Stations Group
abstract: Dennis Swanson, a much-traveled television executive, will leave his post as executive vice president of the Viacom stations division, which operates the stations of the CBS and UPN networks, to become the president of station operations for the Fox Television Stations Group, Fox announced yesterday.     The move means that Mr. Swanson will complete a full circuit of executive jobs, working at all four major networks. He compiled his long television r√©sum√© mostly at ABC, where at various times he ran the sports, daytime and children's programming divisions, as well as that network's stations division. He also worked at NBC, where he managed the network's flagship outlet, WNBC in New York. He joined CBS in 2002.

headline: Bosnians reach deal to modify charter
World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Leader Calls Bail-Jumper 'Shameful'
abstract: Speaking publicly for the first time on the graft scandal that has engulfed the oil-rich state of Bayelsa since its governor, Diepreye Alamieyeseigha, left, jumped bail in London last month and, dressed as a woman, fled money-laundering charges, President Olusegun Obasanjo said the governor's conduct was ''shameful'' and condemned the crowds that gathered to cheer him. Mr. Alamieyeseigha, accused of stealing millions of dollars from the state treasury, was expelled from the president's party this week.   Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

headline: Guidant Shares Go Lower After Subpoenas on Devices
abstract: Shares of Guidant Corp, heart device maker, decline as investors take news that company has received two Justice Department subpoenas as further sign that Johnson & Johnson will reduce or abandon its $25.4 billion offer to buy Guidant (M)

headline: Thousands gather in Hong Kong for first WTO protest
Briefs: Government critic found slain at home
Roche May Allow Others to Make Its Flu Drug
abstract: Facing pressure from governments seeking to fight a possible bird flu epidemic, Roche said it was willing to negotiate allowing outside companies to make its drug Tamiflu.

headline: Ferry Dispute Tests Ireland's Tolerance for Globalization
abstract: When nearly 100,000 people took to the streets of Ireland earlier this month to protest the hiring of cheap East European labor for Irish Ferries, they gave voice to old familiar fears about job security that many thought had been forgotten.      The last time similar crowds demonstrated here over industrial issues was in 1979, when young people were leaving the country in droves to find work and Ireland's unemployment rate was hovering around 20 percent.

headline: Engineer's warning system a lifesaver for air travelers
Gene Therapy in a Bottle of Mouthwash
abstract: Colgate-Palmolive and Introgen Therapeutics, Austin, Tex, biotechnology company, announce alliance to incorporate gene therapy into mouthwashes, gels and similar products to treat and prevent oral cancers; Colgate is buying 9.7 percent stake in Introgen for about $20 million, or $5.54 per share; Introgen's gene-therapy method puts tumor supressor genes into cancerous cells to stop growth of tumors (M)

headline: While Iraq Counts Votes, Politicians Vie for Leverage
abstract: As election workers continued counting ballots from Thursday's elections, political leaders began talks on Saturday to stake out their positions in advance of forming the new, four-year government.     A two-thirds vote by the coming Council of Representatives will be needed to install the executive officers, so parties will have to band together to form a coalition or national unity government. The parties with the most seats in the council are expected to negotiate fiercely for weeks -- if not months -- over top offices and control of ministries, as well as broader issues like regional autonomy and oil revenues.

headline: Currencies: Dollar rises strongly on economic data
Qwest Expected to Announce a Settlement
abstract: Qwest Communications International is expected to announce $400 million settlement of its largest shareholder lawsuits relating to accounting scandal; deal will cover Qwest, some former executives and its directors--but will not include former chief executive Joseph P Nacchio and former chief financial officer Robert S Woodruff (S)

headline: Equities ride out a stormy quarter
Scientists Find the T-Rex of Crocodiles
abstract: Discovery of large sea-dwelling crocodile that lived 135 million years ago, in middle of dinosaur era, is being announced in journal Science; it was found in Patagonia region in 1996; article culminates nine years of study; photo (M)

headline: EU-Israeli-Arab talksyield limited results
AOL Deal May Omit Stake Sale
abstract: Time Warner Inc is still in negotiations with Microsoft and Google over variety of potential deals involving its AOL unit; most of possibilities under discussion do not involve either company's buying stake in AOL; they would involve cooperation on Web search, advertising sales and possibly other areas; Time Warner's leadership has been under pressure from financier Carl C Icahn, who asserts that company is mismanaged and undervalued and has hired Lazard to explore options for splitting it up (M)

headline: Judge in Germany orders retrial on merger payouts
Judge Restricts Use of Calpine Money
abstract: The Calpine Corporation, owner of the largest United States network of gas-fired power plants, was barred yesterday by a judge from using $400 million in a frozen account to buy natural gas for its generators. Calpine shares fell to a record low.     Judge Leo E. Strine Jr. of Delaware Chancery Court said Calpine officials ran afoul of agreements with noteholders by seeking to use proceeds of asset sales to buy stored gas. He ordered the Bank of New York to maintain a freeze on the account and deferred a decision on the return of hundreds of millions of dollars Calpine has already spent on fuel.

headline: Mob Assails Former Prime Minister in Iraq
abstract: Ayad Allawi, who escaped unharmed, later characterized the attack in the Shiite holy city of Najaf as an assassination attempt.

headline: Agency faces scrutiny over heartworm drug for dogs
An IPod Worth Keeping An Eye On
abstract: David Pogue reviews Apple Computer's new Video iPod; photo (M)

headline: Top officer lauds U.S. forces abroad
Japan panel to back women on throne
Steps to Take Before the Collective Well Runs Dry
abstract: BEFORE Doug Pushard, a software company manager, steps into the shower in his home in Austin, Tex., he puts a pail into the tub to catch the cold water that flows through the pipes before it turns hot. After showering, he bathes his garden with the cool gallons he has collected.     But that's just the proverbial drop in the bucket when it comes to how far Mr. Pushard will go to use water efficiently. He also harvests rain from his roof into two covered 2,500-gallon tanks in the backyard. The water enters through pipes linked to the roof's gutters and exits to the garden's drip-irrigation channels.

headline: But for workers, clouds are gathering
Gaza Gets Ready for a Harvest of Produce and Promise
abstract: Palestinians will begin harvesting estimated $20 million worth of produce grown in greenhouses left behind by settlers in Gaza; most of crop is intended for export, with Palestinians using same Israeli export companies that Gaza settlers used; biggest concern is Karni border crossing between Gaza and Israel, even after Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice brokered agreement on agricultural exports; harvest will be first tangible measure of development in Gaza, which has been in economic free fall for most of past five years; Israel sees prosperous economy in Gaza as ingredient for getting peace process back on track; photos (M)

headline: Nissan to Move U.S. Headquarters to Tennessee
abstract: The main reason for the move was to save money, said Carlos Ghosn, Nissan's chief executive, who has earned near-legendary status for his cost-cutting plans.

headline: French state of emergency
Rumsfeld Strikes Less Severe Tone in China
abstract: The Secretary of Defense's visit to China comes in advance of a trip here by President Bush next month.

headline: Philippine government opens inquiry in spy case
Storms help lift ABB profit
Natural Gas: Big Worry This Winter
abstract: Fears are being voiced about natural gas shortage this winter and soaring prices; Energy Information Administration predicts that cost of heating typical home with natural gas could rise by more than 40 percent in coming months; businesses face possible disruptions in supply in some states this winter, since utilities are required to give highest priority to supplying homes; demand has been outstripping supply for several years thanks to huge buildup of natural-gas-fired electricity plants in 1990's even as exploration has slowed; energy industry and major consumers of natural gas are aggressively pushing Congress to open areas for exploration, but with little success so far; industry also faces fierce opposition from environmentalists, real estate investors and residents of areas where it would like to put operations intended to increase imports of natural gas; photos; graph (M)

headline: Syria Police Foil Terrorists
abstract: Syria's state-run news agency says police clashed with suspected Islamic terrorists in northern city of Aleppo, foiling their plans to bomb sites in city; Al Jazeera television reports several suspected terrorists blew up their own car after finding themselves surrounded by Syrian police (S)

headline: Letter from the Middle East: Divisions and demons plague road to peace
Serono settlesU.S. charges
Finland Rekindles Interest in Nuclear Power
abstract: Finland is nothing if not pragmatic and law abiding.     So when Finland, a country with a long memory of the Chernobyl disaster in 1986 and considerable environmental bona fides, chose to move ahead this year with the construction of the world's largest nuclear reactor, the nuclear industry portrayed it as a victory, one that would force the rest of Western Europe to take note.

headline: Mainland affirms one-party rule
G.M. Announces Decision to Cut 5,000 More Jobs
abstract: General Motors announces three-year plan of 5,000 more jobs cuts in addition to 25,000 previously announced, but analysts say blueprint lacks speed and breadth that helped rivals make comebacks; chief executive Rick Wagoner expresses confidence that restructuring will help reverse more than $2 billion in losses this year; cuts and closing of all or parts of dozen installations will still leave GM with more capacity than sales; analysts warn that such inefficiency, along with hesitant leadership, lackluster designs and costly health and pension plans still put GM at disadvantage; photos; map; graphs; Toyota alone is building two more North American plants and rivals Carlos Ghosn at Nissan and Dieter Zetsche at Chrysler have rolled out popular new models and cut spending steeply; Wagoner does not say when GM expects to make money again or how much savings revamping will yield; Wall Street is unimpressed and shares decline modestly; Wharton professor John Paul MacDuffie observes that Wagoner, in post five years, was trained for era when GM intimidated competitors; rivals now have clear identities, commitment to environmentally friendly products and customers who do not need incentives to buy; GM to close assembly plants in Oklahoma City, Lansing, Georgia and Ontario and close assembly line at Saturn's Tennessee plant, known for labor-management cooperation; expects jobs cuts by attrition including retirements and buyout packages being negotiated with UAW (M)

headline: Japanese music industry calls for an 'iPod tax'
Briefs: S&P lifts Russia's rating for debt, citing oil prices
